reviewText: Playing this game is rather like watching the proverbial train wreck: you'll be horrified, but you can't look away. This is in no way a bad thing. Spec Ops wants to tell a story about soldiers in war. But unlike games such as Call of Duty, it doesn't want you to feel like an awesome, unstoppable killing machine that's fighting terrorism FOR 'MERICA!!! or whatever; it wants you to see that war is not glamorous, awesome, fun, or desirable. It wants you to see the terrible toll that combat can exact on those who experience it. And above all, it wants you to see that in real conflict, there are no good guys" and "bad guys
date:
and the world is full of gray areas. War is hell, and anyone who goes in will either join the fortunate dead...or have to live with what they've done to survive.

Spec Ops is a third-person cover-based shooter that alternates between desert environments and crumbling urban ruin. You have two squadmates who can be directed to attack specific targets or heal a fallen comrade; they're pretty good at following orders in a timely fashion and, unlike some other AI partners, they're not highly prone to getting themselves shot constantly or hung up on the level geometry. Enemies are decently clever, more than willing to flank you, toss grenades to get you out of cover, or trick you into walking right into a Heavy Trooper's line of fire.

The game also offers the clever idea of having drifts of sand piled up on fragile surfaces like windows, which you can shoot out to bury your enemies. It doesn't show up that often, but it's kind of neat when it's there.

There's the usual shooter stable of weapons: pistols, heavy pistols, shotguns, sniper rifles, etc. They sound good and feel decently punchy, and aiming is never a problem. Most weapons also have an alternate fire mode, which does add a little depth to the combat.

I didn't play the multiplayer, so I can't honestly review it. I will say the developers originally didn't even want multiplayer, and the campaign is designed well enough to stand on its own, so make of that what you will.

I highly recommend this game. It is a breath of fresh air in an over-crowded genre that's becoming increasingly generic. This game is also visually stunning, with exceptional voice acting, and sound. It is definitely worth the money and the effort to play the game from the beginning to the end.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line might be dismissed at first glance for being just another modern military shooter. That assumption couldn’t be more wrong though.

Based loosely on Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness, Spec Ops provides one of the strongest and mature narratives in recent memory.

The story revolves around Captain Walker and his two wingmen, Lugo and Adams. Their latest mission sends them to a post-catastrophic Dubai to find Colonel Konrad who was in charge of evacuating the civilian population. Captain Walker is often forced to make difficult decisions and any pretense of him being some badass hero is quickly removed as it's clear that sometimes there's no correct decision to make. The character progression is strong and the voice acting is phenomenal.

The art direction is spectacular as Dubai provides almost a surreal experience. When you’re not avoiding sandstorms, you'll travel through luxury hotels and buildings that have all been submerged in sand. The game also gives you a taste of PTSD as you’re sometimes left wondering whether or not certain things are real.

The combat plays out similarly to other third person shooters. It will have you taking cover, blind firing and issuing commands to your squad mates. The AI is well done, making Lugo and Adams feel very capable while the enemy AI on the other hand could use a bit of work. The combat is solid but it makes no attempt to do anything new or innovative.

The soundtrack is fantastic, including a lot of real songs along with ambient guitar pieces that match the mood perfectly. The inclusion of Jimi Hendrix and other classics really give the game an ‘Apocalypse Now’ type of feel which was another Heart of Darkness adaptation.

Unfortunately, Spec Ops is fairly short (around 5 hours) but the different endings offer some incentive to replay the game. There’s a multiplayer mode that offers a few different game types, weapons, and stages but it feels a bit tacked on. It’s fairly clear that Spec Ops was designed to be experienced as a single player game primarily and it’s one I strongly recommend.

For a more detailed review, here’s a video by my friend and fellow reviewer, Trent:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rnHItiRiBbs

Pros
+	Amazing Narrative
+	Fantastic Soundtrack
+	Beautiful Art Direction & Environments
+	Great Characters & Voice Acting

Cons
-	Short length & Linear
-	Generic Combat
-	Multiplayer isn’t very exciting


If you enjoyed this review, feel free to follow me as a Steam Curator: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/4886473/

reviewText:
Finishing Spec Ops The Line was a dreadfully exausting experience.
I walked along a man who's mental brakedown was more stable than my own, I felt remorse and sickness of everything I've done, I reflected upon war, death and life and in the end, I was sitting in front of a PC , trying to figure out why Yager hates me so much and why they would make such a horrible, HORRIBLY harsh journey to drive me into depression.

After a walk on the park, a cup of tea, donating to a charity and helping an old lady cross the street, I still feel like a ♥♥♥♥ing monster, a cruel, unmerciful, selfish meatbag....and probably will for the rest of my life.


EDIT :
Since this is somehow once of the most popular reviews of the game (top 10) I rather expand my thoughts.

This is pure and simple, my personal favorite game of all time. I just cant put into words how powerful it was to me. People will be against this opinion, but this is no doubts in my book the Culmination of what a game can be narrative wise. Last of Us, Undertale , nothing comes closer.

So, as someone who digs story and literature, this game sounded like a treat!
A great 3rd person shooter with unique setting and a good story.
I quickly realized that it was a not mistake to go in full blind. Honestly, it was the most twisted , exausting, tense, emotion packed experience I ever encountered in a medium. The sheer raw brutality and straightfoward truth of the whole narrative drew me in from the get-go.
Everything helped to make the game feel incredible (in a harmful way)

The controls are a bit cluncky at first, but nothing some practice can fix. Its still a very accesible game, that anyone who played shooters (or not) before can handle.

The voice acting is Oscar worthy. Not a single line was wasted or weak. Especially the main cast really nail the dialouge. Belive me when I say few times I really FELT a game protagonist was a human being. Nolan North really sounds like a tired, angry, traumatized war victim.

The graphics, especially with everything cranked up to the max, are ****ing beautiful, the aestetic is superb and the levels are very well desinged.

The sound is overall intense and loud, each fight is nerve wracking to the extreme.

Soundtrack is outstanding and fitting to the themes.

The overall story is open to your conclusions, which leads to very interesting interpretations from players.

Multiplayer is NOT totally dead. A fellow user has made up a group that organises matches frequently. You can join if you want ! MP is sorta good. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Expendables-reality

I could go on forever, but I rather not saturate you.
Just buy it whenever possible.
This was the most incredible game I ever played, and I hope you can someday see why.

We do what is nesessary...and If we are lucky

reviewText:
It's been a year since I picked up the game, and I still cannot bear to play it again when I think of what overcame me when I finished the game.

As my playtime indicates, I finished this in a massive rush. I played from 11pm to 4am, expecting that the game was some sort of quick-play game that I could put down easily at any time, like, say, call of duty (oh good grief, even the comparison makes me cringe). I was so driven to finish the game (the mission, as it were) much like Walker was. This revelation made me hate myself beyond belief, as I realized the very same determination, the self-same urge to commit to a goal made me ignore warning signs all over the place. This game makes you truly explore yourself, the deepest darkest recesses of your psyche where the hidden threads of psychopathy lie.

When I finally finished the game at 4am, I was unable to sleep. I stayed awake, tormented by what I had done and the face of the white phosphorus burnt mother and child. I kept telling myself: This is a game. Get over it and get to sleep."

reviewText:
Every once in awhile, what I call a crime is committed in this industry, a game will be released and end up being one of the greatest games I've ever played. However for one reason or another, it ends up doing horribly. Spec Ops: The Line may be the biggest crime I've ever witnessed...

Spec Ops puts you in the shoes of Captain Walker, you and two squad mates are sent into a sandstorm destroyed Dubai to find survivors. At first glance the game may appear to be another Call Of Duty type of modern shooter. Disaster occurs and America comes in to save the day, but that is definitely not the case.

The first thing I noticed about this game is how beautiful it is, some may disagree, but Spec Ops on PC with max settings truly looks next gen to me, and this game was released a good while before next gen was a thing. The animation complements this point, for example since Dubai is a city destroyed by uncontrollable sandstorms, you will be traveling through a lot of buildings that are now buried deep below the sand. The moment when I first shot out a giant window I gleefully watched as the sand poured in and buried alive an entire squad of soldiers.

Everything that should be good in a 3rd person shooter gameplay wise is present in this game, but I do not want to waste any time so I'll just tell you about the one thing in Spec Ops that will make you love it, the story. This is hands down the greatest story I have ever had the pleasure of playing in a Modern War" shooter. Within the first couple levels

reviewText:
A series of dust storms has destroyed much of Dubai, leaving countless civilians stranded. The 33rd Battalion, a United States infantry unit, is sent to provide aid but soon disappears. In a last ditch effort, a three-man Delta Force team is sent in to find out what happened and rescue survivors. As captain of this reconnaissance team it is up to you and your teammates to fight your way across the city and find answers.

Spec Ops: The Line is a third person shooter where you will find that you are heavily reliant on cover. You have the ability to command your teammates in battle, telling them who to target. Combat is fast paced and fun, albeit a bit generic. My main complaint with combat would be that the AI sometimes feels a bit clumsy, but nothing bad enough to be game breaking.

The game is very story rich and is definitely worth paying attention to. Occasionally you will be forced to make some very difficult decisions. What I liked about this is that there is never really a “right” or “wrong” answer. Unlike some military shooters, this game does not glorify war. Instead it touches on the horrors of war and the profound psychological impact it often has on those who experience it.

The environment is absolutely breathtaking, by far my favorite in any game ever. They did a wonderful job at making Dubai look so ruined yet beautiful, resulting in a few areas where you have to stop just to admire your surroundings.

I realize that this can vary quite a bit from person to person but I was pleasantly surprised by the music used in the game. Quite a few classics including Hendrix and Deep Purple, as well as some more modern but worthwhile bands such as the Black Angels. If that’s not your thing, it’s still worth mentioning that the original score is pretty solid.

I’m normally extremely skeptical of military shooters, but this game is something else entirely and is now considered among my favorite games.  A bit shorter than I would have liked it to be, but still one that I would highly recommend.

reviewText:
Pros:
- INCREDIBLE story
- Immersive environments
- Appropriately timed battles
- Setting actually feels like a post-apocalyptic Dubai
- Interesting political twists
- Vibrant graphics and textures

Cons:
- Controls are meh
- Slow start (not in vain, however)
- Gameplay is mundane

I enjoyed playing Spec Ops: The Line, but nothing blew me away, except for the story. It took me a while to really understand it, and the significance of the ending was a little bit Bioshock: Infinite-esque, so I'd really suggest paying attention to the cutscenes. The gameplay was pretty average and mundane for a third-person shooter, but the controls were the only nuisance I had. By default, they're unconventional and require some time to get used to. They remind me of the Mass Effect controls, but aren't nearly as polished. For example, sometimes I died from jumping over a box instead of taking cover behind it. Despite these cons, the atypical, dark, and twisting story overshadows its faults. The length of the game on the normal setting is just right. I can't think of any gaps in the plot that would extend the length.

Overall, it was a comfortable game to play and I'd definitely recommend grabbing it when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is not a game. No, I refuse to call it a game. Instead, a more fitting way to label this piece of work would be, 'art'. Plain and simple. Just as the 'Fountain' by Marcel Duchamp was a big slap to the face for the art commmunity on 'What is Art?', Spec Ops: The Line does the same for the Gaming Community on, 'What are Modern Military Shooters?' It takes the Badass, Stone-Cold, Heroic and invulnerable killing machine protaganist typical in your everyday Military Shooter and tears it to pieces with its masterful story.

This poigant work will really help making you wonder what it means to be a hero and needs to be played in order to be understood. To be honest, I feel like I ripped off the developers for buying this game when it was on a $6 deal.
________________________________________________________________
Story

Dubai was hit with a series of sandstorm that ravaged the city and turned it into a Kid's Sandbox basically. Colonel John Konrad, a decorated Officer in the US army and the 33rd 'Damned' Infantry Regiment volunteered to help the evacuated the city. Nothing was heard from them ever since until 6 Months Later when a Distress Signal by Konrad himself reaches out to the world. This is where you come in. You're Captain Walker, leader of a 3 Man Delta Team Operative sent to investigate Dubai for any survivors. (Cliche, Badass 3 Man Special Forces Protaganist trying to get stuff done and take care of business where others failed.)

This is about as much as you need to know to understand what's going on.
________________________________________________________________
Gameplay
(AI)
Enemy AI seem to be good enough, alway shouting out what their doing and responding to each other in turn. There are 4 types of enemies Regular, Close-Combat, Sniper and Heavy. * = can be armoured, ie more durable
Regular* - The Grunts. SMG/Shotgunners/Assault Rifle all day, everyday. Shotgunners tend to charge at you which can be a danger
Close-Combat - Remember that Banzai Soldier from World at War? This is him except that its 1 hit kill, he dodges and insta-kills you with his knife when he gets close (Yes, no QTE)
Sniper* - He snipes? Also has shiny red laser sight which you can see since its tagging you
Heavy* - Always comes armoured and just like the Bulldozer from Payday 2, his face is his weakspot. There are 2 varieties of the 'Heavy', M249 Saw or AA12. Either way you're boned as they love walking straight up to you... Jerks

Don't worry about your AI though as they are okay-ish enough to get stuff done though they tend to go suicidal when you issue an attack order. They have no problem in getting kills or distracting enemies and will always shout out enemies of interest during a firefight such as, Shotgunner coming from the right!". Take note that this needs to be heard as battle lines are not subtitled. What can be annoying though is when they take too much damamge
date: they need to be revived and you have a time limit but you don't have the ability to be revived (On Hard
recommended:
idk about normal and easy)

(Core)
The meat of the game comes from being a Cover-Based Third Person Shooter reminiscent to that of games like Gears of War. Basically
hoursPlayed: you sprint form cover to cover (Using a Toggle Key 'Space') and rely on Regenerating Health. The lower your health
voteText: the more bloodied your screen becomes in addition to being Black and White (CoD anyone?). There are 15 weapons in total give or take which felt the same with only the diffference being its 'Alternate Function' key which is 'C'. There are also 3 grenade types
helpfulPercent: Frag
votesHelpful: Sticky and Stun which are pretty self-explanatory. You can carry 2 weapons and all 3 grenade types at once. However
votesTotal: you are only limited to 3 grenades per type making the total number of grenades which can be carried to 9(3 Frags/3 Stickies/3 Stuns). Different from other games is how ammo is obtained here. While there is still the basic
votesFunny: 'pick up ammo from dead body so long as same weapon' concept
commentsCount: what Spec Ops has added to spice it up is that in this game is that you can actually Execute wounded enemies to get ammo for your current weapon type. Because you know.. Executions are fun. Be fast though or they'll bleed out to death(GoW anyone)\n\nIn a nutshell
column16:
it's your run of the mill Third Person Cover based shooter like Gears of War or Future Soldier.. Just like any other games where you're the unstoppable saviour of your country.

(Command)
As Leader
column17: you have control of 2 Squad Mates who use order via the MMB. They are:\nLieutenant Adams\nYour Heavy Weapons Specialist carrying the M249 Saw. Order him to attack an enemy so long as their close and he'll do two things. FIrst
column18: he unleashes hell on them with suppressive fire from his weapon. Second
column19: he throws a frag which finds its mark 90% of the time
column20:
the 10% due to the enemy running away from it

Sergeant Lugo
Your Sniper. Order him to attack an enemy from long range and he'll kill the guy so long as he has vision. Though it takes some time for him to pull the trigger
column21: its usually a 1-shot kill\n\nAs you can see
column22:
the command aspect in this game is very weak but simple enough to make life easy.

(Environment)
Alongside your Red Explosive Containers
column23: you also have the sand which can either help or hinder you. Firstly
column24: Sand can act as either an alternative form of Explosive Barrels. Secondly
column25: throwing an explosive into a pile of sand would create a sand cloud which effectively stuns all nearby enemies for a nice amount of time
column26: similar to Stun grenades if I'm not mistaken. Later in the game at set stages
column27: you'll come across Sandstorms which does two things. Making you unable to issue orders and increasing weapon spread. Extremely frustrating
column28:
especially on harder difficulties (15+ deaths on Hard)

Nothing revolutionary here really though I'll admit its interesting in theory.

(Misc)
Collectables are available in the game and are called Intels. The number of intels available in each level is shown by pressing Escape. It offers backstory to the world of Dubai and its inhabitants. As of the time this review was written
column29:
no Steam Trading Cards are available. Checkpoints in this game seem to be fair enough. 1 checkpoint pre and post engagement.
________________________________________________________________
Music and Sound

I like the music. It's nice... very Vietnam War-esque and is also perfectly timed and well-executed. It's either Gung Ho adrenaline fueled action or music that make you muse over your actions.

Sound also seems to be quite good though the sound of the AA12 doesn't seem to have too much force behind it. Other than that
column30: the sound can of this game can really make firefights here intense
column31:
especially on higher difficulties.
________________________________________________________________
Graphics

It looks nice enough if you really care so much about it. It's able to capture the violence and carnage you unleash (Yay carnage and violence cause that's what every military shooter needs right!... right?)
________________________________________________________________
Mutiplayer
There are two types of Multiplayer here.
Co-Op
2 players
column32:
4 levels. A bit of a challenge when communication between the two is lacking. Can be fun for the first few times though I believe that it will lose its charm as fast as you finish it
Competetive
4v4 PvP from what I heard though sadly the cream of this game comes from the SP hence why I never bothered to try it out.
________________________________________________________________
Overall

Story is honestly speaking the saving grace for this game. It's what made it so spectacular as the entire gameplay is bland
column33: rehashed and has been done countless times though it can be argued that the very fact that it copies its gameplay from other Military Games is what makes this so good. This is because of how Spec Ops question our beliefs on said game. Must buy."
column37: 121 of 128 people (95%) found this review helpful 8 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I will only review the Singleplayer aspect of the game.

My ImpressionOk... I was about to write a negative review for this game - it was a really hard way for me to play through it, but I finally managed to, after completely uninstalling the game twice.
Why I, despite that, do recommend this game and why I had so much difficulty getting it done I will tell you soon.

SummaryYou might be able to tell from this short overview, otherwise, you just have all the points clearly visible.

PositiveMediocreNegative+ Great Message+ Good Story~ quite short+ Cover System- Controls feel unresponsive and messy+ Realistic Damage- too slow recovery time~ I couldn't play properly with keyboard/mouse- aiming with a controller is a pain+ Using the environment, especially sand, to your advantage~ not possible everywhere+ Beautiful Dubai~ not so beautiful textures- Some really bad rendered cutscenes+ Cool and atmospheric music- Quite a few sound bugs+ Characters Evolve+ Choices matter~ or do they?
The StoryA three-headed Delta squad led by yourself is sent on a rescue mission to the once beautiful city of Dubai - now a wasteland covered in sand. In this hostile environment you are to find survivors of the 33rd Infantry Battalion who volunteered to evacuate the civilians of the city, afterwards received orders to abandon them and leave but disobeyed and broke contact since.
Throughout the game, you will see what happened in the five and a half months and how the order of command in the city turned around.
As it is, I think it's not a great story but it is beeing told in a unique way that shows a perspective you are normally not shown by the media. At the end of it, you will be able to emphasize with everybody but yourself - you might hate yourself, you might want to kill yourself (not in real life, mind you, but as the character you are playing) and you will regret everything.

The WorldDubai is beautiful - it has always been and even all those sandstorms couldn't take the beauty of the city away.
What however takes aways it's beauty are the tributes of war and the things that have long left the definition of 'war' and go into the fields of mutilation and violation.
There is quite a lot of detail - many posters and grafiti with different messages - some from the old face of Dubai like expensive cars and then the messages of the survivors, sometimes written in bloody red.
The textures are ok for the age of the game I guess and they are not your main focus anyway, they are pretty mushy at places, though.

The CharactersThe first man of your squad is 1st Lieutenant, heavy gunner, Alphonso Adams - a really loyal and devoted soldier - at the beginning, that is. However as the story progresses his attitude begins to change... for better?
Additionally, there is Sergeant John Lugo - your man with the Eagle Eye and the trusted engineer of the force. He makes it pretty clear what he thinks of the whole mission and the choices you make and his opinion is mostly not in your favor - you can image that this will not become better in the hot wheater of the desert.
Last but not least there is yours truly Captain Martin Walker, the character you get to play and make the decisions with, for your team. Decisions you won't like, decisions that are bad and worse - but that's just how decisions are in a war. His mental stability will begin to fade in the heat of battle and you won't know whats true and whats not anymore - whats good and whats bad - who is a friend and who is a foe. It becomes clearer that he suffers from PTSD[en.wikipedia.org] - which is not too unusual in the light of the situation.
But wait? I am forgetting John Konrad - Colonel John Konrad, commander of the 33rd Infantry Battalion who intended to help the people of Dubai but damned them instead... or did he?
The GameplayIt plays as a third-person shooter with quite a lot of tactical elements.
Control your squad: You can order Adams and Lugo to attack certain targets, it is also possible to ask for a distraction in the form of a flashbang. However be mindful that in the case of them going down, you have to get your men back up.
Stay in cover: The game has a simple cover system and you definitely have to use it - or die. Thankfully the linear levels are designed with a lot of cover in mind, so you will find something to crouch behind most of the time.
Use your environment: Sand... sand everywhere - but why not use it? Shoot windows and glass roofs to unleash a sand avalanche upon the members of The Damned or make your bullets find some explosives positioned near enemy cover.
To be or not to be: It's your choice - you make a call to live or let live... or do you? You get to decide between bad and worse, there isn't anything else in a war anyway... is there? Whatever you do, at the end of it, you have to go through with it and live with what you have done. You can keep telling yourself, that your hand was forced and there was no other way but is this what you really think?However, there is a big problem with all this: the movement.
I used to play this game with mouse and keyboard, but just couldn't navigate really well from cover to cover like this and soon found a lot of bullets in my belly, so I switched to my XBOX360 controller which made moving easier but aiming all the harder. Therefore, I could only play on the lowest difficulty and still died quite a lot.
Enhanced was this problem by the fact, that the damage you take is quite 'realistic', meaning you can endure some 3 shots at most. There is a regeneration system but it takes so much time to recover from just one graze that it makes the firefights feel like walking through instant glue.
This resulted in me quitting the game so many times - I could play through it, after all, mind you, but it was no fun at the beginning.

The SoundYou will get to enjoy quite nice and atmospheric music while you play - provided by Robert Darden - the Radioman of Dubai.
The voice acting is good but not all too good in my opinion, at times it just wasn't matching the situation however at others it perfectly did.
But I experienced a lot of sound bugs such as hearing my own steps behind me, noise while inside of a sandstorm - which was not resulting from it and the like. This often hurt the atmosphere and, therefor, decreased immersion.

The VerdictAt the end of the day, the game has a great anti-war attitude which is shown directly through the eyes of a high-ranking soldier suffering  and losing himself in what started as a rescue mission and ended as a suicide commando.
Nevertheless, it's being held back a lot by the gameplay, which feels poorly ported.
If you can live with the problems it has and manage to maneuver your squad safely through the sandy wasteland you are in for good a story.

NoteIf you have read this far - thank you.
I hope this review helped you in deciding to buy this game and if it did, I would be grateful for a 'thumbs up', if you didn't like it, you can give me a 'thumbs down' but I would be glad to hear your opinion on what you didn't like.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is influenced by the novella Heart of Darkness" and by the movie "Apocalypse Now"
The Line is an emotional rollercoaster that makes you question your actions and motives.
The Gameplay:
Spec Ops: The Line is your typical cover based TPS (Third-Person Shooter). It features your average modern weapons that you can see in other shooters that take place in a modern day setting: Call of Duty
date:

There is also the two gun limit like in many other modern shooters: Primary weapon / Secondary weapon.

The gameplay itself is not innovative at all. It doesn't add anything new to the genre: Shoot

I have to say
votesHelpful: though
votesTotal: that the gameplay in The Line is very smooth and the cover mechanics are one of the best i've seen. Sprinting to cover and vaulting over cover is very smooth. The gameplay is good
votesFunny:
fast and smooth...very well done. It's just that it doesn't add anything new.

The Story
Spec Ops: The Line may seem like your average military shooter at first but make no mistake! It is quite the opposite.
The game doesn't glorify war. You may play the game for 30-40 minutes and think that it's another one of these "murika fu'k yeh" games but it's not.
The story will change soon and it keeps coming up with surprises till the very end of the game. I can't say much about the story without giving away spoilers but all you need to know is this: This game has a story that has NEVER been done before in the TPS/FPS genre. When it comes to video gaming then this story is an unique pearl.
You have to trust me on this one.

Alright

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Spec Ops: The Line
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Third-Person; Shooter; Story Rich; Action; Psychological
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 8-14 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWSpec Ops: The Line is a modern-combat, over-the-shoulder shooter set in a post-cataclysmic event themed Dubai.  Unrelenting sandstorms have all but destroyed the city entirely; and the evacuation (aided by the US army) was a failure.  You go in, with your two Delta Squad buddies, to try to assess the situation and rescue any survivors.

The combat is solid, if not simple.  You take out enemies in standard over-the-shoulder shooter fashion mostly, with some ability to dish out commands to your squad members.  The atmosphere is top notch, and the visuals can be quite stunning.  The voice acting is solid, but some of the lines are cheesy in trying to be funny.  The controls are good, and the game itself is stable.  The gameplay is fun, but a little limited.  You won’t see very much variety in terms of squad commands, grenades, or guns; and can only have 2 equipped guns at a time—which fits the story but somewhat limits gameplay.  Still if you switch your weapons out here and there, picking them up from fallen foes (which you probably need to, as ammo is scarce) you can get just enough variety.

One major strong point for the game is the story.  And not just the story itself, but the way it is told.  The pacing of the story keeps you moving from one combat scene to the next, intrigued with the notion of finding out what comes next.  There are some minor decisions to be made here and there; they don’t have a major effect on the progression of the game—they more so just allow you define the character you play.  The final decisions you make, however, will determine which of several endings you will see.  (You can see all endings by replaying just the last level, no matter the other decisions you made).

Another major strong point for the game is the atmosphere.  The setting and general theme of the game are constructed quite well.  It is a bit Hollywood-style sensationalist with the sandstorms completely destroying Dubai; but at the same time it’s pretty awesome because it makes for quite a novel setting for a modern-combat game.  However, it does put a restriction on the variety of locales in the game, but that’s OK.

All in all, Spec Ops: The Line is a very well put together, story-driven, third-person shooter experience with a great setting.  Highly recommended for fans of a good story, modern-combat FPS/TPS, and a powerful atmosphere.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
SO:TL is dark. Don't be fooled by the sun reflecting off Dubai's sand dunes, this game pulls no punches in bringing the horrors of war to you.

The game plays like a standard 3rd-person cover-based shooter, but all the interesting aspects of the game simply use that as the foundation. You control a small squad as they search for what happened to the American troops that were sent to help evacuate Dubai, and slowly uncover the truth. Its all brought home by some stunning environments and incredible sound design, and the story itself challenges the player to maintain their own humanity when there's none left around them.

The campaign is quite short, but I played it through on FUBAR difficulty as I enjoyed the game so much. There are a couple of scenes where the difficulty spikes (the Freebird" scene being the main offender!) but for most of the game it is fairly well paced.

There are plenty of twists and lots of clues as to what is going on
date: just sit back and enjoy the ride. Anyone who enjoys modern shooters owes it to themselves to complete this game at least once."

reviewText:
Spec Ops really is as good as people say it is.  I'm extremely surprised that 2K didn't promote it more, it just popped out of nowhere without much of an explanation.

The game is a third-person cover shooter, which I thought was an odd choice given the type of game it is.  That said, it actually works very well.  While I'm not a particular fan of cover shooters, I actually enjoyed it here.  There's a decent variety of military weapons to work with along with several grenades including a sticky grenade which I'm pretty sure isn't real so I'm not sure why they included it.  It's fun to use though.

Graphics are decent, nothing special.  It was designed as a console game with no special PC features so I was able to get a constant 60 FPS on a GTX 260 at max settings.

The real strength of this game is the story.  It is extremely well written, perhaps one of the best written games I have ever played.  No other military shooter comes even close.  I'm not going to give any spoilers, but it really draws you in and makes you feel part of the story.  It is a lesson to the Call of Dutys and Battlefields how a single player experience should be.

There are a few tweaks you should use to fully enjoy the game.  If you want to use keyboard+mouse like I did, you will need to visit the game forum and download an INI decrypter so you can disable the mouse acceleration (it's REALLY bad.)  Flawless Widescreen also has support for this game so you can increase the FOV.  Once you do that, the game handles very well, though the combo controls can be annoying.

Pick up this game when you can, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Maybe you came from Call of Duty? What about Battlefield? Perhaps you came from ArmA? It doesn't matter.

What does matter is that Spec Ops: The Line is different from all 3.

In a good way.

A very good way.

A ridiculously good way that will make your eyeballs explode (ok maybe not that last part).

Truth is its hard to recommend Spec Ops without spoiling anything. So go out and look for yourself. If it doesn't capture your interest, then that's fine. I can't persuade everyone to buy. But if you decide to buy it, then by all means: go ahead. You're in for a wild ride my friend.

So pack away those old so-called 'War Simulators' because even though ArmA may be the most realistic, in terms of emotion, this game takes the cake.

Welcome to Spec Ops: The Line. Welcome to emotion hell. Welcome to PTSD simulator.

Welcome to Dubai.

reviewText: The exploration of PTSD in this re-imagining of Heart of Darkness is where it really shines. The gradual loss of sanity - in Walker, in Dubai, and even in the game interface - is palpable and powerful. reviewText:
This game is truly one you will never forget.

There are a couple of aspects about this game, some are generic and familiar (like the gameplay, if you think Gears of War you've pretty much got the picture drawn for you), while others are not generic, like the storyline.

We begin with the gameplay, which is actually very simple. A third-person, over-the-shoulder view. In the game you take cover, you shoot blindly or get up from your cover to shoot , and then move to a different cover. If one just goes all-out, you will be dead pretty quick, this game takes a little thinking and a wee bit of patience. Also, since the game is set in a post-cataclysmic Dubai, there is sand everywhere, including on top of buildings that have huge windows. Shoot these windows and watch the tons an tons of sand crush your enemies (even though you don't get the chance to do it that many times).

The storyline is the driving force of this game, without it, it's not pleasant to get through some levels (in my opinion). This is one of the few games that will make you feel as if your brain was deep-fried, frozen, then smashed into little shards with a hammer. Seriously, this game is not for those who get shocked easily. It is gruesome, disturbing, and appalling. But at the same time, it has a feeling of serenity, ever so faint.

It is an amazing game. Definitely worth the money, go buy it.

reviewText:
I never wanted to hurt anybody...

Spec ops the line is something you can seperate from other shooters, not because of the gunplay, but rather the usage of the storyline.
Now some choices may render obselete, which I find quite disappointing, considering they are there but do not have any impact whatsoever on the story finale. But where this game truly shines is its storyline, and Walkers journey throughout, where you expect a standard stopping-terrorists-saving-the-world scenario, they present you with a debacle of what you are doing is actually right.

The gameplay is standard for TPS games and does not really bring too much new to the scenery and honestly gets quite boring after a while, or at least repetetive, but the game is quite short so you will not be suffering for long if you despise it...

In conclusion, buy this game if you want a game with a great plot which seems to both make a great storyline and subtely mock other games in similar genres where everything is seen from a black-white perspective. If you are here for the gameplay exclusively, I would not recommend this.

reviewText:
Someone recommended me this game as I wanted to play a story rich game. And boy, was the story rich.

+ AWESOME SOUNDTRACK!
+ Good plot twist
+ Great and funny sidekicks
+ Awesome dialogues
+ Great graphics
+ Great voice acting
+ Good enough gameplay (though, I don't play enough shooters to think otherwise)
+ Get to use different weapons
+ Multiple endings

- You don't *really* get to choose.
- You can't save everyone. *sad*
- Made me depressed after the ending. *sad*
- There's no good ending. *sad*
- You can't be a hero. *sad*
- Short game, I wish it was longer.

PS (big spoiler): I got so upset at Lugo's death that I just started shooting at the locals. I'm a monster. *sad*.

Would buy at full price.

My Rating: 10/10

reviewText:
This game is a fantastic story inside of a god awful game. If you've read a review of this game, it probably praises the story more than anything else, and rightfully so. Nolan North is his usual fantastic self, and the voice work of Bruce Boxleitner is always top notch. This game explores the psychology of the average military shooter protagonist and flips it on its ear and shows us how truly psychotic these people actually would be. It starts off fairly generic, but becomes something unique and special.

Unfortunately, poorly designed gameplay mars the experience. There are bugs that will cause progression events to not trigger. The cover system sometimes doesn't work. Moving out of cover is dangerous because it puts you in to a sprint. Vaulting over cover requires pressing the same button that you use to melee, so you'll occassionally punch at the air above a chest high wall instead of going over it. On and on, I would run in to situations where the basic mechanics wouldn't work. I could forgive all of that if the actual shooting weren't so monotonous and boring.  The most intense fire fights become are pace killing once you realize that your best strategy is to move at a snails pace. Pop out, shoot, wait for health to regen. It's basically modern whackamole. This is a problem that these cover shooters have had for a while now, but the best games find a way to circumvent that inherent flaw. Not in this game.

In some cases it takes one second to almost die, and nearly 15 seconds to get all of your health back. So slow progression and unspired game play put together means that the actual game is boring. I honestly just wanted it to end.

If you do buy this, it is the story that will get you to finish it. However, I don't believe story is enough to save a game. Novels exist. I'm judging this purely as a game, and as a game I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
Walking blind into the thought piercing sand granules of Spec Ops The Line, not knowing or understanding what lies in wait, is akin to drawing near the railing on the roof of the Burj Khalifa and looking out into a haze expecting to clearly see the now obscured majestic definitions of the Dubai landscape below.   Perhaps intentional design, perhaps not and most likely subject to the perceptive cognisance of those lost in the immersive sea of Dubai's blood stained sand.

For when the credits roll and you ponder the rich story inspired* by Joseph Conrad's novella Heart of Darkness and influenced by Francis Ford Coppola's iconic Apocalypse Now, Spec Ops The Line is elevated past common war time yarns denoted by the computer game genre.

Where the repetitive Gears of War, run, cover and shoot mechanics overrun, thankfully the avant-garde psychical linear narrative blisters continuously, frequently exposing enough underlying ethical wounds to metamorphosize the title from combat to psychological horror.

Endowed with multiple endings, I researched for a definitive authoritative source that would define which ending is lore and which ending was designed to be deceptively tangential, thus further encapsulating this deep and vividly imaginative work.

Special mention for the soundtrack and the inclusion of Deep Purple and Jimi Hendrix.  Highly recommended.

+ Reshade + SweetFX for post processing effects.
+ Flawless Widescreen for FOV control.

reviewText:
This is a cover based regenerating health over-the-shoulder shooter that has you roaming the desert city of Dubai with 2 other soldiers under your command. The game has a lot going for it, gorgeous vistas, licensed music, a villain that blurs the line of who is the villain, story choices, but the real thing Spec Ops: The Line can hang its hat on is the engrossing story. I'm not a story person, but this would make a great movie watching the story unfold. There are brief cut scenes here and there, but nothing that gets in the way of the action. You are even given choices, so there is some interactivity to the story, but the choices don't have any real impact on the story.

The story is simple, subtle and deep all at the same time, you are sent in to find what happened to a group of soldiers in the 33rd and you quickly discover in the first 10 minutes they've gone rogue. You're not just fighting inhabitants of Dubai, but US soldiers and other factions that I can't name since spoilers. Dubai itself is in a post-apocalyptic state, because it has been hit by a major sandstorm destroying the city except for pockets of civilians and soldiers. You'll come across both. There are elements where you can use the sand to defeat your enemies, such as destroying glass will send sand oceans burying enemies. There are blinding sandstorms. The game makes good use of the environment and city. You'll be in the sand oceans full of wrecked yachts, on top of towering skyscrapers, inside falling buildings and junkyards, this game has a great variety of areas. Each area is gorgeous, no matter how depressing and shambled they are. When you execute enemies at close range, you'll see the detail on their faces. A lot of detail was put into this game beyond the gorgeous scenery.

Since this is a cover based over-the-shoulder shooter, it feels extremely familiar to others especially Uncharted, especially when the main character is voiced by Nolan North who played Nathan Drake in the Uncharted series. Left stick to run, right stick to aim, left trigger to aim, right trigger to fire, left button to throw something, left and right on the D-pad to cycle through your grenades, Y to change weapons (between two, but you can pick up others), X to reload, B to melee, execute downed enemies and leap over cover. Up on the D-pad will let you alt fire weapons, but its mostly forgotten about. The only unique touch to this game is the right button will command your followers. Tap the right button and Lugo will send out a flash bang that on the PC seems virtually useless. I rarely see it even effect people. Holding the right button and aiming at an enemy will have your sniper take out a long range foe, but really when I'm aiming with the right button I can literally just shoot someone myself if I'm aimed at him. On top of that, it seems like commanding your sniper doesn't work on PC when it does on PS3. The final button is of course the all purpose A button that tap it to run, hold it to run and slide to cover, standing next to cover will make you stick to cover, but really this needs a lot of work. I find my character running in and out of cover or sticking to the cover behind me instead of in front of me. It is quite frustrating and results in most of the deaths I had while playing.

The enemy AI seems smart enough and they will flank you, just like you can flank them with your squad. The enemies are similar for the most part, but with AI so good, that means every enemy can kill you. They boil down to standard soldiers, snipers, shotgunners that come to you, bladers that will run at you to knife you and heavy soldiers that walk slowly at you and take a lot of bullets to kill. Its a lot like playing the Uncharted series. You and your allies get put into big open areas with a lot of cover and you need to stay there until everyone dies. Your allies feel competent enough and will take out enemies on their own and call out things to warn you.  They will need to be resuscitated if they take too much damage, but that rarely happens and you can command the other one to bring the fallen back to life. Your teammates serve as guides without seeming too overbearing. The voice acting in the game is great and its probably an unseen high point in a game full of amazing highs.

For the most part this feels like a fun game with an incredible story, despite frustrating cover and run buttons being the same. I can't say the game is worth $30 and I'm really surprised that its not $20 yet. Get it on sale. Its worth it for the single player.

reviewText:
Intense would be a good way to describe this story. Shocking would be another.

Although this is an average shooter, fun enough as it is, with a decent cover system, nice weapons, and good level design, including a few jaw dropping sequences, what really sets this game apart is its story. As far as shooters go, I cant think of too many that can rival this one in that regard, and it really elevates this game above most of its peers.

It didnt take too long to finish (around 6 hours), and you don't have to replay the entire game to see all four endings, which is nice.

this is a game you will definitely keep thinking about long after you finish it, revisiting a lot of the really, really disturbing scenes and decisions that led up to the variations on the ending, all of which have more to do with your characters ability to cope with what he did than the actual gameplay choices you will make throughout.

This game is NOT for the overly sensitive. Some of the scenes might legitimately bring some tears out of you, and even if they don't, you wont feel great about them regardless.

It's pretty rare that a game can mix action with such an evocative and emotional story.

I give this game 9 out of 10, and I feel it is a must own, must play for anybody (but you should also be of age before giving it a go...definitely mature" topic and content due to the intensity and violence."

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line may seem like a typical military shooter at first, but it isn’t... not at all.

Its strongest point, the story, makes up for every flaw that this game has. I won’t give you any other detail about it, with the exception that it is one of the most intense stories I’ve heard from a game and you just have to trust me and play through it. I don’t believe that there is any other game with such an unique plot and, in terms of how good the narrative is, it can be easily placed at the same level with other good story-driven games like The Last of Us and Alan Wake, which I highly recommend if you are interested in intriguing stories. Also, it is filled with lots of action, which makes it a good choice, even if you want to play something just killing some people, but, in my opinion, if you choose to play this game without paying attention to the story, you are simply wasting your time, as probably there are other mindless shooters out there which excel at this category.

The cover system is pretty well done, even though your character will sometimes get into the wrong cover, which can instantly lead to your death if you are already being shot, especially on harder difficulties.  The AI of the squad mates sometimes made my enemies' lives easier, by going out of cover in critical situations and dying, which, combined with a hard difficulty, made it impossible for me to get my squad mate revived. Neither of the above is game breaking and, fortunately, these things rarely happen, so I can say that the gameplay itself is well polished. One thing I want to point out is that the enemy AI is pretty challenging, forcing you to take tactical approaches instead of getting out of cover and shooting everyone. Also, I feel that the sand mechanics were not used at their maximum potential and the developer could do much more with the idea.

The sound is another aspect of the game where it can be seen that the developer put a lot of effort.  The voice actors did a tremendous job, succeeding in making players easily cope with the characters. Fun fact: every single line of the script was recorded in just one day. You’ll probably think that the actors didn’t manage to do this without getting tired. Firstly, that’s the point: the developers wanted the voice acting to closely follow the game, which, with the help of the actors, they did. Secondly: you are talking about professionals. Should I mention that the main character is voiced by Nolan North, the one who was featured in games like the Uncharted series and The Last of Us? Also, the OST fits the game perfectly, giving you an adrenaline shot every time you find yourself in front of many enemies. (I have to admit that I’m into rock/metal music, but in my opinion, the music you’ll find in the game is best suited for this genre.)

The graphics are pretty amazing! Everything takes place in a post-sandstorm Dubai, which was very well represented by the developers. You get the opportunity to see a beautiful sight of the ruins of Dubai from one of its tallest buildings. Also, the great lightning effects and the attention to details makes up for some minor texture loading issues. There isn’t really anything else to complain about the graphics! I didn't experience any FPS drops, graphical artifacts or any other technical problems throughout the whole campaign.

I was looking for a game with a good story and I gave this one a chance when I caught it on sale. I have to admit that I don’t regret a single penny I spent on this game and even if I had to pay the full price, I would not complain, because it is one of the few games that sent chills down my spine. So, if you are wondering whether to buy this game or not and it happens to be on sale, do yourself a favor… buy this game. I can assure you that you won’t regret it at all.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rnHItiRiBbs

It would be easy to look at Spec Ops, groan and promptly write it off as another addition to the bloated cabal of modern military shooters, but to do so would be a mistake. What, on the outside, looks like a game about three hardened delta force commandos shooting up brown people in another sandy Middle Eastern hell hole defies outward appearances and proves to be a bit more clever and surprising. Given the fact that the earlier entries in the Spec Ops franchise preoccupied themselves with cut and dry tactical military action you would be forgiven for making such an assertion.

The game opens with a bombastic set piece that seems to have been ripped out of Call Of Duty. It looks like a deleted scene from True Lies, with your character manning a mini gun, shredding lesser enemy helicopters between the sky scrappers of Dubai. You shoot through large glass walls at choppers on the opposite sides of buildings, one unfortunate bird smashes into a crane as things are constantly going boom. It's what we have come to expect from this kind of game. The sequence ends and you flash back to the beginning of the sequence of events that led to that point. No surprises so far. You play as Walker, a Delta Force operative (voiced by Nolan North of Uncharted fame) and are accompanied by Adams and Lugo, your trusty wing men, on a mission to rescue the people of Dubai and locate Colonel John Konrad. The narrative is loosely based on Joesph Conrad's Heart of Darkness and it takes a lot of cues from Frances Ford Coppola's Apocalypse Now, which is also based on Conrad's novella.

The not-so-unusual set up is followed up with some not-so-unusual third person cover based shooting as the game introduces you to Dubai and your squad mates. The shooting mechanics work well enough. You take cover, blind fire, pop out of cover to take precise shots, order squad mates to throw flash bangs and attack. Left to their own devices, Lugo and Adams prove themselves to be competent. They will kill enemies and they generally stay out of your way and make an effort to preserve themselves. It's very refreshing to have AI squad mates that do more than shout, “Reloading!” and “Stay frosty!” every five seconds. In short order, the first wrinkle to otherwise not-so-unusual formula is introduced—environment based attacks. You will find the sandstorm has left mounds of sand heaped behind fragile barriers that can be destroyed in an effort to bury your foes. These environmental advantages are sprinkled throughout the campaign and really brings the setting to life. Engulfing enemies in sand isn't enough to warrant playing any game, but from here Spec Ops only gets more interesting. The second major deviation this game makes is placing you in the middle of moral dilemmas. These sections don't have any lasting effects on the game's narrative but act as a means of reinforcing the game's themes. These are not about playing a “good” soldier or a “bad” soldier but rather having to make a choice you may not want to make. Making these choices strips any pretense of being a bad ♥♥♥ hero, they remind you that you can't save the the day all of the time and sometimes you might not be able to save anything at all...

One of the most uninspiring and unappealing aspects of modern military shooters is the art direction. I can only wade through so many brown mud huts, gray warehouses made out of tin and steel, and dilapidated villages before I want to gouge my eyes out. In spite of all of the sand, Spec Ops offsets the sandy, sun baked sections with vibrant, colorful interiors. You wade through seas of abandoned cars on highways, blast your way through luxury hotels, crawl out of the apocalyptic center of the city, and bounce across glass filled rooftops. Dubai, as depicted in Spec Ops, is a surreal place. The art style lends itself to the narrative—more specifically the character's mental states. What you see may or may not be real. The characters themselves are detailed and they become more haggard and war torn as the game progresses, animations are altered a bit to reflect the change in characters. There are some visual metaphors sprinkled about if you pay attention (and you should) to the detailed and engaging setting. It's not the technical marvel that the more recent Battlefield games are but the art direction makes this infinitely more interesting to behold.

Also the soundtrack deserves special attention. Dubai has also been rigged with speakers and a DJ, known as The Radioman, is broadcasting throughout the city. He sounds like an aging hippie and the music he plays kind of reflects this. Did you ever think you would have a shoot out in a modern military game while Deep Purple's Hush plays in the background? What about Martha and the Vandellas Nowhere to Run? It's fantastic. The juxtaposition of these tunes with the violence of the gun play creates and truly unsettling tone. It seems really obvious that Apocalypse Now was a huge influence on this aspect of the game. There are also some noteworthy ambient, largely guitar-based compositions that sew together the sections of the game that don't have licensed tunes playing in a cohesive manner. The voice acting is also commendable and the writing is very self aware of genre tropes and plays off of them. The whole game centers around critiquing and in some ways defying what you have come to expect from other games in this genre. You won't play anything like it.

What sets Spec Ops back, and is likely to turn off most gamers, is its short length. It is completable in a single sitting and most players will clock in about five to eight hours depending on skill level. The moral dilemmas are not designed to alter the game but rather to set the tone for your play through and experiencing their different outcomes really doesn't extend the game play experience in any meaningful way. Spec Ops was clearly designed as a single player experience and the multiplayer is best ignored altogether. Playing the game in co-op will only further shorten the experience. It's a shame that completing the main single player experience doesn't unlock bite sized missions or episodes from your squad's past. Given that PTSD and war induced stress are huge themes it would have been an appropriate way to add to the game's content without artificially extending the main campaign.

Spec Ops is one of the most mature and interesting games of the year. It is an experience. One unlike any other in terms of the way the game mechanics reinforce the themes and concepts put forth by the narrative. It should be on your radar but don't expect to put dozens of hours into it. In terms of gameplay it's competent rather than exceptional, but where it excels is where other games in its genre need to take a hard look at what they are doing. Games like Spec Ops and Bioshock will be important examples in video game history for integrating gameplay mechanics with narrative themes. This alone makes it worth playing and possibly revisiting in a few years time.

reviewText:
This is the only game ive played that is realistic modern war shooter.
(Story spoilers so a WARNING if u dont want any spoilers dont read it, its ur choice)
This not like all call of duty or battlefield games where u have a lots of fun, no this is a mature story driven game witch shows you the real horrors of war, it shows that the war is not that fun in real life as it is in games.
Of course it feels like gears of war 3 wich is not that realistic and u can only get killed by getting 10or 5 bullets in you (but you have to be dumb ♥♥♥♥ to think that would be the same in real life) but the story is really like a real war.
in the begging it started off as the same old borring third person shooter with just guns blazing and other stuff, but deeper and deeper i started to think myself what option should i take and how will this affect me, am i going crazy.
The 3 soldiers became angry at each other become insane from all this fighting and blood and thats how its suppose to be in real life, after a long road of killing and innocent deaths u start to get physical illusions of dead people and other people suffering because of ur choices but u cant save everyone, ur not a superhero with super powers that kills every guy with a blink of an eye, u are a regular soldier who wanted to save everyone but started to think how would you survive yourself, you see all these dead suffering civilians who only wanted a good life but they couldnt do anything and so do you and the end off al this madness of suffering and fighting u become insane and shocked form everything that youve experienced.
Do you feel like a hero yet?
We are humans beings not a robots, even if they are soldiers and they were trained for this theyr mind and hearth still feels the same and after so many horror roads its impossible to not become insane (unless ur a serial killer psyhopact) witch this game shows.
This game truly reminded me how the real war is and every guy should always rethink or think longer about theyr options if they want to join the military and face the devil of war.
For me this game is not all about the gameplay and grapchis and multiplayer (even if this review 3years late) its about the story and how well its done.
Mankind must put an end to war before war puts an end to mankind.
John F. Kennedy
10/10

reviewText:
At first glance it looks like a generic shooter. It starts like a generic shooter.
Then it transforms to something... Different. Unique. It kicks you in the balls and doesn't let you get up.
The game reminds me Kane & Lynch: Dead Man. Both games are typical third person shooters, with
self regenerating health, cover systems and dynamic camera. But their story makes them unique.
What is this game about? Basicly it's a adaptation of Joseph Conrad's 'Heart of Darkness'.
It starts as a story about 3 commando soldiers on a rescue mission in Dubai.
Because of misunderstanding and coincidence it turns to something much worse.
In my opinion it's a game about war crime, about sacrificing morality or humanity for accomplishing your goals.
It shows how easy war can change into total massacre because of small factors.
You should play SO:TL and interpret it for yourself.
Graphically the game is really OK, mostly because of original location and beautiful map design.
What's really important - the game is very detailed. As our characters get deeper and deeper into Dubai conflict
they are changing both physically and mentally. They're getting wounds, their equipment is getting damaged, they speak and act differently. They are even executing the enemies with more aggression and hate. Even the tips showing during the loading screens are becoming cynical. The game itself is criticising your actions, it oftens breaks the 4th wall.
The shooting mechanics are good, same as the camera. I didn't have any problems with the technical aspects of the game. What makes the game even better is the soundtrack. It suits every single scene in the game, and makes me want to listen it even after the game. If you've watched 'Apocalypse Now' - you'll feel familliar.

Try it. You will get suprised, how this seemingly generic shooter is going to shock you. It's brilliant. It will definetely put your morality on a test.

reviewText:
Spec-Ops: The Line is a squad-based third-person shooter, but really this is just a cover-up. The game is actually an experimental arthouse game that tries to challenge conventions of the modern game industry, narrative, and ask the player what they really want from games.

Spec Ops: The Line is the 11th game in the Spec-Ops series, but you'd be forgiven for not knowing that, as the series wasn't particularly great and hadn't had a new entry in its series in over 10 years before this game came along. However, Spec-Ops: The Line is more of a stand-alone game, and you need no knowledge of the previous Spec-Ops games to enjoy it.

You play as Captain Martin Walker, who comes into the town of Dubai under fictional settings that its been ravaged and left for dead by rampant sand storms and riots in the town. A US team, known as the 33rd, was sent there to help keep things under control. The last the city and the 33rd team were recorded doing was trying to form a caravan to help save the survivors of the city. However, all contact was lost, and the city was declared a no-mans land, with access to the city barred off by the UAE government.

Our main character, Walker, comes in with a small team, with the only other members being Lieutenant Alphonse Adams and Staff Sergeant John Lugo. Walker has a personal stake in all of this... The leader of the 33rd, Colonel John Konrad, is a personal hero of his, someone who saved his life on the battlefield. This man changed Walker's life, and is the sort of man Walker inspires to be. So when a communication message from Lugo gets out, he takes on the mission very personally, and is determined to do whatever it takes to save him.

Spec-Ops: The Line is a very beautiful game. Countless scenes and imagery are backed by fantastic artistic design, and one sometimes can't help but to just sit-back and appreciate the aesthetics of it all. The characters are well animated, the effects of things like sand and water are impressive, there are some gorgeous overlooks of the city at various points in the game, and visually stimulating environments that range from theaters to malls to aquariums to the natural desert itself.

The soundtrack is also very stimulating. The game features a variety of licensed music, ranging from Hush by Deep Purple to Star Spangled Banner by Jimi Hendrix. The original soundtrack is also rather interesting, featuring rather ethereal sounds, industrial, and pseudo-rock to home in the tones of each scene. The voicing is handled fantastically, and fits each character rather perfectly.

But there is something looming over Spec-Ops: The Line almost the entire time that may turn off a lot of people. The game isn't really all that fun to play. It's serviceable and not badly made, but something about it makes the gameplay never really a fun experience. And as odd as it may sound, I think this is what the developers were going for. There comes a tedium to the combat, a sort of unfeeling to it all. It can be a struggle at times, and there are some moments that are really cool from a visual stand-point and conceptually so, but it still somehow remains unfun.

Also as someone who played the whole game on hard difficulty, I recommend you do not. I usually play games on the hardest difficulty available as I find it fun to be challenged, but in the case of Spec-Ops I'd argue it actually actively worked to try and make me enjoy the game less. I wasn't having fun with the harder challenges, it didn't feel satisfying to overcome difficult segments, and it caused me to repeat several segments over-and-over again, and not in a way that it was enjoyable.

But I'd still say Spec-Ops is worth experiencing. While the game poses as a third-person shooter, and there is definitely third-person shooter gameplay here, that isn't at the same time really what the game is or is about. Talking about Spec-Ops is difficult, as I believe it is best to go into it without knowing almost anything at all. But at the same time, there is a tedium, a drudgery to pull through in the game.And that arguably is part of the game, and is part of the point of the game and its themes. Spec-Ops has a lot of thought put into it, and is a case where the narrative, atmosphere, and overall experience is much stronger than the gameplay.

Here's an odd analogy; This game is essentially to Shooters what Silent Hill is to Survival-Horror or Braid is to platformers. The games are well-made, but gameplay isn't the focus. Other elements take the lead, and the games have rather strong emphasis on its other elements. The gameplay without these other elements is arguably rather lackluster, or kind of tedious. But with the other elements, the games rise from this to become a rather interesting experience in game form. Some may never see the enjoyment of a game that isn't fun to play from a gameplay perspective, but if you can, there is a lot to love in Spec-Ops: The Line.

It's depressing, sometimes hard to swallow, and you may not honestly understand everything the first time you play it. However, it is likely to stick with you, and really delves into a sort of symbolic social message on shooters and war, and how the general public see's it. It's not very fun, but Spec-Ops is still an experience worth undertaking.

reviewText:
To save a fellow American soldier or a civilian. To follow orders or go against them. By the end of it all, are you done serving your country?

Brief game summary:
You play as Captain Martin Walker who is accompanied by a Delta Force team sent to Dubai to rescue civilian survivors. But as you progress through the game, you are faced with betrayal, horror, hallucinations, and a heck load of sand which forces you to make moral decisions. Ultimately, whichever decision you make, you'll have to live with it. As you spiral down the horrors of war, your fellow squad mates will react differently to your chosen paths.

Review:
This game takes on a perspective where you place yourself in the shoes of a soldier tasked on a rescue mission. Throughout the game, you'll be faced with moral dilemmas, just like the trolly effect, and you will have to choose your own path.
I really like the story line (hands down, the best story line I have ever seen) and the combat in it was entertaining enough. You have to use your environment, which is sand, to your advantage. Your 2 squad mates, unlike other game bots, are very effective. You are literally in control of the outcome of the game. #1 PTSD simulator.
-Storyline: 11/10 (Hit me right in the feels)
-Gameplay: 8.5/10
-Combat: 8.5/10
-Graphics: 9/10
-Sand: infinity
EDIT: Finally completed the game and will very likely be playing it again. Storyline again, is beyond phenominal which also made an impact on me while playing--had to take breaks in between because it got really intense after a few unfortunate  events where it made me feel like sh*t. won't spoil it for the unlucky people who haven't played yet. Unlike other war games, this game takes you on a different perspective, you experience the horrors of war, the aftermath of war, the PTSD experience, and most importantly, it forces you to make unspeakable decisions under very stressful circumstances, in which you would have to deal with the consequences of your actions.

I can definitely say that if you were Anakin Skywalker, you will probably sit this game out. But you're not Anakin! Sand doesn't scare you! So what are you waiting for? There's a demo for you to try, however it'll probably end before you even get to the good parts. Or even better, you can just get the game during a sale and experience it yourself.

In the end, do you choose to save a fellow brother in war? Or do you finish what you were sent to do?

reviewText:
READ FIRST: I finished this game originally on a console before but bought It again on Steam because I'm primarily a PC gamer. I finished this game twice to make sure I got the facts and the story straight.

INTRODUCTION:
Do you feel like a hero yet?, this is tag line that will haunt you all throughout the story of Spec Ops the Line.

At first glance this game looks like your average American Action War Hero game much like most modern day military shooters but it's not, its something else.

PROS:
+ Great story and unexpected plot: -Most games glorifies war and conflict but this game oddly focuses (in a good way) on the horrors of it. It takes unexpected twist that makes you question all the decision's you've made through the game. Gameplay wise (see Cons) you can call it generic, the thing that carries this game however, is the story.

+ Graphically pleasing: -Given that most games right now has stunning visuals, this is unique in it's own right, adding small details such as sweat, grime and atmosphere makes into a nice experience.

+ Sound : -Very nice voice acting that draws you into the story.

+ Healthy Game Time: -Not too long, not too short, it doesn’t overstay it's welcome but long enough to make the price tag reasonable.

CONS:
- Gameplay: -Aside from the added sand" feature
date: it's a generic 3rd person cover based shooting game much like Gears of War.\n\n- AI (both allies and enemy): -Some parts of the game
recommended: your allies act like real Special Forces
hoursPlayed: but in some parts they act like a clueless kid playing a multiplayer match. The game artificially increases the challenge by enemy numbers and bullet damage
voteText:
but does nothing to improve the enemy AI's survivability. Would have been nice if they properly used cover and flanking moves (like FEAR 1).

Conclusion:
GREAT GAME for someone looking for a good story and plot

reviewText:
Dust and bodies lie
Question rattles in my mind
How evil am I?
Outstanding game.

Highly recommend this cover shooter. As a shooter in itself, it is competent. You will enjoy the gun play, the hit boxes, the graphical impact. On higher difficulty, the game is challenging but not stupid and incompetent, like Call of Duty series is, at this point.

But the meat of the game, the attraction, is not in the shooter itself but in the story it weaves. That story could have been told in any medium and any genre of game and it would still be phenomenal. Don't read about it if you still haven't, just get the game and follow through and enjoy.

Once done, try not to overthink it, a lot of critics are all over it already, just feel for yourself the impact it makes. You'll be able to talk about that game with anyone who played it for quite a while.

reviewText:
Games don't affect me.

I mean, sometimes you're playing a game, you blow someone's head into a pile of gore, and you sit back and wonder what the hell you're doing. Then you shrug it off and do it a few hundred more times. You beat the game, you do something else, the shock forgotten.
I've been there.

So I wasn't expecting much from Spec Ops: The Line, a game I'd heard had a deep and moving story and would mess you up. I thought maybe there'd be a lame twist, a heavy-handed moral, and then a shock ending that would leave me nonplussed. Honestly, for the first half of the game, I thought I was right. I felt like everything was progressing naturally, that I would wind up disappointed. I even got sick of the game about halfway through and left for a while.

I'm glad I finished it, though. Here's why.

Spec Ops drops you into the sandy combat boots of Captain Walker, a man with a gun and a couple of companions. Seems about par for gaming. Two squadmates, one a heavy gunner with explosives and one a long-range specialist. Average.
It prods you through a few levels, and I have to say that's one thing Spec Ops never disappointed me in: these levels are great. They're full of color and design variety, and I actually stopped and looked around admiring the view whenever the combat would let up.
Which lets me segue into a quick point before I get back to the main one: Spec Ops: The Line is very by-the-numbers, as far as the actual combat mechanics go. Two guns, some grenades, the lightest of squad-command mechanics, a cover system, and waves and waves of enemies to shoot. It never progresses, save for dropping you into a couple on-rails segments, and it's the only real flaw I have with the game.

That said, about halfway or so through, I was just about done. I'd shot some people in the head, shot some more people in the head, shot some people I wasn't sure I should be shooting in the head, walked through beautiful landscapes and disgusting squalor and I'd seen some serious ♥♥♥♥.
I was about done.
The game was dragging, and then it led me to a slightly-different segment. I won't go on about it, but I thought it was pretty boring and I guessed what was about to happen. I was right, but I wasn't prepared. It finally shocked me, and my character's expression mirrored my own. I tuned out everything else. I was thoroughly engrossed and a little bit repulsed. I took a break for a while, letting everything sink in, and I set off again on my trail of shooting people in the head.

The game funneled me through wave after wave of enemies, punctuated by comments from other characters and general story beats. It was fun, I had the right emotions, I was in the groove.
When I got to the final levels, major ♥♥♥♥ was going down. I was pumped. Bad things happened. I got to the end.
The game threw me for a loop, and I was forced to reflect on a new reality.
I faced the last of a few major moral choices.

I made my choice.
The credits rolled. A song played. I sat back in my chair, stunned.
Had all that really just happened? Had a video game just done all that?
Not all of it made sense. Not all of it had to. That was the point.

Spec Ops: The Line had caused me to think, it had caused me to feel, it had caused me to reflect on my actions in a video game. Had that happened before? Surely. Of course it had. But Spec Ops did it in a unique way, and I want to congratulate it.
The writing throughout was top-notch, set the mood, and progressed the story. The characters were fleshed out, deep, and believable.
I also give a nod to the soundtrack, with various tracks all ready to pump you up, get you in the mood, and keep you heading forward.

Do I recommend Spec Ops: The Line? Yes. It's full of gore, guns, explosions, and buff men. It has you shooting people in the desert, it's got on-rails sequences.

Even with all that, it's still unique. It's still full of heart, or soul, or charisma.
It's not without flaws, of course. It is, however, worth playing.

9/10
