reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line

This isn't the run of the mill shoot em' up. At first glance this game looks like the average shooter with no meaning what so ever but this is not the case. Spec Ops: The Line is a deep emotional ride through the mind of one man in dire situations. This games story kept me enthralled and entertained at all times. The story takes a few chapters to piece itself together but after a few painless chapters it comes together.

Visuals - This game isnt the newest game on the block but there is no lack of beautiful vistas and cut scenes. The characters transition from the begining to end is all envolping in facial features and body language. Nothing short of awe is captured from start to finish in the vast vibrant yet desolate Dubai. I ran the game on ultra with absolutley no hicups.

Gameplay - The line, to me, leaves something to be desired in this department. While the shooting and such serves its purpose it feels somewhat hollow. Now don't get me wrong when it comes down to it there are some scenes where it is down right awesome but i think that comes more from the visuals and story and not so much the game mechanics itself. I found myself missing environmentals and just running through waves of hollowed baddies" to progress the amazing story. If i had to compare the gameplay itself id say its not all to disimilar to Army Of Two (1).

Overall this game is overlooked all too often and should be taken seriously for the heavy amazing story that ensues. I give this game a  4.5/5
"

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line isn't a perfect game. The multiplayer is essentially a miss, the gunplay is somewhat formulaic, and the controls have a bit of a snag, but it is a great return to the franchise.Were it not for some technical issues and console-related shortcomings, Spec Ops: The Line would be one of the best games for 2012. But, things being as they are, it remains merely a diamond in the rough, destined for wicked crazy status within the following years. Spec Ops: The Line proves that, with a steady vision and soul, a genre so clichéd like military shooters, can not only surprise us pleasantly, but totally overwhelm us. A solid third-person shooter that delivers intense action and a compelling setting, but relies too much on established mechanics, rather than delivering something new. The story however really stands out - a grim and challenging reflection on violence is something you won't find in any typical shooter. Fortunately it's also missing that dull patriotism you've come to expect from today's military action games.It truly deserves applause for the courage to confront us so harshly with our own character, even if our choices sometimes seem forced or useless. Spec Ops: The Line tries new and interesting ground on storytelling, but falls short on the action department. Still, it's worth playing through for the atmosphere and few different endings alone.

reviewText: The game is a repetitive shooter, with linear and boring gameplay. But that doesn't take away from this game being amazing. What makes the game amazing is its story. It wouldn't even be ridiculous to say that the story is a master piece. The massive twist ending as well is a huge pay off for the games boring gameplay. The only way to recommend the game is for its story. At first the story feels boring and badly written. But once you get a couple of hours in the game, the story goes deeper, especially into the characters. Once you reach the last act of the game, the game seems very confusing, but all is explained with its amazing ending. It's a must have for its amazing story. But if you want to play a game for some gameplay, you might want to skip this one.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is one of the best third-person shooter I played, if you don't like the generic popular shooters out there, you will love this game.

The storyline is absolutely great, as well the characters. It begins in a very ordinary way but as you going further it starts to blow your mind.

The game design is awesome, beautiful sceneries, great buildings, lots of details and a nice use of the light and the ambient.

The sound and voice acting is perfect. The music will give the unique atmosphere of the game and the voices of Walker and his teammates Adam and Lugo reflects the stress of the situations as you progress.

The gameplay is pretty good, and the ability to command your team is very useful and nice to use. The cover system could be better, sometimes you will find it hard to do a quick escape especially when the enemies throw grenades in your way.

There is a plenty variety of weapons to use and sometimes you can use the ambient to take out the enemies which is always nice.

I wasn't expecting this game to be so good, it was a nice surprise and I totally recommend.

reviewText:
Many have dissected, analyzed, and downright devoured Spec Ops: The Line. Many theories have been concocted regarding the game's complex and incredibly disturbing narrative. But only one thing is certain: The Line is the most mature, intelligent, and introspective video game ever created. I would go as far as to call it the first post-modern video game ever made.

It is, thus far, the only video game in existence that manages to ask so many questions of the player in such unbelievably subtle and imperceptible ways. It may be the first video game that truly is about something. And not only is it the only video game that truly made me question my perception of reality, it's also the only video game that made me truly question the ending I chose. But did I actually choose at all?

Well, whatever Spec Ops: The Line is, it's well worth the price of admittance. The gameplay can be lackluster, at times (it's still very much playable and enjoyable, though), but the profound and compelling story more than makes up for any of its faults.

reviewText:
PROS:
- Story and overall presentation of the game.
- Voice acting.
- Cover system (it does not make you invincible, some realism is appreciated.)

CONS:
- Not ideal console port along with somewhat clunky controls with mouse and keyboard.
- Cover system (control wise, often unresponsive.)
- Inconsistent and horrible checkpoints later part of the game.
- FUBAR difficulty is frustrating not because of the way it is designed, but because of consolitis, random bugs, and allies' glitchy AI.
- Tacked-on multiplayer.

Final Remarks:
Despite having more cons written, story alone makes Spec Ops: The Line interesting and fun compared to other typical shooters. Gameplay is by no means horrible either, just generic. This game is definitely worth a playthrough.

. RECOMMENDED .

reviewText:
I was skeptical starting this game, I didn't expect much from it. What I got was an overall impressive gave with a fairly awesome storyline to boot. *No spoilers here*.

The combat is pretty intense and seems very fluid, the visuals are quite nice, and the soundtrack is great. I enjoyed nearly every moment of the game as I was playing, and though it was short, it was sweet. There are a few moments that seemed a bit rushed and choppy, but in the larger scale of things, they're minor issues. If you pay close attention while playing, there are subtle surprises throughout the entire game that simply made me want to sit back and appreciate the work that went into creating this game. Seeing as Spec Ops: The Line is a bit old and outdated now, you may actually be pleasantly surprised if you decided to purchase and check it out.

8.5/10  -- I'd definitely recommend and will continue to play for SnG's. :D

reviewText: This is a game that, the moment I completed it, I sat down to write a review. I was conflicted about the storyline and content, as it's a game that it's nearly possible to complete in good conscience. Spec Ops : The Line is a common 3rd person military shooter in a lot of ways, save one : Its narrative. Some will find this game to be overly preachy, but having completed the campaign I think I know what the developers were going for.\n\nMilitary games of the last few years have shown players a lot of things. New graphics, firearms, and storylines that encompass many historical geopolitical campaigns. Spec Ops intends to show players something they've never been forced to confront. Themselves. In many ways, it's incredibly difficult to put a rating on this game as it's mediocre gameplay is carried by the narrative and (more importantly) the narrative's intent. It's also difficult to avoid spoiling as this is a game you will only experience the first time once. (duh) But the first time will be a troubling journey. During this game you will do horrific things simply because the objectives say so. The developers prod at you by saying Just because the objectives dictate you should

reviewText:
I started playing this game with fairly high expectations and I must say I was not dissapointed. Even though the game is fairly linear - with little decision making in terms of the events unfolding - it still instills a sense of freedom as to how you choose to go about it.

The game is clearly trying to grapple with the moral choices during times of war and battle, survival and necessities and in many ways it succeeds quite well.

The setting and graphics are both very nice, while the locations are well thought out and quite detailed. The story (while nothing to jump out of your clothes for) drives you forward quite well, more than anything because it succeeds in instilling the feeling that you have to move on, that there is no choice but to move on...

There isnt extraordinary variety in the weapons and most dont feel much diferent between them, but the momentum of the game doesnt really allow you to think about it much. You mostly grab whatever weapon you have some ammo for.

I played it at the hard settings, which in some situations challenged me, but was overall an enjoyable experience (I believe normal dificulty might be a bit too easy).

Finally there are a few points in the game where your (moral) decisions affect [if only partially] how the game unfolds.

All in all it is a very nice story driven third person shooter, full of intense moments of combat. Not sure if there is a lot of replayability, unless you are after all the achievements, but I can see myself going back and playing it all over again.

reviewText: There's no glorification in war. A conflict of ethics and code of conduct. What's the importance between one's conscious and one's choice just to survive. Spec Ops: The Line define such philosophies. The game's narrative is one of the most memorable in video game history as modern first-person shooters are too mainstream and cliche. There are certain scenes in the game that might or will make you pause, reflect, or even quit the game just to remind yourself on what war is. However, Spec Ops: The Line is NOT an anti-war game. It just tell what war is like. Many people and gamers can compare this game to Apocalypse Now. Sure, that's comparable but the game can be interpret to many literatures and certain documentaries like Waltz of Bashir. The gameplay is decent and typical but I believe that the developers strongly focused a lot more on the story and its message rather than gameplay. Spec Ops: The Line is a memorable game, but its more of the one-time play" game mainly because of its heavy subject matter. Would I recommend this game to others? Yes
date: but it is up to you if you can handle the game's content. Best purchase this game on a steep discount."

reviewText:
Best way to put it into a TL;DR is by stating that this is like Rainbow Six type of gameplay mixed with a story that was the sole reason I played this game through and enjoyed it for it's uncensored gruesome nature.

War isn't rosy, nor is it cozy. It's crazy. And this game displays exactly that very, very well. You can behead people with sniper rifle, pop their heads off with a shotgun and turn them into bloody giblets with explosives.

But that's not the reason you play this game, no. The gameplay is very mediocre 6-7/10 as one would rate it. It's the story that keeps you wanting to play and find out what happens next more than anything. The characters are all well crafted into believable and realistic feeling experience as you play the game and advance within the story. The witty comments, yelling in combat and the terror is all well displayed and feels authentic. The soldiers you fight against yell orders loud and clear, just like you would in combat to relay the info. The game just feels right atmosphere wise.

If you're looking for a game that displays how f*cked up a war can be when there's no clear answers, and how it can affect your morale and choice making, and how ruthless some things you must decide on can make you feel like a complete d*ck for doing so. This game extremely well relays the weight of your choices, if you f*ck up, you will feel and see what it will cause.

A must buy to people who want to experience something different, and enjoy a really well made story.

reviewText:
Spec Ops is a third-person shooter with a run-and-cover mechanic.
While there is nothing new about this, I couldn't help but love this game, because this is so much more than your average TPS. It's also really, really well optimized.

The gameplay is nicely done, and you handle it pretty fast, being immersed into the universe and the action really quickly. But what really makes it a unique game, is its story.

In this game, you are not just an almighty stereotypical soldier, you are also just a man, with his weaknesses.
The story features some choices; and while you're playing, I'd like you to think twice about everything that happens. Is everything justified? Can anything be justified at all?

I won't spoil the story for you, but this game is much more than an action game. The scenario reminded me a bit of Shutter Island, and this is a good thing.

TL;DR - If you want a game with a lot of action, this is for you. But if you also want an interesting and deep enough storyline, by all means, PLAY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Spec Ops the Line at first seems quite carelessly executed FPS, a match for last Medal of Honor. But it is only an envelope which brings you emotionally affluent, strong message. Message about soldiers, war exhaustion and very basic one - about role of destruction in our system of values.

For a gameplay Yager offers you a railroad shooter with a bit of squad support. If you seek a glorious, challenging gunplay - look the other way, that's not about Spec Ops the Line. For some reason, the most of the action feels like you were shell-shocked from the start of the game. Shooting part not really engaging. Two big notes about AI:
1) your companions are not that bad, as you can expect, playing in games like Bureau: XCom Declassified or Battlefield3. They scoring kills, and it feels like in normal difficulty setting they can bend opposers almost without your support. If only they were not rushing forward before it's clear sometimes, I'd say they are a perfect team.
2) Quite opposite, behavior of your enemies usually is quite weak from the point of battle effectiveness. Even in the hardest difficulty setting where they shoot very precisely, and you dying alot being both outnumbered and outgunned... Still they a prey, and you are the hunter. You mow them, in dozens and hundreds.

Being quite a mundane FPS, Spec Ops the Line offers a rather spanning visual experience, though. Sights of Dubai, all those sand and weather features are gorgeous. Impression when you destroying something to let another portion of sand, symbolizing chaos, gets even more space over a once-a-great-city... Can't buy it with mastercard, obviously.
And music! Music part is fabulous. Maybe the best part of whole game.
Overall, an artwork, audio and visual feast, all of this combined - is what keeping your interest, where the rush for gunplay challenge leaving you.

But again, all of that - gunplay, visuals and one of a kind soundtrack - still just a cover for story with guaranteed catharsis in the end. For that Spec Ops the Line is taking such inordinanar reviews, like take a PTSD in 6 hours. 10/10!" That game Will Be Remembered.

reviewText: This is easily the best game I've ever played. You shouldn't go into this game for gameplay, it isn't anything new but it works perfectly fine with guns being relatively fun to use and enemies having good AI. At times you will find yourself dying a little too quick while some enemies feel like bullet sponges, but that's about right considering how little you wear while they are fully armoured. Now that we're done with the gameplay, the story is the real hook to buying this game. You will find yourself in a gripping story where you are put though many different situations to test your morality, most of which are no win scenarios and give no obvious good choices making you feel worse the more you play. The game is not black and white but rather the complete opposite with the game itself questioning you on whether or not you're really the hero as you fight your way through an entire army in order to find Konrad and end the nightmare he brought to Dubai when him and his soldiers were unable to evacuate this forgotten city. As the game progresses both you and the main protagonist will start to question what's really happening and your current mental state until you reach the ending which left me in such shock that I was left speechless and felt the need to replay the final mission numerous times to see all the endings. I personally felt dead inside after my first run. By the end of my experience I encountered so many twists and turns I didnt know what to expect next and after everything was over, I wanted to go back through the game and make different decisions from my first run to see how my teammates, myself and how everyone around me would react. Overall This was the ultimate video game narrative I've ever experienced and found it more than worth my time, this game took me about 8 hrs to complete due to some moments that took me a few too many tries, keeping it from being fun at all times, but for most people this shouldn't be much longer than 6 hrs though for most who play it on normal difficulty. I found that this game's length was excusable due to the fact that it was so immersive it felt at least twice as long. In the end this game has the best narrative in just about any game I have played so far including Telltale's Walking Dead games and it conveys a great message for the players, making this more than worth the cost.

reviewText:
It's hard to comment on this game without spoilers, but I'm trying my best to avoid them. Also note that I didn't try the multiplayer and I'm only going to comment on the single player campaign.

The game presents a well-crafted story that starts out as a mission to scout the city of Dubai as it suffers from the destruction caused by a gigantic sand storm. Civilians are trapped inside mile high dunes of sands after the military lost contact to a former evacuation squad and they send Martin Walker and two companions to investigate after they received a distress signal. The deeper the squad dives into the city, the more gruesome events get. You witness atrocities done by American soldiers who lost track of their goal as the horrible story of the fallen Dubai unfolds with your discoveries and the game doesn't hesitate to shock you when it wants you to see what terrifying things people can do in a struggle for survival. (if you don't have a thick skin, you might want to plan to take breaks)

If it weren't for the story, the game would be forgettable, and that is the biggest danger if you don't know it yet - those who don't know what to expect will easily lose interest. The shooting itself plays well enough to work - there's cover-based shooting with various real-life weapons, there are melee attacks and finishers, a small selection of squad commands, you can sometimes destroy terrain to take out clusters of foes with sand dunes. There's not much traditional gameplay evolution, except that the selection of weapons grows as some weapons only appear later in the game.

If you ONLY come for the shooting, you will most likely be disappointed or even confused through the first couple of chapters. If you want to give this game a fair chance, keep on playing until the end of Chapter 8 at least. If you get there and still only come for the shooting, but want to give the game a chance nevertheless, start over again and pay close attention to the dialog and try to think about the twists that happen in the beginning of the game, which are admittedly a little hard to follow the first time around.

A word about the length of the game: The play time is rather short (I beat the game in 6 hours on easiest difficulty.. there is a reason you don't want to turn up the difficulty in the late game, which I leave up to you to find out), but if you get into it, it probably won't let you go for a while, especially since many discussions on the internet send you away with spoiler warnings right away. Once you've played through the game and see the revelations, you will want to play it again to see things in a different light. If you find yourself in an obsession about the meaning of the game, a good reading after you finish it is Killing is Harmless" by Brendan Keogh. It's an affordable eBook that expands on a lot of details that you will easily miss on a casual playthrough. It links a good amount of articles on the internet
date: some of which include stances by the developers and lead writer. My Steam profile says I've played this game for only 16 hours
recommended: but I spent well over 30 hours reading up and watching on YouTube on what others thought about it.\n\nSpec Ops: The Line deserves more attention for the sheer courage the developer showed for demonstrating such a cruelly honest truth through a video game
hoursPlayed: and I recommend it wholeheartedly to everyone who likes unconventional games. It makes you think about the nature of good and evil and takes a harsh stance on recent topics like Western military interventionism and the cruelty of modern warfare. It made me think for long
voteText: and it pulled something off that is impossible to do with a book or a movie. I want more people to play this game

reviewText: I normally avoid first person shooters, which sadly is what I thought Spec Ops was when I picked it up in a bundle off of the glowing praise it’s story has reviewed. In reality, it is a cover based third person shooter. Sadly I’m sure most people glazed right over this game amongst the veritable sea of cover based third person shooter garbage flooding the market. In many respects, it’s hard to blame them. The controls are average, squad AI is passable at best, the shooting isn’t weak, but at the same time doesn’t carry as much weight as you would expect. The difference with Spec Ops is that the narrative is absolutely fascinating. I can’t in good conscious point out any specifics of the plot because to spoil it would ruin the impact it would leave on anyone who hasn’t yet played it. What I can say is that at the end of the final cutscene I sat back and really thought about all of my choices and actions I took throughout the campaign. I can only think of a handful of games which have ever made such an impact on me.\nSpec Ops: The Line breaks the mold and is a must buy if nothing more than to see what modern military shooters have to offer us besides 10 year old multiplayer daycare.

reviewText:
I believe that we all want to do the right thing, and in ideal circumstances with the right information, most of us would make the right decision.  However, how far would we go to do the right thing?  How much would we be willing to sacrifice to do what is right?

Captain Walker and his covert Delta Force team of three face this exact dilemma.  Tasked with conducting reconnaissance and radioing for extraction once completed, the mission was straight forward.  However, upon arrival they realize the situation has changed and the mission must as well in order to do the right thing.

Spec Ops: The Line is a shooter unlike others when it comes to storytelling and presenting a different perspective on war.  The game portrays warfare as an ugly affair.  This it accomplishes through its visual and auditory details.  Furthermore, throughout the game you will witness the affect this has on Walker and his team.  Around him the situation rapidly is deteriorating and Dubai becomes essentially hell on Earth.  Walker primarily is affected by this and his appearance and demeanor changes as a result.

In terms of actual gameplay, Spec Ops is your typical shooter.  Although ammo is manageable you should avoid spraying and praying.  Instead issue commands to your team to conserve ammo and prioritize targets.  The game is linear for the most part but you should be able to complete it within 5 hours.

I highly recommend Spec Ops: The Line to anyone looking for a unique perspective on modern warfare.  The gameplay is standard but the story was well worth it.

reviewText:
My score: 8/10Playthrough time: 8.5 hours (not rushed, watched all cutscenes and including retrying some sections a few times) Did not try the multiplayer mode.

Pros:+Excellent graphics (Unreal Engine).
+A good selection of weapons at your disposal.
+Nice gameplay, it's a cover based third person shooter that works really well
+The story offers a different take to the military shooter type of game, dealing with the consequences of killing hundreds of people in combat.

Cons:-The game might be too much for some, it's not all fun gunning down enemies, you have to deal with the consequences of your actions (in a more realistic manner than most games) as well.

Performance notes:Runs very smooth (60 fps) with an R9 280X @1080P and max settings. The Xbox 360 controller works well (even though you don't get the same precision as with the keyboard/mouse) and this game is a good one for playing on the TV from the couch, but it's just as good in front of a desktop computer controlled with the keyboard/mouse.


Main review:I was very positively surprised by this game.

The story starts out in Dubai, where most of the population have been evacuated due to heavy sandstorms. Your team is sent on a recon mission, and when discovering dead American soldiers, you continue further in to the city to investigate and look for survivors.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=482770326
The basic mechanics of the game are those found in most third person cover based shooters. Most of the time you're behind cover, returning fire at any enemies present. You also have grenades at your disposal, and you can issue simple commands to your squad members (target certain enemies, and in some situations order one of them to throw a flashbang).

The game mechanics themselves are good enough to make the game worth it, but as the game unfolds, you discover that there is more to it than most other modern action games. You are faced with some difficult choices, and have to live with the consequences of your actions in the game.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=482770499
The choices are few and far between, and don't really change the storyline, this is not a role playing game, it's more of a cinematic experience (the player is even credited as a special guest star" in the credits) where you take control over the action. The level design is quite linear

reviewText:
There is one basic and important thing to know about Spec Ops: The Line, and that's that it is at the same time a deeply satisfying and a deeply frustrating experience. Gameplay-wise, it's a fairly competent shooter marred by some very poor design decisions- checkpoints often come before cutscenes and are too far apart, which, combined with the surprisingly unforgiving difficulty (even on Normal you can find yourself gunned down in seconds) can be teeth-grindingly annoying. The range of guns you can pick up is unremarkable and there are nice secondary functions to a lot of them; you can carry three kinds of grenades; the cover mechanic is just flawed enough to be irritating but functions tolerably for the most part.

This is not a game about gameplay, however.

Were it to be judged purely on its design and mechanics, Spec Ops: The Line would be pretty forgettable, but it has an ace in the hole: a story so out of the blue in its direction and message that it's a miracle a major publisher put this game out at all. What you think you're getting- particularly if you only play the demo- is another gung-ho gun-wielding slice of Americans saving the day by killing all the brown people. What you actually get is a slow, spiralling descent into madness that wears its Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now inspirations proudly and uses them to forge a modern-day commentary on the type of video game you thought you were going to play. Captain Walker is no godly Call of Duty avatar who can murder a thousand people and walk away- he falls apart mentally, visually and audibly as the game continues, his professionalism is stripped away and raw ego left exposed. Tango down" becomes a more chilling
date: "Kill is ♥♥♥♥ing confirmed" as the game confronts you with issues of culpability and responsibility. It's incredibly unsettling.\n\nIf you don't come away from Spec Ops: The Line with questions and doubts about shooters
recommended: I have serious concerns about whether you're dead inside. Do your best to ignore the sometimes-frustrating controls and systems and try and appreciate just how important this game is in the history of
hoursPlayed: and commentary on

reviewText:
CAUTION, THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS!

To begin with, Spec Ops: The Line is not a typical action shooter. Spec Ops is a game that will indeed shock you in some parts of
the campaign. The developers wanted to show us the other side of the war where everything that you think will be all right, goes wrong and you are the one blamed for that. The campaign takes place in destroyed by storm Dubai where we have the mission to rescue any survivors. The game shows us then a very good perspective of how a such a powerful city as Dubai can be destroyed in days by thirst, hunger and civil war. The campaign then also shows how rest of the world just do not care about other conflicts. The game takes then focus on team-work where you and two other soldiers are going through the city trying to survive. I also felt like the campaign was slowly turning you into a murderer, where you began as a friendly soldier and ended as a killer.                                                                                                                                                              The game itself is very good. The shooting mechanics are great, there is also some stealth gameplay. The game offers a wide list of weapons which is also great. The missions are ´´OK´´designed, so do not expect much. The game offers some decent graphics, but it´s still the gameplay that shows most potential. Spec Ops: The Line offers also a great addition where you have to find several ´´intelligence files´´ so it´s also a great thing for achievement hunters. Unfortunately I haven´t played the multiplayer yet, so I can´t review it.
I personally liked the game. I bought it on Humble Bundle for several dollars and I can´t really say it was not worth it. The campaign after all was great experience in my opinion even though it shocked me in some chapters. The game itself was also good; the AI, weapons, Dubai perspective are definitely its best features.
Overall I would like to say that the game was great and I truly recommend it to anyone to try it out.
I give the game a solid 7/10

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a cover based third-person shooter in which the player controls one Captain Martin Walker. The player also has some control over Walker's crew, Adams and Lugo, in terms that they can be commanded to kill specific enemies on the battlefield. The entire game takes place in a post-war zone Dubai, where Walker and his crew have been sent out on a reconnaissance mission.

At the time of writing, it has been nearly three years since Spec Ops: The Line released initially. The game has definitely stood the test of time in every aspect imaginable; the story, graphics, gameplay and soundtrack have all aged beautifully. For the time, the graphics were above par for shooter titles, and they're still outstanding to look at today; especially the way Walker's face becomes more and more disfigured by the turmoils of war as the campaign wears on. The use of dynamic lighting is also some of the best that I've seen in early-era last gen games. The city of Dubai, as sand-swallowed as it may be, is massive and stunning to look at.

I will also add in a quick note here that the game does not suffer from any type of performance issues, at least in my experience. I always maintained a stable 80-120 FPS throughout the duration of the game while capping out at 144 FPS, and there were no crashes, glitches, or bugs.

The gameplay is solid for a shooter, there are no clunky controls. The entire control scheme is similar to that of the first Gears of War title; which is not unusual, seeing as Spec Ops was indeed crafted using the Unreal Engine. There are slight annoyances, such as when you're running you will sometimes stick to a piece of cover. Other than that, the control scheme is smooth and nearly flawless. As expected, there are tons of shooting sequences... almost too many at times. Around every corner there lurks another gang of foes who are waiting to rip Walker to shreds bullet by bullet. Like any good military style shooter, there is also Intel to collect.

Where Spec Ops: The Line really shines is within its story, and its soundtrack. This game has one of the best soundtracks of any shooter that I've ever played; from the rocking classic tunes to the Louisiana bayou styled twangy guitars, the tracks never get old no matter how many times one plays through the game. The same can be said for the story, which has a possibility of four endings once the player has reached the end of the ride. While I won't say a lot about the story, for those that have not played the game yet, I will say that Spec Ops definitely ripped off the original Black Ops, but I personally think this game does it way better.

A once respected high ranking military man who gradually goes crazy over the course of the campaign, only to have a huge twist revealed at the end. There are lots of feels-hitting areas between the beginning and end of the game, and the player can become very attached to Walker, Adams and Lugo throughout the time spent within the title; making it that much harder on the emotions when something goes awry. This aspect is where every single Call of Duty ever created has failed, and it's why people love Spec Ops: The Line. The game does spend a good amount of time carving out the characters, so that they don't just become more expendable jarheads in another military shooter.

If you haven't played Spec Ops: The Line yet, and you're in the market for a good third-person cover based shooter, definitely pick this up. It will be one of the greatest storylines in a shooter that you've ever experienced, and it's sure to stay within your memory for years to come. There are also many replay factors, and reasons to go back to the title; whether it's as soon as you complete it, or a couple years down the road. However, I cannot justify $32.99 CAD for a title that is almost three years old, get it on sale.

Rating: 5.0/5.0 - An amazing achievement, this game must be played.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)

reviewText:
WARNING: A LOT OF FORESHADOWING HERE, BUT NO SPOILERS

The best works of art are created in a time where they are most needed, and found in the places no one would bother to look. In today's gaming industry, many are looking for the next great narrative to be found in a small indie game, or an expertly crafted RPG. Absolutely nobody was expecting a third-person military shooter to be the breakthrough they were desperately searching for, and that just adds to the utter brilliance of Spec Ops: The Line.

As you may have heard, the game is very much intwined in the same themes as Joseph Conrad's incredible novel, Heart of Darkness". You are a Special Forces captain sent in with your 3-man squad to the ruins of Dubai. The way the city is presented is unlike any other world design in recent memory

This game is a ♥♥♥♥ing master piece. I know everyone praised it and well, this game is not overrated. It is a beautiful take on war, its meaning and an in-depth look at a soldier's psyche. voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Now this is a game that has impact on you. Throughout the chapters you come to feel what means to be human, to make mistakes and to learn about the weight of your actions. Three main characters (though only one is playable, but you get to like all of them), each one with their own personality and showing different reactions to the situations they come across and the things they have to do and choose to do. Yes, this game is a master at making you think if you ever had a choice, if you could have made the outcome different. You'll most likely get yourself wondering what you would have done or how you would have felt in their places.

Storywise this game could hardly get any better. It's epic, it's moving, it's personal.

Gameplay could see some improvements, movement sometimes is your worst foe, but it's not bad, many guns, squad commands, smooth aim, some strategy, some possibilities and the most useful grenades i've ever thrown (the enemies fully agree with this, believe me).

It has a decent amount of replay value, if you want to see the different paths you can take, make different choices and see all the possible outcomes. You can also increase the game difficulty and replay it, things can get very challenging.

So, in a nutshell, this game is a gem, completely worth playing, an amazing experience that still doesn't receive all the attention it deserves. I highly recommend this one.

reviewText:
There's probably nothing I can say about this game that hasn't been said already, but since I enjoyed (maybe not the right word) it so much, I'll say it anyway.

Spoiler Free-
Spec Ops: The Line is more of an experience than a game.  It's something that all gamers, particularly fans of the shooter genre, should pick up at least once.  If you haven't played already, quit reading reviews (it's better to go in blind) and pick it up, on sale if you need more persuasion.  The gameplay may not be great, and downright infuriating at times, but there's a reason for that, too.  Keep that in the back of your mind as you play.  Pay close attention to what's going on around you, how the people act, what they say.  Keep an open mind, and be ready for ♥♥♥♥ to go sideways.

Spoilers-
Wow.  Yager did a fantastic job of creating a game that challenges the norms of the genre, and speaks volumes for video games as an art form.  The gameplay may be frustrating, but it only serves to emphasize the fact that while everything tells you that you/Walker should stop playing/fighting, you continue to push on.  Losing your sanity, the difficulty ramps up, anger builds, the game opens professes its hate for you, and it's not even fun to play - but you keep going.  Why?  What does that say about you?  Is simply reaching the end worth what you'll have to do to get there?  The line between player and character is blurry.  You can justify your actions by saying that it's the only way to move forward, that the game is forcing you to do it, but you - and Walker - always had the choice to turn away, to leave Dubai, to put down the game.  But you keep going.  Notice how some of the transitions fade to black, while others fade to white?  Notice how often you begin a new segment of the game by falling, rappelling, descending?  Even though you were just underground, you're now above it just so you can descend another thousand feet into insanity?  Welcome to hell
date: Walker."  My hat's off to you

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line...

Ladies and gentlemen... Welcome to Dubai.


Story
Starting my review with commenting on how good of a story this game had (IMO).
Dramatic twists of events. Taking choices you wouldn't want to. Going through a deep slow path of insanity by each chapter.

I'm usually not amused by any type of story an army game has to offer and I must admit in my eyes most of them are more or less the same.
However out of the bucket of clichés and reused material Spec Ops: The Line stands out.
The fictional concept told here is so well blended that it kept my interest through the whole time from start to end.
I even did 4 runs of the game itself in order to experience all 4 different endings.
Can't say it is original, after the amount of movies and games that have been out so far, there's hardly anything new to be served in militaristic games. However it is the way the content is served that makes the difference in this type of games, this one right here gets the cookie for me.


Direction
The game is very very well directed. The way the story is balanced through action sessions, intense cutscenes, sweet environmental designs, and impressive musical options.
All combined so smoothly with some of the very best voice acting I've seen for an action shooter.

Graphics
Neatly scripted on Unreal Engine 3, the game has sweet physics and sandstorm and smoke dynamics. Of course there have been titles a lot more famous for their graphics for 2012.
But for the experience offered, Spec Ops: The Line's graphics are just perfect and it's lacking major bugs or issues.

Gameplay
Very easy and comfortable to handle. Ammo and amount of weapons is just about right.
Destructible environment (just a few details here and there) add a good taste on the style of the shooter experience and of course not missing the ability to take cover and using commands to make your crew help you dynamically in various situations.
Difficulty makes a difference from the easiest to the hardest mode and it gets more and more challenging, sometimes kinda too hard in the hardest difficulty level.

Music
The music used in the game is AMAZING.
Not only the acoustic backrgound is very good, but you will also hear a brilliant collection of songs through the game, every single one very accurately put in each situation like a glove.

Sound
Cool environmental and battle effects that seem about right at any moment of the game. No problems with blending music or voice acting.


Average
Considering that this game was implemented by a very small team and the studio itself is not even famous for having any other major titles around the market (Yager Development only have one other game implemented which is very old)
It was freaking amazing. With a story that has a beginning, a peak, and an end.
Well made, balanced, satisfying, with good action and even a well done multiplayer and co-op modes.
Considering how shallow other a lot more famous games from bigger studios have ended up being, Spec Ops: The Line is by the full meaning of the phrase 'a job well done'.
And for the asked price, this title is pure gold!
Do get it. 100% recommended!

-The story, although predictable, is interesting and provides social commentary on video games and the players in general

Cons:
-Gameplay can get repititive

-Story progression and plot points feel forced at some points
-Short campaign

reviewText:
Baby Killing [check]
Open Fire on Ayatollah Lynch Mob [check]
Teleporting Juggernaut [check]
Magical Shadow General [check]
Max Payne the Radioman [check]

---|ATMOSPHERE|---
Spec Ops is your own personal 8 hour episode of the show Zero Hour" as in everything goes to hell in it very quickly. You basically get to watch Dubai slowly crumble into a deserted wasteland with a few hellish parts in between. The diolague is great and the art design is fantastic. Voice acting is superb and the story is one of the best I have ever seen in a game. This is what Max Payne 3 should have been in this regard. The ending also wraps up nicely and makes perfect sense while being shocking.

---|GRAPHICS|---
The graphics can look pretty nice but may freak out. Imagine texture pop-in without the pop-in part. Also has inconsistent frame rate. Set it to HIGH setting for best results
date:
VERY HIGH generates a lot of heat for those with cheap fans and laptops. Lighting is also overdone in some parts to a certain extent.

---|GAMEPLAY|---
Spec Ops plays like any other 3rd person shooter. I have a feeling that the Devs had this in mind so they expected the story alone to carry the title. As a result the game didn't sell well but I still suggest you pick it up and don't read the spoilers. You will have a great time. Also
recommended:
the AI completely freaks out on FUBAR difficulty but you shouldn't need 2 playthroughs to really enjoy it.

---|MULTIPLAYER|---
Don't. Just please stick with singleplayer. Multiplayer feels rushed and slapped on to the wonderful singleplayer story.

In conclusion if you want a great story I highly suggest you try this title out. This isn't like all the other military shooters like Homefront and CoD. Spec Ops is not one of those "MURIKA kills evil terrorists" games. It simply shares the same setting."

reviewText:
Underated game. Glad i picked this up. At first glance it looks like any other 'pew pew murica to the rescue' sort of shooter but it goes far beyond that.
Gameplay seems pretty generic but the battles are quite fast paced and action packed. The environment is really cool. Fighting amongst a city swallowed by sand is defs one the games coolest features.
Now for the games winning feature..the story.
Words dont do it justice. The story sheds light on the side of warfare that is not often seen. It brings forward the harsh realities of warfare, how it changes people, that sometimes there are are no right choices. The game forces you to make choices that are definetely not easy to make and you will hate yourself for making them.
Give this a playthrough if you see this on sale. It will seriously suprise you.

reviewText:
Without giving out too much of the plot, this is a modern military shooter that deconstructs modern military shooters. The things that you'll do in this game will haunt your dreams weeks after you finish, and you'll question the things you do in other games for nearly the rest of your life. This third-person shooter blows the ♥♥♥♥ out of crappy, big budget FPSs like Call of Duty and Medal of Honor. Spec Ops: The Line is a must-have, must-play, and is worth every penny. By the way, I suggest that you find someone willing to hug you and tell you that you're still a good person once you finish...You'll need it.

.....Why haven't you bought this already, damn it?!

UPDATE 12/31/14: I've been ruminating a bit more on this and gaming's place amongst other media, and I want to say something else: Gaming may not yet have its 'Citizen Kane', but it damn sure does have its 'Apocalypse Now'. Also, as I'm writing this, the Steam Winter Sale has this at $5.99 US, which is 80% off its normal price. Anyone else dragging their feet on this purchase has no financial excuse. Buy this game as soon as possible.

reviewText:
You are climbing a mountain.

Woosh, swooosh, the wind blows hard into your face and all you see around you is vast desolation. Maybe some rocks are scattered around you, maybe a large endless blanket of snow threatens to swallow you up or maybe Big Foot is planning to mug you behind that large Pine Tree, whatever it is everything looks the same for miles around you. That's until you reach the top of the summit, at the summit you see everything: the blinding sun, the bodies from people of previous attempts... YOU ARE THE KING OF THE WORLD.

That's...Until you climb back down, except your climb is more of a tumble and then a cascading avalanche as you fall back to reality.

You aren't king, you are just one of everyone else.

reviewText:
To get into what made Spec Ops the Line one of the best games of the 7th generation I have to first shed a little background on the game.

Spec Ops the Line is a sequel to the Spec Ops games released in the 90s. It was originally planned to be a new IP but was made part of the Spec Ops brand for sequel bait. This is important because this ties into what Spec Ops the Line was advertised as. It was advertised as a big budget modern military shooter with an interesting setting but overly generic game mechanics and plot premise.

What we got was an elaborate satire of modern military shooters. Spec Ops the Line starts out similar to how you'd expect a big budget AAA game to start. You are a squad of soldiers, sent in to investigate a crisis, and you have to cowboy in and shoot some brown people.

However the game plays with this a lot. What was the exact nature of your mission? Why are the enemies so hostile to you? Why are your squadmates talking erratically about you? There are so many questions raised and the game delightfully gives you answers that you don't want to hear.

Spec Ops the Line's writing is very top notch. It satirizes the heroic power fantasy nature of modern military shooter plotlines and characters. And it plays with the idea of how would killing hundreds of people change you as a person".

Beyond that the gameplay is sound
date: it has Mass Effect style squad combat and fairly generic multiplayer. The singleplayer is what you get Spec Ops for
recommended: and it remains one of my favorite games ever for its message and its post-modern view on the 7th generation of video games overall. The main gripes I have with it are due to the linear nature of the game
hoursPlayed: and due to how the plot is written it isn't as replayable as you might think. But it still is one of the most breathtaking games I have ever played
voteText: and one I dearly recommend to people who want to play a game that'll make you feel uncomfortable and uneasy with your objectives."

reviewText:
Do you know this feeling when there are two voices in your head arguing over what is the right thing to do and it makes you extremely uncomfortable? It's called cognitive dissonance and Spec Ops: The Line makes you take a nosedive into a sea of that feeling.

It shows war as what it is. Not as the glorified, heroic, romanticized ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that we get stuffed with from games like Call of Duty and Battlefield, but as horror, pure, unfiltered horror. If you felt like the moral choices in games like Fallout punched you in the gut, what you'll have to do in Spec Ops will leave you feel like the game punched you in the face, wrenched open your jaw, reached down your throat and ripped out your guts.

Spec Ops makes the player feel what the main character is going through, but not simply via making you identify with the character you play. Its gameplay, world design and everything makes you feel uncomfortable, nauseous and morally torn apart. It really is brilliantly crafted.

I'll stop here to avoid possible spoilers or how you perceive the game while playing, but if you feel like dropping the game after playing for an hour because the combat feels generic and/or bad, please, please don't do that and press on, it's well worth it.

There's one last thing I'll say, if you decide to play it: When you hear the line Because you wanted to be something you're not."

reviewText:
Welcome to Dubai!
What do you See?
Is it a Salvation or an Devastation?
What do you think?
Is this the work of a Madman?
Your choice and Actions reflects upon yourself.
Question is, did you have a Choice?

Pros:
Great story
Well characterized characters, you are Captain Walker with your men Lugo and Adams.
The Environment is Nicely made and works.
Depending on what difficulty you can push yourself to real survive, tip make evert Bullet count.
A realistic AI from the Enemies, if you choice to hid behind cover, they will try to outflank you. Making it different from the Normal wooden duck shooting of enemies behind cover.
The lore/intel have an interesting background to it all.
Cons:
The NPC AI companions can be stupid sometimes but they eventually work.
The Cover mechanics can be a bit clunky times to time.
The Controles can be a bit weird, but in the end they work when you get used to them. (And you can always change them if you want)
Summary:
I Loved this game and it is really worth playing, maybe not for being the most Functionally, but for its Great Story.
If you have thought of buying this game, I suggest you do. So try to grab it next Steam Sale when you can.
And you will be in for an Experience.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line, is not really a fun and enjoyable game at its core, which is why it's so interesting, especially as just one (pretty short campaign with not very much multiplayer) shooter in a world where shooters are released en masse. Mechanically speaking, Spec Ops is a pretty standard third person shooter - two weapons at any one time , three throwables, and a selection of alternate weapon options with a comparatively smooth cover system. I did not really like the inability to aim and fire while sprinting, but that's a bit of a minor issue that I feel can be overlooked.

The graphics are reasonably good, especially for a game released in 2012. The background and setting is particularly well done, well able to convey a sense of a city tearing itself apart, and also the issues that have arisen from a city cut off from the rest of the world. It is a pretty brutal Dubai that you find yourself in, and the game conveys the sense of horror that has descended on the city very well.

The soundtrack is fantastic. Both it, and the storyline, short it may be, are probably the standout features of the game for me. Evoking imagery of Apocalypse Now, Spec Ops: The Line shows just how nightmarish and hellish war really is, apart from the glorified imagery that certain media has portrayed it as. Offering a look at the damage that can be done to a soldier's psyche from tours of duty, it also offers a look at the chain of command, something that is explored comparatively rarely. Offering questions regarding morality and cause and effect, while short, Spec Ops: The Line is well worth playing through.

reviewText:
A masterpiece in Dubai
Here it starts. Finally I completed this game third time (2 times like not license version and one more time here) and I can say with full confidence -  it is the best shooter I've ever played. But let me tell you more closely why I think so.

Graphic. In this game, you might find one of the best images in all shooters. Since the beginning you will be amazed by the fantastic scenery of the desert ... detailed characters, weapons, and equipment. Due to the game engine Unreal Engine 3 you'll subjugated by landscapes in this game .. it's just something incredible (for 2012).

Gameplay. The gameplay is also at a very high level. I can say with full confidence that it is much better than in CoD or Battlefield (yes, I played all these games). Every movement, every jump clearly and realistically worked out. To stay alive you need as quickly as possible to cross from one shelter to another, 'cause here you can be killed by EVERY bullet. Here is a great combat system and a large selection of weapons. You can kill your enemy with machine guns, pistols, shotguns, grenade launchers, different types of grenades. You can kill with his bare hands (it looks fantastic, and not just waving a knife as in CoD)! Or even just to fill their enemies great bunch of sand, which almost break out the windows or rooftops.

Story. Apparently, I have not enough words to describe it. For me - this is the best story that I have experienced in the game world. This story, the story of three brave friends deserves an Oscar! Welcome to Dubai, paradise on earth, which turned into hell! First, we have an intriguing start that somehow draws you and you want to know more... During the game events are fantastic, I will not spoiling, but the game has a heap of points that can cause you to fear and even tears. As for the end of the game ... I am quite sure that by the end of the game you will overfill different feelings... There are several different endings, and you have to make it for your own choice .. no matter how difficult it will be... This story impressed me to the core. And I really happy that I passed this way together with Delta team - Captain Walker, Lieutenant Adams and Sergeant Lugo.

I can talk for a long time about this game. Because for me it's really clever game that I'll always want to play. I want to say thanks studio Yager that they gave me this small miracle. I am so depressed that many players don't pay attention to this really fantastic game and continue to play CoD and Battlefield which  just turned into a boring conveyor.

Thank you for reading my own point of view.

Definitely 10/10
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line it's a third person shooter released in 2012 by 2k Games. It looks really generic and for absolutely sure I can tell you that there's nothing generic about this game.

Yeah the gameplay it's not something out of the box, but it's well crafted, a lot of weapon diversity, online cooperative and also a bunch of achievements to go for.

But the point here it's the story, the details of it that makes this game so enjoyable. You're Cpt. Walker, accompained by Lt. Adams and Ssgt. Lugo, you three are sent as a three-man Delta Force team to carry out reconnaissance.

You will really get into it and will question every decision that you and your fellas make. In fact your decisions impact the ending of the game. I won't spoil anything, but for sure it's not easy to be a hero.

Spec Ops shows what many shooters can't achieve: a great story combined with a well crafted gameplay.

Gentlemen, welcome to Dubai.

reviewText:
While Spec Ops is a difficult game to recommend based on its mediocre gameplay, performance issues, and frustrating controls the story packs a real punch and is the sole highlight of the game. The 'Do you recommend this game, Yes : No is very limiting here because it depends. If you are looking for a good game this isn't it. If you are looking for one with a great story that is a military game no less than you found it. In this "I'm offended" generation where someone always has to be offended by something and demand its removal the devs went all out and didn't care who they offended. They had a message to send and pulled no punches.

Game wise Spec Ops The Line suffers. I was constantly fighting with the controls and couldn't help but be bored to death whenever the shooting started thanks to the mediocre mechanics and bad AI. It came to the point where I was trying to rush through the game just so I could be done with it and that's a shame because it somewhat took away from the impact of the story.

The visuals are average and the aliasing hurt my eyes but it runs worse than Crysis 3. On a rig equipped with a 3770K
recommended: and a GTX 780ti I was getting frequent stutters
hoursPlayed: shaky mouse movements

reviewText:
I just finished a lenghty Spec Ops achievement marathon. Played this game a lot in my freetime and now I finally can put it to rest. While I don't want to consider myself an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥, I like to pay games I really enjoy a tribute by completing them 100%.

Now, this introduction perfectly fits (more or less) into the message of the game. Are violent games really just games, you play and get an achievement for your 50th headshot? Is it okay to sit back and enjoy war, while you are the hero, kicking the ♥♥♥ of all the terrorist scum that threatens to destroy the world? I can't really compare Spec Ops: The Line to Battlefield, Call of Duty setting-wise or Gears of War and Mass Effect gameplay-wise, as I've never played them. But what I can say is, that, in my humble opinion, Spec Ops: The Line is a masterpiece. Not without its flaws, but a masterpiece nonetheless.

Gameplaywise, you get the typical brown modern war 3rd person shooter thingy. What do you expect? You play a badass dude to murder tons of evil dudes. Simple as that. But storywise, you are encountered by some moral questions, you might not have asked you yet. And suddenly, all the dull gameplay makes sense in a more complex way.

I don't want to spoil too much here, so I'll keep it short: If you are expecting a breakthrough in modern warfare gameplay and gunfights, this game is nothing for you. If you are interested in a good and gripping story, with one ore the other twist and an underlying message, you must play this game, even if you don't care about war shooters, like me. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a basic 3rd person shooter with a great and impacting story.

The gameplay is pretty much your standard 3PP game. However it can be very challenging if you're not careful. You don't feel like the Terminator pushing through pumping bullets into meatbags. You have to have somewhat of a strategy as you move about the levels.

The best thing about the game itself though, is the story. From the time your boots on the ground in Dubai to the heartstring pulling choices to the compelling end you will stay hooked. The scenery is also great in this game. While obviously not boasting some of the best graphics, it holds it's own against other games of the genre.

I highly recommend this game, expecially if you can catch it on sale.

reviewText:
Gameplay-wise, this game shares a lot with games like Call of Duty or Battlefield. However, while those games are about gunning down black people with a gun you've balanced on your giant America-boner, this game is about madness, and the horror of wartime.
You play as the commander of a squad of soldiers, sent to evac Dubai after a series of disasters. However, you arrive to find the people being oppressed by rogue US soldiers. What follows is a long, hard journey, punctuated by brutality, anger, insanity and blood. In this regard, The Line could be described as a parody of CoD, except no-one's laughing.
A little pre-warning for this game: you will feel evil. Certain events in the game involve doing things that no sane man could do, and you will hate yourself. The more famous example of this is the infamous White Phosphorous scene, but what stuck with me more is the scene at the very end, when you have time to reflect on just what you have done.
This game will abuse you, smack you around for a bit, and light you on fire. But hey, after playing hundreds of games where you stomp all over the innocent, maybe we deserve our punishment.

reviewText: The story and the things going on really are a very unique and interesting piece of writing, since it shows the things you usually don't get to or want to see about war, especially in games. The graphics, cutscenes and voice acting is also superb. Because of that I really recommend getting this game at some point.\n\nThe game's main problem is its very generic gameplay - just a typical 3rd person shooter with a cover-system. The levels are very linear too.

reviewText:
Bottom line, I recommend this game.  If you like shooters, can stomach some very dark content, and want to play something a little bit different... this may be the game for you.

I am reviewing this as a single player title.  I have no interest in the multiplayer content, and have not tried it to provide feedback on it.

Before the good, I need to be clear on something many might view as bad.  I finished this game in one sitting last night of about six hours.  Some people hate short games, but this game is surprisingly deep, keeps you wanting to stay and play more, and I already am thinking about playing through again as its obvious there are different ending possibilities.  I view the shortness of this game as the one standout thing against it.

Moving on though... there was a lot I liked.

This game is about people who are in very dark situations, confronted by nothing but dark and challenging choices.  You are not either saving the damsel, or killing her dog.  I once read a review that seemed intriguing.  It said that once you realize whats going on you will be hooked and want to see the rest of the game through.  I got there.  I was hooked.  I had to see how it ends.

The gameplay was good, and by the time I realized why -- I was actually surprised.  Too many games have cover systems that aren't necessary.  Enemies that could fire 1000 bullets and maybe hit your water canteen once.  Etc...   Spec Ops:  The Line is not such a cake walk.  The enemies can hit you accurately, and they will.  Your AI team mates will be a necessity, but they will also be vulnerable.  There are times where you will run out of ammo and even if you don't like this gun or that based on your own style... you will think its a god send to have a way to fight off the enemy, and play accordingly.  I found myself using cover at every possible avenue.  Grenades were not an afterthought.  It was FUN.

I've played numerous shooters dating back to Wolfenstein 3D and Duke Nukem.  I've played Medal of Honor, Call of Duty, Battlefield, Halo, and more.  I have to say this game really felt different and drew me in how many AAA games have.

When everything was said and done, it was the story and presentation that blew my mind.  Mature modern story in a believable setting.

Random number score system? 9/10.  I was that impressed.

date: the more it started to...eat away at me.\n\nThe decisions that I made. I though that what I was doing was for good. To save people. The further I progressed

the more I started to doubt my decisions and my morals. Was I really saving people? Was I really doing this for good? Or was I doing it for myself?

The horror....the horror...."

reviewText:
This is a truthful, heartfelt and deeply grim perspective of war.
As close as we gamers will ever get to the real feel of what it is like.
The real depth and weight of our actions.

For years we have been desensitized to violence. To be taught it's kill or be killed - and the more gratuitous the kill the better the gameplay is. We never truly feel the weight of the kills we so effortlessly dish out to anyone who dare stand opposite of us. We're just trying to get from point A to point B and kill as many as possible.

Spec Ops: The Line changes the formula of traditional military shooters really making your decisions resonate with you. Making you thoroughly evaluate your moral scale and the horrific decisions you will have to face during war.

Absolutely outstanding, it made me feel like a monster when I was fighting for my life.
Highly, highly recommended.

10/10

reviewText:
While this game might seem like a normal military fps, it isn't. This is another game made by 2K https://www.2k.com/games . It's interesting to note how many of the games are made by 2k when we asked the various gaming groups to nominate games with the best story. This particular one entitled 'Spec Ops: The line' is actually the 8th one in this particular series though it shares nothing in common with its former installments of the games with the same namesake.

(Spoiler Alert)

The story basically follows a soldiers personal journey through limbo. You take control of a captain Walker who is in charge of a 2 man delta squad. The three of them are on a rescue mission to find the 33rd battalion and their captain Konrad who is someone considered to be of noble rank since he saved your life in a previous battle.

Dubai has become somewhat apocalyptic thanks to huge never ending sandstorms requiring that the whole city to be evacuated. The politicians and the elite downplayed the situation while at the same time evacuating it themselves in secret leaving countless thousands of refugees behind. The 33rd battalion coming home from a war in Afghanistan volunteered their services to help with the relief efforts.

The United States government however ordered the 33rd to abandon the city and its refugees, but the 33rd led by Captain Konrad ignored the command and insisted upon their wishes of leading a caravan of 1,000 people out of the city. However the sandstorms grew worse and the caravan promised never arrived at the proposed time given. Future communication and travelling was severed and the 33rd was publicly disavowed for treason.

After significant time a looped radio signal could be heard coming from the city again. It was a brief one from Captain Konrad. It basically stated that the attempted evacuation was a complete failure and the death toll was too many. The US military then decide to send a covert 3 man delta team in to locate any survivors and then radio for extraction.

Problem is as you guide this 3 man crew into Dubai, things begin to seriously not add up. The refugees are trying to kill you, the 33rd battalion wants to kill you and so does the CIA operatives. As you begin to hallucinate voices and visions, you also begin to witness some atrocities that each splintering faction of the city has done to each other. The game unfortunately forces you to make some of those atrocities yourself in order to push on and find answers and hopefully in the vain attempt to nobly save someone. Somewhere at the end of the game you will be haunted by the dead faces of those that you have killed asking you why you committed such acts and for what purpose? Eventually you will realize that your character is suffering with severe effects of PTSD.

There are 18 campaign chapters to play through with a somewhat highly decorated abstract version of Dubai buried in the sand. These chapters are spasmodically broken up with several morale choices placed throughout the game. The importance of these morale choices and the effects they will have on the game are purely there for illusion. None of your choices will really matter. No matter what you choose or how you go about things your character will be haunted by the people he has killed. There is no pleasant way out of this. The game literally forces you to make a decision which unknowingly at the time will kill thousands. It will then show you the consequence of that decision regardless of the fact that you had no choice about it and it will ask you why did you do it?

Here's where the nobility of the story fails immensely and does not have the same power or punch to a story where your choice really does matter. Any morale judgments are quickly dismissed under a rigged gaming framework. While it does get you to think about things and it has moved and inspired countless people to think about the consequence of actions, I personally think it could have been delivered better to make more of an impact on gamer's than what it already has.

Definitely worth a look...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xx-DgKI12qA

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Spec Ops: The Line is a third person shooter who takes a warfare story telling aspect, and mixes in gritty realism, coupled with very solid cover-based-game play.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  How do you talk about the story in this game without giving away any great details? The story goes in a very unorthodox direction from most Shooter games I've played. Additionally there are choices that you make throughout the game, and it's not just go right or go left" as the saying goes "indecision is a choice".
In the words of William T. Sherman we hear the well known quote "War is Hell" To be quite honest not very many shooter games run with that concept
recommended: you will see far more gritty details of consequences of warfare... and the people effected.\nAs a final note regarding the story length
hoursPlayed: I after playing through the game my first time I put in 5.5 hours. I generally play slower trying to find extra items and do restarts for achievements

reviewText:
A underrated gem of a shooter
Title: Spec ops: The line
Genre: 3th person shooter, story rich
Developer: Jager
Publisher: 2K games

Introduction

This game really took me by suprise. I went in like it was another generic third person shooter so I can kill some time but after playing I was 3 hours further. without even noticing. next to the shooting and blowing up heads there is a engaging story.
Now lets get into the review!

The Story:

You are playing as captain Walker. a delta force operator who was dropped in Dubai for a mission to find survivers of the failed evacuation of Dubai. but when you and your team reach the outskirts of Dubai everything goes south real fast. You get ambushed and attacked from all sides. And you seem to be landing deep in a ♥♥♥♥♥torm. after a while you find some terrible secrets about Dubai after the sandstorm. ( dont want to spoil anything)
your mission just changed: SURVIVE

Gameplay:

This is a 3th person shooter with cover based shooting mechanics. The game has some responsive controls and plays very well, you can also command your squad to stun the enemy with flashbangs or kill them from a distance to get you out of pretty messy situations. It is a bit more tactical than most shooters of this genre. You can choose from a variety of weapons do completely destroy your enemies, ranging from pistols to long range rifles. The gameplay ain't anything special but it works well for this game. Jump in and out of cover while you try to dodge bullets and command your 2 comrades in battle.

Graphics, voiceacting, performance

The game has some really neat graphics and it looks good for a thirdperson shooter. The devs really brought a post-apocalyptic hit by a sandstorm Dubai to life. Destroyed enviroments, broken buildings and snad.. lots and lots of sand. as for the voice acting I have nothing to complain. The voice actors did a good job. The game itself did not suffer from bad framerate and bugs, glitches. nothing to take me out of the game. It is well optimized and there are enough settings to mess around with at the menu.

Multiplayer:

Dont, just dont.. it adds  nothing  to your experience and is just boring as hell.. the devs were forced to put it in so I guess we just have to go along with it. you cant blame them for being forced to put it in.

Conclusion & Final verdict

I would recommend you this game if you are in for a 8 to 10 hours of explosive gunplay and a good story to go along with the shootouts. (not a fun story, its war. war isn't supposed to be fun) but well written and voiceacted. If you are not here for a story you will still have fun with shooting people straight in the face I guess.After I played trough the game 2 times  (dont mind the only 3 hours because I just bought it again since I had a version of the game which was not on steam.)
This is one of the most underrated games out there in this genre. I highly recommend you to pick it up if you are in for a good story and some enjoyable gunfights.
My final verdict for Spec ops: The line is a great 9/10

reviewText:
Do you feel like a hero yet ?

It is a crime that SO: The Line is way under the radar. Hands down, it is one of the best third shooter games I've ever played. This is not another one of those shooters were you go all Rambo on your opponents' asses in the name of 'Murica.

The story is something else. I went through a lot of mixed feelings while playing it ranging from anger, to disgust, to regret. The story features multiple decisions to make, which neither will be good or bad.


The graphics are pretty and the setting of the game is unique. Despite being a work of ficition, it actually gave me sorta of an answer to my question which is; how would a post apocalyptic Dubai look like ?


Now for the gameplay. While many people found the gameplay to be average, I actually loved it, probably because I love third person shooters such as Killswitch (regarded as the godfather of 3rd person shooters, Uncharted, TLOU, Gears and many others. Aside from shooting, running, and hiding, you get to order your unit to either take down targets, stun them, heal an injured comrade or revive" him if he is down.

This game is a must play. Don't judge it from ♥♥♥♥♥♥ screenshots or youtube videos. Try
recommended: the demo and judge for yourself."

reviewText:
What can be said about Spec Ops The Line? This is a tough one. I mean it is a ♥♥♥♥ing cool game, but the emotions it gives you can really be tough to deal with.
Games with  Stories like this should be in every gamers library and every gamer and non gamer should experience a story like this.
We hold for granted what war is actually like. We go around blowing ♥♥♥♥ up and blasting the ♥♥♥♥ out of whatever moves without any ideas to the reality, the actual truth of war. I recognize first hand what war can do to somebody. I know the mind can become damaged with PTSD. My father is a Vietnam veteran and is  100% disabled with PTSD. He has been suffering all his life and will for the remainder of his lifetime. We don't understand the horrors and choices of war if we have never experienced them for ourselves. Well, this game brings out some of those feelings and choices that War can bring people to. What is right or what is wrong? Who is bad and who is good? What must we do to survive?
The game play is not the greatest cutting edge style.. You may get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at your NPCs or at the controls of your character, but the story and really nice visuals will overpower these flaws. Don't get me wrong the gameplay is fun. I truly love playing cover style shooters. They just seem more real to me because if you're in a fire fight the first thing you're going to do is jump behind whatever you can. The cover system does have its flaws, but nothing that ruins the fun.
If you want a game that is not your typical shooter a game that really gives you tough choices you should play this game..
This game is the chronic ♥♥♥♥.
http://youtu.be/deSEELtbQIs

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is awesome and amazingly underrated.
It looks great (that setting! that landscapes! every room is different! that graffiti! characters become dirtier and dirtier as plot advances!), has awesome music (astonishing selection of vocal tracks, including Jimi Hendrix, Deep Purple, Mogwai and Bjork, and instrumental depressing post-rock ambience) and terrific story (it wil make you feel the feels, man, I guarantee it).
The only complaint is monotonous gameplay  and a couple badly designed parts (mostly it's because of lack of checkpoints) which were too difficult (at least for me) AND MADE ME ♥♥♥♥ING RAGE MY ♥♥♥ OFF ARRRRRRGGGGHHH (almost threw my gamepad against the wall; btw — I do not recommend playing this on gamepad, use keyboard & mouse, it's  much better); still the game has better gameplay than Call Of Duty or single-player Battlefield campaign  (lol, haters gonna hate).
Everything else is totally cool, final plot twist and overall plot awesomeness is comparable to that of Bioshock Infinite.
Also very enjoyable collectibles, every one of which has some plot exposition (again kind of like Bioshock Infinite with its collectable voxophone records).
Very nicely done. Good job, devs.

9/10, one of my favourite story-driven games of all time.
