reviewText:
I've had this game for a while now and have just got to playing it, and I have to ask myself: Why have I not played this sooner?

Without spoiling anything, the story and plot are completely beautiful and heartwrenching, on the edge of your seat surprising, and will completely question your morales and those of the characters you interact and meet. I jumped in expecting another mindless shooter with loose story, but found myself in love with this game and its story.

On the technical aspect, the gameplay is relatively simple and easy. Suicide difficulty is not incredibly challenging, but a large factor of combat is to utilise your Delta squad and hide behind cover. The game can be completed in under 7 hours, probably less, which seems perfect as the story isn't drawn on and combat seems fast enough behind cover that you aren't getting entirely bored.

Graphically, I am also surprised at how beautiful this game can look. Your Delta squad continues to degrade and gain battle scars, blood, and torn clothing as the game progresses and otherwise looks like days of fighting in Dubai. The scenery and city looks amazing as well! I play with a GIGABYTE P35K-1 with nVidia GTX 765m and ran everything to the max and had no flops.

Story: 10/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Graphics: 9/10
Strength of Denial: 100/10

I actually Like This Game!

Controls are easy to manage. Graphics are very beautiful in parts.

Put off playing this for the longest of times.

Find the enemy AI is good on the 2nd hardest level.
Multiple ways of doing things ( even for an on the rail shooter).

In all, If you don't have this in your collection then you are missing out.

reviewText:
i owned this game more than 1 year without playing it, but now i regret that i did not played it earlier.
the game is also having the message that we all can make a stupid decision, which we will regret later.

in the first hour of gameplay this isnt much different compared with any other 08/15 3rd-person shooter.
but with further progress in the story, the true strenght of the game will be revealed.

the game is taking place in dubai, where heavy sandstorms isolated its whole population.
the player is taking the role of cpt. martin walker accompanied by his squad members lugo and adams.
this squad was sent to investigate the misterious vanishing of the 33rd Battalion who was sent earlier to start a rescue mission for the survivors of the catastrophe.

the story is showing the dark side" of war on a high psychological level.
several choices will be given to the player
date: during the playthrough.\nat the end of the 5 hour long story
recommended: cpt. walker is getting confronted with "the truth"

the decisions the player made will come back to him in a very uncomfortable way.

reviewText:
Not to be dramatic, but this is likely a historical game for the games industry.

Never has a game made me actually feel the horrors of war, made me feel horrible, even physically sick after specific moments.

What's impressive his how... seamless the combat is. Its nothing that really stands out, unless you cound nice responsive controls and good feedback special, because it almost is nowadays. But whats important is that it doesn't detract from the narrative, which makes it all the more impacting.

I won't spoil anything, but the plot mainly focuses on PTSD, as well as commenting on the current trend of Modern War, essentially saying they're bad like we already knew. But the best part is that it presents itself like one of these Call of Duty like games, drawing you in with this illusion of turning your brain off for the fun.

In short, amazing narrative, game of the decade, must buy.

reviewText:
I finished it in hard mode in a day. Compared to fps like Mass Effects, CoDs & Battle Fields etc, the controls for Spec Ops is a little unsmooth. I struggled to shoot behind cover most of the time becoz the character would suddenly stand up and get shot.

Gameplay-wise its a little mix of good and bad. Some parts of the game really depends on your luck. You replay the same part after dying for a few times, doing the same thing and finally get through after trying many times. AI is mediocre, but you definitely can't Rambo like you do in CoD.

Graphics are ok, I know some people complained about the lack of details, but overall I think its still acceptable. The game is 2 years old anyway.

Story. Especially after playing recent CoDs & BFs with terrible storyline & endings, Spec Ops' story definitely got me hooked. There's much depth & insights that make you questions your decision.

If you want a fps game with a good storyline, go for it. If you want a game where you can be Rambo, go for CoDs.

reviewText:
To be honest with you, I just picked this game up because it was on sale. And looking at the metacritic score and the name itself I rather expected it to be another generic, mediocre shooter.
Oh boy, I couldn't have been more wrong!!

Gameplaywise it totally fits that description. It is a Gears of War-esque Shooter with slightly harsher damage model.
Graphics are typical PS3/Xbox360 stuff. On the other hand the Leveldesign, though linear, is well made and creates a atmospheric and breathtaking environment I often found myself starring at in appreciation.
AI is decent. Squadmates are actually useful, taking cover and supporting you. Enemy AI will use suppressive and cover fire and try to flank you and also use grenades to flush you out of cover.
Not gonna talk about MP. Yager studio themself said in an interview they didn't want it and they didn't do it. But Publisher 2K still made a different studio do it and shoe-horned it in...
So what is the BIG selling point of this game? It's narrative!

If Apocalypse Now" (and for that matter "Heart of Darkness") was a game
date: this is what it would be like. You will see plenty of references and parallels but rest assured
recommended:
the game isn't just a copy. It has a story in its own right and goes its own ways.

As the story unfolds the lines between good and evil will start to dissolve until there is nothing left. You are being dragged into a conflict you have no concept off and always left one step behind. It keeps spiraling out of control fast as things turn sour and ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan - mainly because of your own ignorance - while you also have to bear the dire consequences of your actions.

On the metalevel the game is toying with alot of our preconceptions about Shooters
hoursPlayed: how violence and morality is represented and going into some other really deep stuff if you start thinking about it.\nSpecOps deliberately keeps giving the players red herrings
voteText: false targets and vague objectives and watches us kill again and again regardlessly. It says we need to blow up some people and we do it.\nBecause it is what needs to be done to accomplish the mission
helpfulPercent: right?  "We have no choice" like Cpt. Walker says. After all we are the good guys
votesHelpful:
fighting for a just cause with only the best intentions. Violence is a mere necessity.
Who would have thought those people might be unarmed civilians with children? And at the next loading screen you will be asked  “Do you feel like a hero yet?”
That effectively is what SpecOps is all about: to ♥♥♥♥ with your head and expectations. This game is a mind ♥♥♥♥ through and through.

Bottom line: don't let yourself be put off by it's looks
votesTotal: because there is more to it than it first seems. You should really give it a try! Chances are you won't be disappointed."

reviewText: So, how do you review this game without spoiling anything? Well, if you're tired of the run-of-the-mill triple A shooter games, you should definitely try this. You could still play it by just mowing down enemies with whatever weapon you have, but this game is not about that. It's about the journey of three Delta operatives sent on a mission that doesn't exactly go as planned. It is a story about the thought processes that take place in the mind of a war-torn operative that's just trying to follow his orders. But is he?\n\nIn the end, you'll get a glimpse of your own thought processes. But remember this. There is ALWAYS a choice!

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line plays like a rebuttal to the jingoistic chest beating espoused by the CoD and MoH series in their later iterations. This is a story which puts war under the magnifying glass, and examines its horrific consequences, both on the individuals who fight those wars, and those caught in the crossfire. Essentially, it is gaming's Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now.

The Gameplay is standard cover shooter fare, so it begins to feel a bit tired towards the final third of the game, but given the story content, I almost feel that this exhaustion with the game mechanics helps reinforce the themes of the game - which I will not comment on here, and instead say: Play this game, it is an amazing piece of work that is sadly vastly underappreciated.

Survivors: One too many.""

reviewText:
This is probably one of the best games I've ever played.

Why?

The gameplay is pretty standard fare for the shooter genre, with some somewhat interesting squad dynamics thrown in. I've heard the multiplayer is terrible, if you can find anyone still playing it at all.

So why is this game so amazing? The story in the campaign. It plays on your psyche, messes with your head, and makes you question why you even play games like this. It's a critique of the entire genre, one that desperately needed to be made. Why do we, as gamers, typically like to shoot things for fun? Is killing people in a video game truly harmless? If so, should we still enjoy it as much as we do?

The story draws from some classics for inspiration (most notably Heart of Darkness, by Joseph Conrad), but it takes what it needs and expands on the rest. It takes some classic conventions, and finds a way to use that to tell its own story, and tell a completely new and fresh message.

To kill for yourself is murder. To kill for your government is heroic. To kill for entertainment is harmless.""
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't often go out of my way to review games. But this game? As a a gamer in the first person shooter era - and especially being an American - I feel this piece of art should be experienced unspoilt by everyone. No other game will make you feel so strongly connected to a storyline as this one will.

Spec Ops the line has fairly average third person shooter mechanics. This sounds like a negative: it isn't. Why? Because Spec Ops: The Line is a commentary as much as it is a game. Since the story is what makes this game gold, I'll avoid saying too much, but the game does a good job of making the player aware of the struggles on all sides of war. On top of this, it continually references the destructive military culture of America, and questions the player whether they are truly okay with the way media treats war in general.

It's all done in a way that simply poses a question : Do you feel like a hero yet?

reviewText: Wow!  What an amazing, story-driven, combat game.  It was like watching a serious and brutally viscious war-gone-bad movie on acid.  The character voice-acting, imho, is the finest yet in all of gaming.  The music is top notch.  The weapons are real military weapons, and there's many.  The visuals are excellent.  The many diverse combat sequences are wild, intense, and sometimes challenging.  Some combat scenes and cutscenes are downright crazy, shocking, and memorable.  I think this is one of the best games ever made, and it's bound to be a classic.  I highly recommend it, but only if you can stomach brutal war images.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a third person cover-based shooter. Your mission in Dubai is to save some people, but how far you go to save them,  the further you will go into insanity.

To give my opinion about the experience of playing the game, I have to say it, at first it felt generic to me. ( like the trailers felt generic to me) I didn't really care about anything or anyone. The game felt like a parody of modern shooters, because it was so generic. But after I reached a certain point in the game I finally saw what makes this game so special. And that is letting you feel the pain of making choices in war.

There were some gameplay parts that were exciting but most of the time it wasn't. The only thing this shooter has that other shooter don't, is the use of sand, which hasn't been used that much sadly in the game. You can use your A.I. partners to help you. Sadly, you can only order them to throw flashbangs or target enemies. So you can't really execute big tactical moves with them. But I have to say on the hardcore difficulty I played the game on they sometimes were useful. Except when you have to revive them...  There are stealth missions, that are just 'kill these 3 people and than just go on shooting again.' I had really hoped that they would expand on those parts just for the variety.

The levels are really well styled with a lot of detail. But, in many places, it doesn't look that amazing graphically, I think the reason for that is due it being an unreal 3 game. This also contributes to the game looking often like a generic shooter.

I really liked when the game let you made in-game choices because they felt well thought out. This occasionally stops the game being a 'shoot everything that moves' game, and allows you, for example, to make a choice whether to kill or not to kill someone. But, often you will be shooting everything you see, which struck me as strange. Sadly, these choices have no effort on the game ending. You will always get the same two endings to choose from. Once I completed the singleplayer I reloaded a save to see the other ending I didn't choose. I also reloaded some missions to get 3 collectables, most of the time they are easy to find, because of the invisible walls. The collectables told some other stories. Also helped with the achievements, which are easy to get in the game.

I would really recommend this game to anyone who is interested in war. The game really made you confront with what you done and makes the line between good or bad people invisible. It also made me think about different aspects of war while playing it.

(Co-op &  Multiplayer:
You should get the game for the singleplayer experience.

I haven't played the 2 player co-op, but, from what I have seen, it is just 5 edited levels from the singleplayer. I guess they are just okay, because nobody is talking about it.

From the multiplayer I have played I can say it is what you would expect from the game after having completed the singleplayer. If you are interested in playing it, you can join the spec ops group  here	  , which has just recently been made. It already has many people joined up, though that could be because there aren't many proper online third-person cover-based shooters on steam. ( correct me if I am wrong ) They are also working on some mods. Still, if you search for an online match normally you will find nobody.)

In short: Spec Ops: The line is a third person cover-based shooter which shows that killing people doesn't make you feel like a hero.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
WOW! What a surprise!

I got this game really cheap and had no expectations at all, though I thought the game atleast looked rather good, and I liked the idea that it was located in Dubai, one of the most interesting cities in the world.

To my surprise it had an interesting, intense and clever story told in a mature way. The scenery you go through is stunningly beautiful and devastating at the same time. I love the level design. Along the way you have to make choices that carries real consequences. You can use the environment as cover and as means of destruction. You get a wide variety of weapons with limited ammo and face waves of varied enemies that want to take you down. Tha AI seemed quite good in this game. And there is hidden intel to find.

I found the game hugely entertaining, but it also leaves a foul taste in the mouth. You kinda get to understand the situation you're in and how it psychologically affects you. You don't see that in many games. I applaud the developers here.

The one issue I found in this game is that it is rather short. But seeing you usually get this game cheap I have no trouble recommending it to anyone who likes FPS's and/or good storytelling. Should not be missed.

8/10

Happy gaming!

TJ

reviewText:
Dude, Spec Ops: The Line, what a trip to hell... if you like stories, not the stereotypical stuff with the happy ending and ♥♥♥♥, im talking about something to make you think, something to make YOU feel... anger, sorrow, guilt, madness, then you're in for a treat with this game.

I should say that some games have evolved so much that they are also an expression of art, not only in the visual context but in the narrative side, putting you in the perspective of the protagonist, making your choises somehow important to the development of the plot, which is also fun as hell, these games are the artform from the present era.

About graphics, i loved them, Dubai city is presented in such great detail, even the climate is represented accurate, always seems to prevail a horrid heat wave and the characters sweat and get injuried in a realistic way. About the cutscenes, the editing technique is very well done and the graphics are the same as the rest of the game keeping the action style, the main character suffers an insane transformation to get the end of the game, you can see him as a wild animal cornered trying to save his life by destroying his hunters, look at his eyes.

About the sound, is all realistic about gunshots, blasts and enviromental, the voice acting is superb, i read they hired Desmond from assassins creed, in that game he kinda sucked but here he really delivers all his lines, the interaction with the characters is also really good, lets say something like at the begining he sounds like all technical and professional soldier, but later on he becomes sadistic and full of rage and you can hear him getting all psychotic, its insane.

About playability, what, lots of guns, explosives, properly represented-- and is really friendly to master combat techniques, there is also some interaction degree, like firing heavy machine guns or issuing orders to squad members, also destroying certain parts in the map to let sand bury your enemies alive, all the good ♥♥♥♥, but is in the command to your guys stuff that i found the weak point in this game, The AI is mostly lame as it gets, if you fail to cover them, your guys will run into certain death and that is more troubles for you. About the dificulty level, easy is for dumb ♥♥♥♥s, on the other side, FUBAR dificulty will get your ♥♥♥ on the grill, hard as nails, it is a big challenge.

Last words.. man i loved this adventure, but it left me with a weird feeling in my soul (?), something other war games failed to portray, lets say call of fruty, where enemies fall just like shapes under your relentless gunfire, this game will make you think over your choices, war is not fun, i really dont know when we desensitized so much about killing other humans, i know ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, its just a game but think about it, you're getting used to the idea of unloading your mag upon other humans without feeling anything, thats not right. We need more games to think about it, we need to THINK more.

You don't play Spec Ops: The Line for it's mediocre gameplay and combat mechanics, you play it for the unforgettable story that perfectly portrays a man's decent into complete madness.

reviewText:
Para análise em português, leia mais abaixo.

Spec Ops The Line - Review: Lost and Damned

Dubai. An oasis of technology and lust in the middle of desert. Magnificent buildings in a developed city. But nature is always more ruthless than our ability to oppose. Destroyed by intense sandstorms, a city in ruins. The 33rd Battalion of the American army is sent to town for a rescue and extraction operation of the survivors. And then, they disappear from the map.

You are Captain Martin Walker, leader of an elite team of Delta Force of the Army of the United States of America, leading his fellow Lieutenant Alphanso Adams, heavy gunner and Sergeant John Lugo, sniper. Sent to Dubai after a transmission captured after six months without contact, his mission is to locate, reunite and rescue possible survivors.

Beautiful scenarios, even among ruins. The opulence of Dubai can be seen in the ruins and in few places that remained intact. Even the desert, displays an exotic beauty that brings a melancholy tone to the game.

Spec Ops is not just a shooting game in third person. It is a psychological plot. Every dialogue, every action, every event in this journey shows you more than bullets flying. Dubai is alive. Dubai is at war. And war... war never changes. The horrors of war are not shown as simple digital polygons falling to the ground with AI off. You will really feel them. You will hesitate. You will have anger and and will be thrilled. And maybe you even cry. You'll be confused. Do not stop. Go straight. Reflect, try to understand. Do not come to this game to play. Come to this story to live it. And so, you will not regret it.

Gentlemen, welcome to Dubai.

My Personal Score                Fun:        9/10                Gameplay:        9/10                Ambientation:        9/10                History:        10/10                Replayability:        6/10                Multiplayer:        1/10
--

Spec Ops The Line - Análise: Perdidos e Condenados

Dubai. Um oásis de tecnologia e luxuria em pleno deserto. Construções magníficas em uma cidade extremamente desenvolvida. Mas a natureza, é sempre mais impiedosa do que nossa capacidade de nos opor. Destruída por intensas tempestades de areia, uma cidade em ruínas. O 33º batalhão do exército americano é enviado a cidade para uma operação de resgate e extração dos sobreviventes. E então, eles desaparecem do mapa.

Você é o Capitão Martin Walker, líder de uma equipe de elite da Força Delta do Exército dos Estados Unidos da América, liderando seus companheiros Tenente Alphanso Adams, artilheiro pesado e Sargento John Lugo, franco-atirador. Enviados a Dubai após uma transmissão ser captada depois de 6 meses sem contato, sua missão é localizar, reunir e resgatar possíveis sobreviventes.

Belos cenários, mesmo entre ruínas. A opulência de Dubai se destaca em traços que podem ser percebidos nas ruínas e em poucos lugares sobreviventes. Mesmo o deserto, exibe uma exótica beleza que traz um tom melancólico ao jogo.

Spec Ops não é apenas um jogo de tiro em terceira pessoa. É uma trama psicológica. Cada diálogo, cada ação, cada acontecimento nesta jornada te mostra mais do que balas voando. Dubai está viva. Dubai está em guerra. E a guerra... a guerra nunca muda. Os horrores da guerra não são mostrados como simples polígonos digitais caindo ao chão com IA desligada. Você realmente irá sentí-los. Você irá hesitar. Você terá raiva e se emocionará. E talvez, você até mesmo chore. Você ficará confuso. Não pare. Siga em frente. Reflita, procure compreender. Não venha a este jogo para jogar. Venha a esta história para vivê-la. E assim, você não irá se arrepender.

Senhores, bem-vindos a Dubai.

Minhas Notas Pessoais                Diversão:        9/10                Gameplay:        9/10                Ambientação:        9/10                História:        10/10                Rejogabilidade:        6/10                Multiplayer:        1/10

reviewText:
A very under-rated atmospheric third person shooter.

This game follows a very rich storyline with a Fight Club ending that will blow your freaking mind.
A short campaign lasting approx 5 hours loaded with difficult co-op & multiplayer modes.

This game on normal difficulty can give you troubles. Play on suicide if you dare.

Only negative in this game is the cover system. While it works very well, when you're behind cover and you need to move quickly (a grenade has landed next to you), you will literally go exactly where you DO NOT want to go. This caused many very frustrating deaths & situations. Apart from this mishap, you will not be disappointed. Spec Ops The Line delivers very well with a rich storyline & many great atmospheric environments.

+ Atmospheric
+ Story Rich
+ Third Person (Done properly)
+ Short Campaign [COD Style] 15 Chapters lasting approx 10-20 minutes each.
+ Co-Op
+ Psychological Ending
+ A challenge
+ Intense
+ High Fast Paced Action
+ Execution System
+ Bullet Time

- Cover System (Although this does work well when taking cover at times)
- Heavy Armed enemies
- Bit too pricy for what you get


Only negative in this game is the cover system. While it works very well, when you're behind cover and you need to move quickly (a grenade has landed next to you), you will literally go exactly where you DO NOT want to go. This caused many very frustrating deaths & situations.
Apart from this mishap, you will not be disappointed.

Spec Ops The Line delivers very well with a rich storyline & Dubai perfectly served in post-apocalyptic conditions.

8.5/10

(Yes I played 7 chapters first straight up & then finished the last 8 chapters 2 years later after realising I was missing out on a great ending.)

reviewText: Short, but satisfying game. Even after 4 years, the graphics look nice and the engine works well (no bugs encountered). What made me love this game is the soundtrack, playstyle (getting headshots 24/7), and the story, although the last one is a love-hate relationship, as it shows the somewhat real army life - gorey and brutal, rather than running around killing people (though you have that too, from time to time). Also, the cinematics are pretty amazing, especially towards the end of the game - destroying buildings whilst flying a helicopter - what more could you want? You're allowed to make multiple choices throughout the game, which affect your sanity. The only drawbacks for me are the 30 fps/720p cutscenes, and the length of the game (6 to 12 hours), but that can be justified by the quality of the game, and the multiple choice scenarios. Overall, it's a great and original TPS, definitely deserving more recognition. If you haven't played it, make sure you get it on a sale, it can go for dirt cheap, and it's definitely worth playing.

reviewText:
Don't think I've ever played anything quite like this. Not your typical gung ho shooter in the slightest. The actual gameplay is solid but the story is where it really shines. Sounds wrong to say I enjoyed it as some parts are pretty gut wrenching but it's easy to recommend. Just don't blast through it like you would any other shooter. Taking in the plot, dialogue and your surroundings really pays off.

A contender for my game of the year which is a huge surprise as it hadn't been on my radar at all until I picked it up extremely cheap in the sale.

reviewText:
An interesting take on a modern shooter game, with a well written story that is as far from the standard shooter game narrative as you can get.
It makes the player think rather than run around with a gun celebrating violence and the myth of a clear line between the good and bad guys.
The guys at Yager did a great job, and I would recommend this game for anyone who is interested in a deep thought provoking storyline.

The multiplayer was an unneccessary addition that brings nothing to the games single player experience, but that should not stop you from getting it, this was always intended to be a single player game only.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a third person cover-based shooter. Your mission in Dubai is to save some people, but how far you go to save them,  the further you will go into insanity.

To give my opinion about the experience of playing the game, I have to say it, at first it felt generic to me. ( like the trailers felt generic to me) I didn't really care about anything or anyone. The game felt like a parody of modern shooters, because it was so generic. But after I reached a certain point in the game I finally saw what makes this game so special. And that is letting you feel the pain of making choices in war.

There were some gameplay parts that were exciting but most of the time it wasn't. The only thing this shooter has that other shooter don't, is the use of sand, which hasn't been used that much sadly in the game. You can use your A.I. partners to help you. Sadly, you can only order them to throw flashbangs or target enemies. So you can't really execute big tactical moves with them. But I have to say on the hardcore difficulty I played the game on they sometimes were useful. Except when you have to revive them...  There are stealth missions, that are just 'kill these 3 people and than just go on shooting again.' I had really hoped that they would expand on those parts just for the variety.

The levels are really well styled with a lot of detail. But, in many places, it doesn't look that amazing graphically, I think the reason for that is due it being an unreal 3 game. This also contributes to the game looking often like a generic shooter.

I really liked when the game let you made in-game choices because they felt well thought out. This occasionally stops the game being a 'shoot everything that moves' game, and allows you, for example, to make a choice whether to kill or not to kill someone. But, often you will be shooting everything you see, which struck me as strange. Sadly, these choices have no effort on the game ending. You will always get the same two endings to choose from. Once I completed the singleplayer I reloaded a save to see the other ending I didn't choose. I also reloaded some missions to get 3 collectables, most of the time they are easy to find, because of the invisible walls. The collectables told some other stories. Also helped with the achievements, which are easy to get in the game.

I would really recommend this game to anyone who is interested in war. The game really made you confront with what you done and makes the line between good or bad people invisible. It also made me think about different aspects of war while playing it.

(Co-op &  Multiplayer:
You should get the game for the singleplayer experience.

I haven't played the 2 player co-op, but, from what I have seen, it is just 5 edited levels from the singleplayer. I guess they are just okay, because nobody is talking about it.

From the multiplayer I have played I can say it is what you would expect from the game after having completed the singleplayer. If you are interested in playing it, you can join the spec ops group  here	  , which has just recently been made. It already has many people joined up, though that could be because there aren't many proper online third-person cover-based shooters on steam. ( correct me if I am wrong ) They are also working on some mods. Still, if you search for an online match normally you will find nobody.)

In short: Spec Ops: The line is a third person cover-based shooter which shows that killing people doesn't make you feel like a hero.

reviewText:
WOW! What a surprise!

I got this game really cheap and had no expectations at all, though I thought the game atleast looked rather good, and I liked the idea that it was located in Dubai, one of the most interesting cities in the world.

To my surprise it had an interesting, intense and clever story told in a mature way. The scenery you go through is stunningly beautiful and devastating at the same time. I love the level design. Along the way you have to make choices that carries real consequences. You can use the environment as cover and as means of destruction. You get a wide variety of weapons with limited ammo and face waves of varied enemies that want to take you down. Tha AI seemed quite good in this game. And there is hidden intel to find.

I found the game hugely entertaining, but it also leaves a foul taste in the mouth. You kinda get to understand the situation you're in and how it psychologically affects you. You don't see that in many games. I applaud the developers here.

The one issue I found in this game is that it is rather short. But seeing you usually get this game cheap I have no trouble recommending it to anyone who likes FPS's and/or good storytelling. Should not be missed.

8/10

Happy gaming!

TJ

reviewText:
Verdict:
Buy now!
Buy on sale
Save your money

Summary:
Spec Ops: The Line is your fairly run of the mill 3rd person shooter, with one exception - the story. Without giving away anything, the story is gritty and engaging and the game is worth playing for that alone.

Some of the action parts will seem a little silly as you mow down countless enemies but generally the game is well paced and the story keeps you hooked and wanting more.

The game itself is short (it will take you around 5 or so hours to complete if you don't rush) but in this case that's not a bad thing, as any longer would just drag it out and negate the impact of the story.

That said, given the relatively short life span of the game, I recommend you pick it up on sale.

Overall Score:
7.5/10

The Good:Fantastic story line
The atmosphere is gritty and visceral
Combat is done and well and enjoyable if you don't take it too seriouslyThe Bad:
Apart from the story, there is nothing here to distinguish this from your average 3rd person shooterThe Ugly:
The price (given the game is over 3 years old) - pick it up on sale

reviewText:
A really good game with OK gameplay as in you go from cover to cover and you shoot the bad guys and throw grenades and stuff, however the ability to give your squad members commands such as attack, stun and heal the other squad mate is KINDA unique.

The real cream of the crop here is the story. It is pretty short though, you can complete it in about 5 - 7 hours on the normal difficulty. After replaying this game about 5 times to get every single achievement even the one for completing the game on FUBAR (which was brutal and almost made me commit a war crime on my computer) I can safely say that I understand the story of the game (at least that's what I say to look cool). I won't be revealing details about the story for people like Vikezor who don't want anything to be spoiled for them even though they may never even play this game in their lives, but what I WILL say is that it isn't your typical military shooter story about taking out a terrorist leader threatening to blow up Pluto or something. The story is pretty unique and left me questioning ''What happens next?''. The story makes you think about war and the attrocities people commit under speciffic circumstances. It also has multiple endings about 4 I think and a few descisions you have to make during the story. The soundtrack to this game is also amazing, it fits the story pretty well and makes me wanna replay it to be able to battle enemies while listening to some rocking tunes. Without going into the hostile spoiler lands I can't really say much more so I will cross the border into them for a few seconds to say this:

SPOLERS YO KIDS SPOILERS RIGHT HERE

The game left me wondering what happens to Walker after he leaves Dubai in that one ending where you shoot at Konrad in the mirror and don't kill the US soldiers that arrive to extract you. Questions like ''What's he gonna do now? Will the things he's seen and done haunt him forever? And did he even have any family to return to?'' popped into mind while watching Marty boy leave Dubai.

END OF THE SPOILERS KIDS

In general I personally think this game is amazing because of the story. However the developers have revealed that they won't be making a sequel or another game in the Spec Ops series for a while because as amazing as the game is it didn't make them a lot of money, not as much as they hoped for at least.

Final score: 578/603

P.S. Bailey shut the heck up.

This game follows a very rich storyline with a Fight Club ending that will blow your freaking mind.
A short campaign lasting approx 5 hours loaded with difficult co-op & multiplayer modes.

This game on normal difficulty can give you troubles. Play on suicide if you dare.

Only negative in this game is the cover system. While it works very well, when you're behind cover and you need to move quickly (a grenade has landed next to you), you will literally go exactly where you DO NOT want to go. This caused many very frustrating deaths & situations. Apart from this mishap, you will not be disappointed. Spec Ops The Line delivers very well with a rich storyline & many great atmospheric environments.

+ Atmospheric
+ Story Rich
+ Third Person (Done properly)
+ Short Campaign [COD Style] 15 Chapters lasting approx 10-20 minutes each.
+ Co-Op
+ Psychological Ending
+ A challenge
+ Intense
+ High Fast Paced Action
+ Execution System
+ Bullet Time

- Cover System (Although this does work well when taking cover at times)
- Heavy Armed enemies
- Bit too pricy for what you get


Only negative in this game is the cover system. While it works very well, when you're behind cover and you need to move quickly (a grenade has landed next to you), you will literally go exactly where you DO NOT want to go. This caused many very frustrating deaths & situations.
Apart from this mishap, you will not be disappointed.

Spec Ops The Line delivers very well with a rich storyline & Dubai perfectly served in post-apocalyptic conditions.

8.5/10

(Yes I played 7 chapters first straight up & then finished the last 8 chapters 2 years later after realising I was missing out on a great ending.)

reviewText:
Para análise em português, leia mais abaixo.

Spec Ops The Line - Review: Lost and Damned

Dubai. An oasis of technology and lust in the middle of desert. Magnificent buildings in a developed city. But nature is always more ruthless than our ability to oppose. Destroyed by intense sandstorms, a city in ruins. The 33rd Battalion of the American army is sent to town for a rescue and extraction operation of the survivors. And then, they disappear from the map.

You are Captain Martin Walker, leader of an elite team of Delta Force of the Army of the United States of America, leading his fellow Lieutenant Alphanso Adams, heavy gunner and Sergeant John Lugo, sniper. Sent to Dubai after a transmission captured after six months without contact, his mission is to locate, reunite and rescue possible survivors.

Beautiful scenarios, even among ruins. The opulence of Dubai can be seen in the ruins and in few places that remained intact. Even the desert, displays an exotic beauty that brings a melancholy tone to the game.

Spec Ops is not just a shooting game in third person. It is a psychological plot. Every dialogue, every action, every event in this journey shows you more than bullets flying. Dubai is alive. Dubai is at war. And war... war never changes. The horrors of war are not shown as simple digital polygons falling to the ground with AI off. You will really feel them. You will hesitate. You will have anger and and will be thrilled. And maybe you even cry. You'll be confused. Do not stop. Go straight. Reflect, try to understand. Do not come to this game to play. Come to this story to live it. And so, you will not regret it.

Gentlemen, welcome to Dubai.

My Personal Score                Fun:        9/10                Gameplay:        9/10                Ambientation:        9/10                History:        10/10                Replayability:        6/10                Multiplayer:        1/10
--

Spec Ops The Line - Análise: Perdidos e Condenados

Dubai. Um oásis de tecnologia e luxuria em pleno deserto. Construções magníficas em uma cidade extremamente desenvolvida. Mas a natureza, é sempre mais impiedosa do que nossa capacidade de nos opor. Destruída por intensas tempestades de areia, uma cidade em ruínas. O 33º batalhão do exército americano é enviado a cidade para uma operação de resgate e extração dos sobreviventes. E então, eles desaparecem do mapa.

Você é o Capitão Martin Walker, líder de uma equipe de elite da Força Delta do Exército dos Estados Unidos da América, liderando seus companheiros Tenente Alphanso Adams, artilheiro pesado e Sargento John Lugo, franco-atirador. Enviados a Dubai após uma transmissão ser captada depois de 6 meses sem contato, sua missão é localizar, reunir e resgatar possíveis sobreviventes.

Belos cenários, mesmo entre ruínas. A opulência de Dubai se destaca em traços que podem ser percebidos nas ruínas e em poucos lugares sobreviventes. Mesmo o deserto, exibe uma exótica beleza que traz um tom melancólico ao jogo.

Spec Ops não é apenas um jogo de tiro em terceira pessoa. É uma trama psicológica. Cada diálogo, cada ação, cada acontecimento nesta jornada te mostra mais do que balas voando. Dubai está viva. Dubai está em guerra. E a guerra... a guerra nunca muda. Os horrores da guerra não são mostrados como simples polígonos digitais caindo ao chão com IA desligada. Você realmente irá sentí-los. Você irá hesitar. Você terá raiva e se emocionará. E talvez, você até mesmo chore. Você ficará confuso. Não pare. Siga em frente. Reflita, procure compreender. Não venha a este jogo para jogar. Venha a esta história para vivê-la. E assim, você não irá se arrepender.

Senhores, bem-vindos a Dubai.

Minhas Notas Pessoais                Diversão:        9/10                Gameplay:        9/10                Ambientação:        9/10                História:        10/10                Rejogabilidade:        6/10                Multiplayer:        1/10

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a marvelous game. While the gameplay isn't revolutionary, the storytelling is the real gem here. Spec Ops does a great job revealing the fragile nature of humanity, and then smashes it like a cheap vodka bottle.

After playing through several missions, you'll slowly realize how messed up reality is. While you spend alot of your time dodging bullets, and the ever changing enviroment, you'll find the enemy trying to out manuver you.

Overall, I'd suggest playing this game. Even if you don't like the gameplay, the story is intriguing. If anything, it's an excellent game to see friend's reactions.

reviewText: Short, but satisfying game. Even after 4 years, the graphics look nice and the engine works well (no bugs encountered). What made me love this game is the soundtrack, playstyle (getting headshots 24/7), and the story, although the last one is a love-hate relationship, as it shows the somewhat real army life - gorey and brutal, rather than running around killing people (though you have that too, from time to time). Also, the cinematics are pretty amazing, especially towards the end of the game - destroying buildings whilst flying a helicopter - what more could you want? You're allowed to make multiple choices throughout the game, which affect your sanity. The only drawbacks for me are the 30 fps/720p cutscenes, and the length of the game (6 to 12 hours), but that can be justified by the quality of the game, and the multiple choice scenarios. Overall, it's a great and original TPS, definitely deserving more recognition. If you haven't played it, make sure you get it on a sale, it can go for dirt cheap, and it's definitely worth playing.

reviewText: You know, I would have already recommended this game on the basis that it's a well-disguised pushback against the insane military worship present not only in video games like Call of Duty and Battlefield 3, but in American culture in general. But it's also a pushback against American imperialism, military intervention, our actions towards the Middle East, war itself, and also the player for going along with the game, no matter how insane it gets. It's a thoroughly horrifying game and I'm frankly surprised to see that it even got published at all. And the genius of it is it's like Call of Duty mixed with Gears of War, so any teenage ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ can just get sucked into it and then made completely horrified. Get it for the kids at Christmas!

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is possibly the most riveting, most intriguing, most powerful shooter I have ever played. Whilst the gameplay mechanics are pretty traditional and bring little to the table, the story is fantastic. The Line is a linear game through and through but does a very good job of making the player feel responsible for the actions they carry out. Part of this is due to the illusions of choice that occasionally pop up through the game, allowing you to feel as though your decisions will make a difference. Multiple endings add a bit of spice to it as well. Without a doubt, Specs Ops: The Line is the best third-person shooter I've ever played that had me on the edge of my seat and constantly thinking about it when I wasn't playing it.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a game about morality and introspection. An action/adventure title which grips you with just above average game-play mechanics. Along side that, there is profound situational scenarios that forces an analytical and emotional side from you, with every decision. It may seem like you start as, just, another soldier given, just, another mission. Although, as you act in what seems to be an orderly manner, you begin to question the authenticity, or integrity of such orders. You begin to question because of the veracious nature of these orders. It becomes difficult and even, regretful, when you persist to just 'follow orders.'

It is a game which for the most part of the story, is confusing. Your distaste by all the violence you do as this character, I don't want to give any spoilers but there are some really deep philosophical questions that the game provokes from you, after these unfortunate situations. All that thought, accumulates into a severe confusion and doubt about where this is all going. Why so much pain? So much death?...Well, the ending holds a powerful question, the question is what will you do?

In regards to the game-play mechanics, they're inherently superficial and refined. This allows for the player to not completely focus on just the action, but the scenery, the sounds, the presentation of a doomed Dubai. There were many breathtaking scenes, in which I have numerous images for.

There is only one reason one should purchase this game, it is if you are looking for a intellectually provocative game. Take head tho, there is alot of filler action. Seemingly useless scenes of violence. Furthermore, I would like to add, that discussing such an issue, as this game does, with such a small script, was impressive. I hope the studio is working on the next of the series, maybe one that jumps further deep into the monstrous acts of war, and the repercussions of those wars.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a 2012 third-person shooter video game developed by Yager Development and published by 2K Games. It was released on 26 June 2012 in North America and 29 June 2012 internationally for Microsoft Windows, and the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 consoles.
n Spec Ops: The Line, the player controls Captain Martin Walker, who is sent into a post-catastrophe Dubai with an elite Delta Force team on a reconnaissance mission, where they find dead American soldiers. Upon the finding, Walker declares that the team's mission has changed, and that they will search Dubai for survivors

Spec Ops: does so many good things right, but falls short from a masterpiece. While the game is a brilliant set-piece of PTSD and the true horrors of war, it falls short as a game in whole. While the story, soundtrack, voice acting, visuals and overall quality is amazing, it's gameplay is just so generic and boring. Nothing new will be seen here, unfourtunately. The game is a third-person cover shooter game, with no originality. The cover system and gunplay are mediocre at best, and this is a real drawback from it being an amazing experience in all sectors. But, I really don't want to get too much into such details, it's just something you've played in a hundred other games, let's focus on what's so amazing about this underrated game.

The story. It may sounds like something trivial, because people have high standards these days, amazing gameplay, amazing graphics, amazing this amazing that, you get my point. This game is narative driven game, and that's it. Multiplayer is shallow and unstatisfying, but this isn't the point of Spec Ops. It's a game that sets one goal, and one goal only. To trully showcase the Horror of war. War is a gruesome experience that really scars the human mind, and while me and you won't probably fight in one, this game has a trully shocking way of showing us just how brutal things can get between the gunfire. It will surely have a last impact on you, it did on me at least. The game starts pretty standard, a turret section that's pretty bland and boring, nothing too over the top here. But once the game kick off, things start to get heated. We start in the shoes of Cpt. Martin Walker, voiced by Nolan North. The game starts off with you and your squad mates being sent to the new destroyed Dubai, to investigate and search for survivor, call for reinforcements and get back home. Those are your only orders, nothing more. But things get out of hand once Walker gives to order to  open fire on the enemy. This thing will become more relevant down the line, since this game has set out to question one simple thing, Who is the enemy?. And it will teach you that thing, once you complete it.

Being developed on the Unreal 3 Engine, the games shines mostly. Dubai is a super showcase of glowing sand, vibrant interiors and a feel of depth and complexity. But it's all just a shell to hide all of the horros that lay ahead of your journey to destruction. The game will soon present to you the brutal, and extremely graphic violence of when things get ouf of hand when people mentally breakdown and can't tell the difference between good or evil. It's amazing, especially since this game breaks once and for all the trope that all enemy's in video games must be shot down immediatly without question, and because they are different or russian/middle eastern. It's superb, to be honest.

In the end, since I could talk about this game for hours and hours, even though it's a short, but it's an intense ride, and filled with guilt. Never, ever I have felt such guild after playing a videogame. Like, really. Videogames that make you feel guilty? How is that? One might ask. Well, it's quite easy. This game does not reward you for shooting everyone in a 100km radius at the speed of Clint Eastwood, it will break you down as fast as the protagonists. It's amazing how well the story is crafter, considering at the end of the day, it makes you feel human, it makes you question so many things. Superb. Honestly, superb.

In case you don't want to hear all of my rumbling, I will list the things that I enjoyed and disliked about this game and give it a rating.

The good
Amazing story
Superb story
Breathtaking visuals
Retroactive enviroment
Unique setting
Incredible soundtrack/voice acting
Moral and emotionally heavy
The bad
Generic gameplay
Mediocre gunplay
Short lenght
Cookie cutter multiplayer
No replay value
The cover mechanics are a bit awkward

I give this game a 8/10 rating, thanks to so many good elements in it, falling short, unfortunately to such a generic gameplay. Amazing overall nonetheless, I highly recommend this game to everyone.

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line is the hidden gem of 2012. FTL would be my hidden gem
date: but after the whole massive Kickstarter success thing, it was obvious FTL was going to be good in my point of view. Honestly, I used to play Call of Duty and Halo. There. I said it. However, after Black Ops 1, I quit the Call of Duty series and haven't played any of the games since MW3. Halo Reach was the Halo that I played the most, and was the only Halo game (Halo 3 and Wars were good though) that I loved and played often. However, above all of these games, Spec Ops: The Line has one of the best stories of all time. It isn't like Call of Duty how you're fighting as some American soldier running around solo armed to the teeth with weapons and murdering terrorists and in the end saving the world." Not at all. Some people believe there are "good guys" and "bad guys
recommended:
but this game is solid evidence that war is just opinions being decided to the death, sometimes costing one's sanity, social health, emotional health, and physical health. Spec Ops: The Line proves war in no way is enjoyable, cool, or humorous in any kind of way. War is horrific, and this game is enough to prove that.

Graphics
The visuals are absolutely outstanding. The environments look beautiful, and the atmosphere is bright on the outside, but dark and horrific on the inside. The characters look amazing, and it's rare you can actually see the sweat of a character in the middle of combat. This game is able to do that. If I were to compare these visuals to The Last of Us, Spec Ops: The Line would win by a mile. These graphics are extremely realistic, but the only con to this is that the facial animations can look weird. For example, when Walker is talking to Lugo or Adams when it isn't a cutscene, it looks like he's gaping every time, like he's shocked at everything for some reason. During cutscenes though, Walker looks fine and doesn't gape like that when he speaks.

Gameplay
The gameplay is suprisingly the weak point to the game. Although this game is a shooter, Spec Ops is more for people who want a story based game, rather than a gameplay based one. The AI is suicidally bad and the difficulty spikes at times and the awful gunplay ruins it even more. My squadmates keep bumping into me and I die, one enemy shot 3 RPG rockets in a row without reloading for some reason (He had an RPG, I saw him with the weapon, I swear!) and the AI prefer running toward me like overconfident barbarians. However, the game understands the meaning of limited" unlike other games *cough* Call of Duty *cough* *cough* and makes ammo a bit more difficult to get
hoursPlayed:
so that's something few games did that aren't in the zombie survival genre.

Story
The story is the reason Spec Ops is highly praised. Like I said before

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a 2012 third-person shooter video game developed by Yager Development and published by 2K Games. It was released on 26 June 2012 in North America and 29 June 2012 internationally for Microsoft Windows, and the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 consoles.
n Spec Ops: The Line, the player controls Captain Martin Walker, who is sent into a post-catastrophe Dubai with an elite Delta Force team on a reconnaissance mission, where they find dead American soldiers. Upon the finding, Walker declares that the team's mission has changed, and that they will search Dubai for survivors

Spec Ops: does so many good things right, but falls short from a masterpiece. While the game is a brilliant set-piece of PTSD and the true horrors of war, it falls short as a game in whole. While the story, soundtrack, voice acting, visuals and overall quality is amazing, it's gameplay is just so generic and boring. Nothing new will be seen here, unfourtunately. The game is a third-person cover shooter game, with no originality. The cover system and gunplay are mediocre at best, and this is a real drawback from it being an amazing experience in all sectors. But, I really don't want to get too much into such details, it's just something you've played in a hundred other games, let's focus on what's so amazing about this underrated game.

The story. It may sounds like something trivial, because people have high standards these days, amazing gameplay, amazing graphics, amazing this amazing that, you get my point. This game is narative driven game, and that's it. Multiplayer is shallow and unstatisfying, but this isn't the point of Spec Ops. It's a game that sets one goal, and one goal only. To trully showcase the Horror of war. War is a gruesome experience that really scars the human mind, and while me and you won't probably fight in one, this game has a trully shocking way of showing us just how brutal things can get between the gunfire. It will surely have a last impact on you, it did on me at least. The game starts pretty standard, a turret section that's pretty bland and boring, nothing too over the top here. But once the game kick off, things start to get heated. We start in the shoes of Cpt. Martin Walker, voiced by Nolan North. The game starts off with you and your squad mates being sent to the new destroyed Dubai, to investigate and search for survivor, call for reinforcements and get back home. Those are your only orders, nothing more. But things get out of hand once Walker gives to order to  open fire on the enemy. This thing will become more relevant down the line, since this game has set out to question one simple thing, Who is the enemy?. And it will teach you that thing, once you complete it.

Being developed on the Unreal 3 Engine, the games shines mostly. Dubai is a super showcase of glowing sand, vibrant interiors and a feel of depth and complexity. But it's all just a shell to hide all of the horros that lay ahead of your journey to destruction. The game will soon present to you the brutal, and extremely graphic violence of when things get ouf of hand when people mentally breakdown and can't tell the difference between good or evil. It's amazing, especially since this game breaks once and for all the trope that all enemy's in video games must be shot down immediatly without question, and because they are different or russian/middle eastern. It's superb, to be honest.

In the end, since I could talk about this game for hours and hours, even though it's a short, but it's an intense ride, and filled with guilt. Never, ever I have felt such guild after playing a videogame. Like, really. Videogames that make you feel guilty? How is that? One might ask. Well, it's quite easy. This game does not reward you for shooting everyone in a 100km radius at the speed of Clint Eastwood, it will break you down as fast as the protagonists. It's amazing how well the story is crafter, considering at the end of the day, it makes you feel human, it makes you question so many things. Superb. Honestly, superb.

In case you don't want to hear all of my rumbling, I will list the things that I enjoyed and disliked about this game and give it a rating.

The good
Amazing story
Superb story
Breathtaking visuals
Retroactive enviroment
Unique setting
Incredible soundtrack/voice acting
Moral and emotionally heavy
The bad
Generic gameplay
Mediocre gunplay
Short lenght
Cookie cutter multiplayer
No replay value
The cover mechanics are a bit awkward

I give this game a 8/10 rating, thanks to so many good elements in it, falling short, unfortunately to such a generic gameplay. Amazing overall nonetheless, I highly recommend this game to everyone.

reviewText:
Game reminds me a LOT of Binary Domain; another third-person shooter (wall humping and military lingo included) with average gameplay and a fantastic plot. I'm not gonna dwell too long on the game mechanics. It's typical stuff with nothing impressive or worth mentioning. This is one of those games that's more about everything BESIDES the gameplay, which says more about the writing than anything negative about the gameplay. I will only complain about one thing: the game has mechanics that are severely underused. Specifically, silencers, which would let you sneak around getting kills if the game dedicated more to that aspect.

Anyway, the plot is fantastic, and its SPECTACULAR how it handles good and evil. Ultimately, the paradigm (big word alert) is meaningless here; everyone has their motives and reasons for doing what they do. The game weaves a complex narrative that ultimately pins you as neither a 'good guy' nor a 'bad guy'; you are merely someone doing what he believes is right. Emphasis on ''believes'' because all supposedly moral actions in this game are subject to questioning.

I love the title for that alone. I love when villains are given motives and reasons for their actions other than ''I am bad raawr come get me in my evil evil castle''. They took it a step further by making the protagonist's morality ambiguous as well, and you get to shape some of it along the way. There are some segments where you have to make choices, and the writing makes it so that each option in these segments is a valid choice. Moral choices in games tend to boil down to ''kill grandma; don't kill grandma'', so there's never really any critical thinking involved; developers take note, this game does it right.

I could go on and on about how the pacing is done very well and how I love the narrative. But I'll end on a few unrelated notes:

-For a console game this ♥♥♥♥ looks great. This dude's bald head is so...so bald.
-The menu changes as you play the title, which is a cool touch. It's little things like that that give a title some flavor.
-The game is loosely based on an old novel from the 19th century. So, like Binary Domain, it isn't exactly original.
-You might not get sound in pre-rendered cut-scenes. It's a bug having to do with NVIDIA cards or some ♥♥♥♥. Anyway, the fix is insanely simple and there's a thread on the forums about it. Or you could watch pre-rendered stuff on youtube.

The game's pretty short and straight-forward. I love strong narratives so I can't recommend this enough. And while you're at it, pick up Binary Domain as well.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a prime example of ho-hum gameplay, but a powerful and engaging story. This game will make you feel like a monster at the end. You'll see the destruction you caused, the violence you inflicted on people, and the deterioration of your soldier's mind.

The gameplay in Spec Ops is really nothing special. It's a Gears of War-type shooter. You're in third person, you shoot enemies, you hide behind cover, you make things go boom, so and so forth. Playing a demo of this game will not do you justice. Sampling a portion of this full course will either make you crave more and throw it away. If it needs to be experienced, it needs to be experienced in it's entirety. Through out the 14 chapters, the gameplay stayed mainly consistent, with turret sections and tons of cover shooting. It's simple, and can get repetitive very quickly. There's nothing special about this gameplay. Some scripted sequences are definitely pretty cool, but other than that, you're going to be shooting and hiding behind cover for most of the time.

Spec Ops is all about story, though. You might think that story has no impact on a generic military shooter like this, but you would be wrong. The story in this game is incredible; it's like a good book you can't put down. It's very well written, and in the end, you'll transform into a hurly, burly tough man into a hollow shell of a human being.

I highly recommend playing this game. First time I played this, I felt that it was just a simple third person shooter with nothing to offer. After friends told me about it further, I tried it again and realized it was about the story. I was super impressed with this game. If you do choose to play it, make sure you don't look up any info of the story on the internet, it will give stuff away. You'll want to experience it for yourself.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a really immersive game that will put you in a tough position in different moments of the game, putting your moral on a test.

Your decisions do have an effect on what happens next, some will be more noticeable though. If you like shooters, and like them on a third-person view, this game is for you, as it is full of action, it will make you think twice before taking any decision, and will keep you from moving anywhere else until you reach the end of the game.

This game became one of my all-time favorite games within my first playthrough, and I'm sure it will have the same effect for every third-person shooter enthusiast out there!

For a full review with images and so on, feel free to check it out here: http://johnheatz.com/2013/06/09/spec-ops-the-line-review/
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This could be just another war shooter, among so many others, but don't be fooled by its look. While in other war franchises where you take place as a cold-blooded soldier, used to face death in all its ways, this game makes you actually feel what is like to be fighting a war, not only physically, but also mentally.

The main character, as the game progresses, becomes more and more injured, and his mind, at a moment, starts to twist and be filled with guilt, which causes him to have hallucinations that will affect the behavior of you and your team, from professional soldiers, to out-of-control psychotics, thus affecting gameplay.

As of the mechanics, it follows the classic formula for third person shooters: precision aiming, cover system, etc. Being squad based, it gives lots of emphasis on colaboration within your team, and to survive you must work together with your  teammates. Ammo is very scarce, as you are often required to scavenge weapons from fallen enemies. Enemies comes in varied forms, from light soldiers to heavy-armored juggernauts.

With a good plot, and a good concept for a war game, give it a try, as you won't find such a realistic approach in another game.

It's worth every penny.

reviewText:
It's hard to recommend this game. It's hard to enjoy it and even harder to like it. Why the thumbs up then? Because it's bad for all the right reasons. Let me elaborate:

MILD SPOILERS AHEAD!

The game starts as a typical military shooter but as you go about shooting bad guys" things get F.U.B.A.R. real fast. Your character is forced to commit a series of war atrocities
date: each worse than the last one. The gameplay in between is dull and repetitive but this is a very conscious design decision on the developer's part. While you get bored your mind wanders and you can't help but think about what your character has done. As you try to rationalize his actions you go through some of the same psychological changes that shape his mind during the game. These changes are further pointed out by the exceptionally good voice acting.\n\nThis game leads you on at first
hoursPlayed: video-game/action-movie inspired expectations. And then it shows you what killing hundreds of people in a single day actually does to a person's mind. It gets in your head and hammers the point home by breaking the fourth wall and messing with you
voteText: goading you to simply stop playing. You're not supposed to have fun while playing this and the game itself is perfectly aware of that. If you do decide to play it to the bitter end it will simply leave you feeling drained and dirty.\n\nSpec Ops fails as a game on purpose to prove a point and teach you a lesson. I can't help but respect that."

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line - War really is Hell.

[WARNING:SPOILERS - No, seriously, reading this entire review will likely ruin the impact of some key moments in this game]

War is hell. We've all heard this particular turn of phrase. Hell, for some of us, we've heard it so many times it's lost all meaning. For people who don't believe in hell, what's it supposed to mean in the first place? For those of us who've never been to war, what do we have to compare it to? What frame of reference would I have, aside from that vaguely haunted look when my dad would politely decline to discuss his time in Vietnam, or how he prefers not to watch movies based on real wars.

I think the closest thing I've seen yet, at least for the most part, has come as quite a surprise. I have a habit of picking up Call of Duty games because I played the first one way back in the dusty days of the early 'naughties when they had intense single-player campaigns and the multiplayer was decent but not the main focus. They were really trying to show you how hard it was being a soldier at first. Nowadays, it's 'MERICA FK YEAH except for the scenes with the charmingly amoral SAS soldiers. Don't get me wrong, Captain Price is a total badass, but a believable character he's not.

Spec Ops: The Line is not the first in its series, but it's the first I played. I'd never heard of the series before this one, and wouldn't have picked it up if not for the good words of two critics I respect, a well-done demo on Steam, and Amazon having a summer sale of 50% off on a game only released maybe a month prior with a key redeemable on Steam.

To get the technical aspects out of the way, because those will surely not be the focus, the gameplay does not carry this one at all. I can't imagine people will be flocking to the multiplayer, as the land of chest-high walls makes an appearance here, along with his best friend, Mister Cover-Based-Shooting. It's average gameplay at best. I hesitate to say the Call of Duty franchise does it better, but that's not where it shines.

I was truly taken aback by the story. I went in expecting a gung-ho John Rambo-style, check your brain at the door experience, with the ever-popular Delta Force as the main characters. That was not what was delivered. The game starts out, innocently enough, as you're tasked to investigate a distress call from a military commander of a unit, the 33rd, that stayed behind after Dubai was swallowed by massive sandstorm with people still living in the city. What follows is several episodes of standard shoot-em-up combat with a surprisingly hostile US Army force. Just as you get over questioning why these supposed friendlies are firing on you and you start to get into the rhythm of counter-attacking, the game drops a huge moral choice in your lap.

You encounter two men suspended from a bridge. You're told that one man, a civilian, was stealing water to help his family. The other, a soldier, was in the process of apprehending the man and used excessive force, resulting in the death of the man's family. You're then advised, by the very man who sent the distress call, to shoot one of them. You cannot simply refuse, as there are four snipers with their weapons trained on you from behind cover. Refuse, as I did, and you are forced to take the snipers out, resulting in the two men both dying in the exchange.

OK you say. That's not too bad. A play on a common theme. It gets worse. At one point, the 33rd launch a white phosphorous mortar strike on a group of insurgents sponsored by the CIA that you're only meters away from.

White Phosphorous, or as it's colloquially known as Willy Pete, has valid uses. It burns obscenely bright, as far as illumination, and can produce a solid smokescreen for obscuring movement. Loaded into a mortar, as in here, and almost nothing better defines Death From Above." An airburst of WP burns and poisons
date: and can cause death from multiple organ failure if you don't die from shock first. The few times it's been used in combat have been wildly controversial to say the least
recommended: and it's been addressed under Chemical Warfare conventions.\n\nYou have to walk through the burning and dying remains to reach your next destination. This comes back to haunt you later as you reach the outskirts of a 33rd outpost that simply could not be breached on foot

reviewText:
It's a relatively short game. You can finish it pretty quickly. It's a beautiful game. The graphics are excellent, especially the environmental effects. It's got some good squad-support mechanics, a bit of RTS mixed in when it comes to combat.

Where it really stands out is the story. This is no CoD shoot-em-up against the russian/korean/middle eastern/chinese terrorists who pose a threat to MURRICA and the good guys have to go blast 'em with MUH FREEDOMS until they're all dead and a soaring bald eagle screams overhead just before the credits.

No, this game takes a much more realistic approach with a small squad in unfamiliar territory as you watch the effects of combat and decision-making on their mental state and relationships.

Of course, it's a game, so it is a dramatization. But it's an excellent game. Your choices have an effect. It wasn't made so you could choke on McDonald's while singing the Star-Spangled Banner. It was made to show that on the inside, there is no glory in war.

reviewText:
This is a first person shooter
and you can skip the videos and ingore the story.
But this game is about the story.
The shooting mechanism is good, the cover system is very good, the weapons are fun to shoot with. The game would be a good shooter on its own.
But the game shines when it comes to the story. Sometimes you have to make choices. I do not know the differences between the choices or if there are totally different stories depending on the choices.
But I do know that I really was sad when my choices turned the events in certain ways.
This is not a funny game. It is a sad game for adults.

I liked the story, the graphics, the sound, the handling of the character, the weapons, nearly all of it.
I disliked that certain situations are so much harder than the rest of the game.

If you like shooters where you have to use cover to be able to survive, if you like a good story then you should like this game too.

It is not very long, it took me 6 hours on normal difficulty. But this game is really good.
I think it is only for persons > 20 years interesting, but I might be wrong there. Don't know.

Get it, play it and live with your choices.

reviewText:
At first glance Spec Ops: The Line seems like an average modern military third-person shooter with a cover system. And that assessment is largely correct. It feels and plays a lot like Call of Duty and Battlefield singleplayer campaigns, mainly due to its action-movie style setpieces. This despite it being a third-person cover shooter.

Even so Spec Ops: The Line is one of the better singleplayer shooters you can pick up today. It's not a standout in visuals, bombastic action scenes, shooting mechanics, or multiplayer options. Rather it sets itself apart due to the atmosphere set in the singleplayer story, the gruesome choices you're forced to make, the cruel twists as the story moves along, and some horrific scenes of brutality.

You get to make only a few choices during the campaign and Spec Ops' environments are linear throughout. But those choices you do get to make have an impact - not so much on the game's story as on you as a person due to their immediate effects. Additionally the game comes with several different endings. There's no need to replay the game for them, because the decision that determines which ending you get is made in the final mission, which is both sad yet convenient.

At 6-7 hours the game never overstays its welcome. Likewise it's never overly challenging, and that's on Hard (Suicide Mission) difficulty. That short, mostly-linear campaign holds up surprisingly well in a second playthrough. Finding all the nuances that point to the game's final twists further enhances the experience.

Conclusion / TLDR
Spec Ops is not a fun game. But it's one hell of an experience for those who can handle a bit of grimdarkness in their third-person shooting. Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
I don't review games often but this one really smacks you in the face. When you watch a movie and you're still thinking about it days later, you know you've seen something special. I am having that same feeling with this game.

I am not a big shooter player so I won't comment in detail on the gameplay mechanics or the difficulty, I found them both great, but the story and the artwork was incredible. I found myself rationalising the protagonist's choices as if they were my own. Even as events started to spiral out of control, I found myself trying to think about what I would do if it were my boots in the sand. I couldn't ever question Walker's decisions because they were always based on a truth he had compiled from an incomplete understanding of the situation, which was something I shared with him.

It's a three dimensional look at war, imaged in breathtaking scenes and with commendable voice-acting. Oftentimes, war is not as we traditionally define it. Decisions are not always based on what is good or bad, heroic or cowardly. They are often driven by interpretation of orders and gut-feel. And when dreadful things happen, do we really fully appreciate the toll on those that felt they had to pull the trigger, squinting though the fog of war?

This is a visceral and engaging experience which I highly recommend to gamers looking for something a bit different.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line, set in the desert city of Dubai, is an Unreal Engine-based military 3rd person shooter that surely doesn't revolutionize its genre, but certainly stands out because of its mature, intense and moral-conflicting story and its great voice acting and writing.

The game doesn't focus on the usual glorifying AMERICA, F* YEAH crap where you blow up stuff and ride into the sunset. It shows you the dark side of war and confronts you with moral choices that will get people killed, no matter how you decide - and you will see the results of your choices, laying dead in front of you.

The playtime for the campaign is around 7 hours. The game also features a multiplayer which, unfortunately, is pretty much dead. Additionally, there is a co-op mode that lets you team up with a buddy and fight your way through 4 unique missions.

Spec Ops: The Line isn't a game with a happy ending and it certainly won't make you feel comfortable, but that's what makes this game so special and rare.

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line is a solid 3rd person shooter that focuses on the horrors of war. It's kind of like Apocalypse Now!" with Dubai as the setting but that comparison is giving it a little too much credit.  It's more like an ultraviolent summer blockbuster war movie. The story and dialogue come off hamfisted and silly at times. The voice acting is decent for the most part and the sound design is good.\n\nI would've liked the guns to be louder and bullet snaps would be great for immersion. The shooting mechanics are satisfying and the intensity of the combat is what kept me coming back to 100% this game. It's no "Red Orchestra" immersion wise
date: but I think it illustrates the horrors of war well in some ways. Enemies collapse and some suffer while clutching wounds or crawl away. They cough and whimper as blood pools around them. One thing they never do is surrender
recommended: which is an annoying trope of modern shooters. At least there are unarmed civilians on some levels
hoursPlayed: which goes against convention. The game also forces you into some bad situations with civilians which is a great way to show the ugliness of war.\n\nThe game looks fantastic
voteText: even years later and it's surreal to see Dubai turned into a wartorn blood soaked ruin. Every firefight is fun and challenging if played on the harder difficulty levels. It would've been nice to have stealth be more viable. It's also a little funny that a 3 man squad kills off thousands of enemies. I know it's supposed to be somewhat of a satire on the modern military shooter but I would've rather had "Rainbow Six" style squad selection/commands and losses than 2 invulnerable baby sitters. I hope more games try to execute a "military shooter gone horror" vibe. I really like that the game is a train wreck of bad events and it tries to make you feel responsible and bad for it
