reviewerDisplayName: The Hulk Hogan of Slamming Muff
reviewText:
I'd class myself as a bit of a pessimist about raving reviews that give 10/10 saying things like ' the most electrifying game since x' etc these days, as there are very few honest reviews around as they've either been paid for by the developers, or it's people kissing major ♥♥♥ so they can be looked upon favourably by developers in the future.

I picked this up last year on sale for around £4.00 as I was looking for something a bit different to your COD's and Battlefield's in terms of a singleplayer story driven FPS and actually, was quite surprised at the level of detail and immersiveness it offers.

You play the leader of a small squad tasked with trying to find a general believed to still be alive somewhere in a ravaged Dubai. Pretty soon ♥♥♥♥ (mixed with an unfeasibly large amount of sand) hits the fan, and being such a badass your character is increasingly more determined to find out wth is going on.

As the story progresses you are faced with some plot changing ultimatums which will have an impact later on, the more you get to these stages of the game the more you are drawn into this world and the story itself.

If you can set the detail level and textures to max on your PC, then i strongly advise to do so. So many times i'd completely forget about the objective and just stop and look around in awe at the strange mix of a half destroyed metropolis, really quite impressive considering it was released a few years back.

Difficulty is actually quite challenging and can be brutal in some places, it's a fairly short game but dying so many time got a bit more longetivity out of it. Both your squad AI and enemy AI are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in places but it can be forgiven for the times that your tactics work like clockwork, hit and miss.

Even i'm getting bored of this review now, so all I will say is that if you're into challenging immersive games, with ultimatums, well written story and a bit more level of tactical awareness needed than a bog standard FPS, then pick this up in the sale and you'll be glad you did.

Oh yeah, and don't buy it if you're easily grossed out or offended - aka: a massive crybaby

reviewText:
Ever wanted a game which Murica ♥♥♥♥ yeah! is not the winner?
Get Spec ops: The Line.
Ever wanted a game which showed you the effects of war on yourself and others?
Get Spec ops: The Line.
Ever wanted a game which not only got you immersed in the game world, but also got you attached to the characters?
Get Spec ops: The Line.

This should not be classed as a game, but more an interactive work of art. It tells a story of a squad of American soldiers fighting their way through Dubai to try and free the citizens from the evil John Konrad. The game portrays the effects that PTSD has on soldiers and how a simple rescue mission can turn into a mass graveyard.

This game is not FUN" it is a serious story-based game which would be best played over a weekend as it can be beaten in roughly 8-9 hours.

Final thoughts:
This game is amazing and you should buy it once on sale because it is a short story

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line is a solid 3rd person shooter that focuses on the horrors of war. It's kind of like Apocalypse Now!" with Dubai as the setting but that comparison is giving it a little too much credit.  It's more like an ultraviolent summer blockbuster war movie. The story and dialogue come off hamfisted and silly at times. The voice acting is decent for the most part and the sound design is good.\n\nI would've liked the guns to be louder and bullet snaps would be great for immersion. The shooting mechanics are satisfying and the intensity of the combat is what kept me coming back to 100% this game. It's no "Red Orchestra" immersion wise
date: but I think it illustrates the horrors of war well in some ways. Enemies collapse and some suffer while clutching wounds or crawl away. They cough and whimper as blood pools around them. One thing they never do is surrender
recommended: which is an annoying trope of modern shooters. At least there are unarmed civilians on some levels
hoursPlayed: which goes against convention. The game also forces you into some bad situations with civilians which is a great way to show the ugliness of war.\n\nThe game looks fantastic
voteText: even years later and it's surreal to see Dubai turned into a wartorn blood soaked ruin. Every firefight is fun and challenging if played on the harder difficulty levels. It would've been nice to have stealth be more viable. It's also a little funny that a 3 man squad kills off thousands of enemies. I know it's supposed to be somewhat of a satire on the modern military shooter but I would've rather had "Rainbow Six" style squad selection/commands and losses than 2 invulnerable baby sitters. I hope more games try to execute a "military shooter gone horror" vibe. I really like that the game is a train wreck of bad events and it tries to make you feel responsible and bad for it
helpfulPercent: kind of like the Kane & Lynch series. It was just a little too hamfisted
votesHelpful: on rails and "gamey" for that feeling to hit me
votesTotal: but I enjoyed the horrific descent into madness nonetheless. If you are looking for a solid 3rd person shooter with an intense atmosphere
votesFunny: definitely grab this game.\n\n7/10"

reviewText:
This is hands-down one of the most emotionally engaging and impactful games I have ever played. What starts out as your run-of-the-mill third-person military shooter, quickly turns into a psychological and unique story unseen in modern gaming. The developers did an incredible job of truly making you feel the weight and consequences of the decisions you've made in not just this game, but every game you've played previously.

I personally do not enjoy shooters; this is precisely why I loved this game so much. It is not only addictive and engaging, but it's a smart and expertly crafted critique of the very genre it represents. Nolan North's performance is extremely impressive, even given his pedigree.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough - if you want to experience something unique and memorable, you need to play this game. I finished it in one sitting it was so addicting.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is set in a war torn Dubai in the aftermath of an unprecedented sandstorm that left the city engulfed in sand. You take up the role of Captain Martin Walker, leader of a Delta team alongside Lieutenant Adams and Sergeant Lugo. Together, you've been sent to Dubai after a strange radio transmission was reported and your objective is to search for any remaining survivors. Dubai, (meant to be completely uninhabited after the sandstorm) is discovered to home many civillians and the group known as the 33rd. As the story progresses, you discover that the 33rd are not who they were thought to be and with that, you're forced to go through many different moral choices to help decide the fate of Dubai and your squad. By the end of the game though, everything isn't what it seems and you discover who the true enemy really is and it will leave you wanting more.

TL;DR Edition:

Pros:
+Shooting mechanics are fun and simple to use
+Squad members actually help out in fights, when compared to other games
+Amazing Story
+Had to Google what the ending meant

Cons:
-Most decisions decided in the game doesn't really affect the ending
-Once you die, you cannot be revived, unlike your squad members

5/5 - One of greatest story's I've witnessed in a game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
At first glance Spec Ops: The Line seems like an average modern military third-person shooter with a cover system. And that assessment is largely correct. It feels and plays a lot like Call of Duty and Battlefield singleplayer campaigns, mainly due to its action-movie style setpieces. This despite it being a third-person cover shooter.

Even so Spec Ops: The Line is one of the better singleplayer shooters you can pick up today. It's not a standout in visuals, bombastic action scenes, shooting mechanics, or multiplayer options. Rather it sets itself apart due to the atmosphere set in the singleplayer story, the gruesome choices you're forced to make, the cruel twists as the story moves along, and some horrific scenes of brutality.

You get to make only a few choices during the campaign and Spec Ops' environments are linear throughout. But those choices you do get to make have an impact - not so much on the game's story as on you as a person due to their immediate effects. Additionally the game comes with several different endings. There's no need to replay the game for them, because the decision that determines which ending you get is made in the final mission, which is both sad yet convenient.

At 6-7 hours the game never overstays its welcome. Likewise it's never overly challenging, and that's on Hard (Suicide Mission) difficulty. That short, mostly-linear campaign holds up surprisingly well in a second playthrough. Finding all the nuances that point to the game's final twists further enhances the experience.

Conclusion / TLDR
Spec Ops is not a fun game. But it's one hell of an experience for those who can handle a bit of grimdarkness in their third-person shooting. Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
I don't review games often but this one really smacks you in the face. When you watch a movie and you're still thinking about it days later, you know you've seen something special. I am having that same feeling with this game.

I am not a big shooter player so I won't comment in detail on the gameplay mechanics or the difficulty, I found them both great, but the story and the artwork was incredible. I found myself rationalising the protagonist's choices as if they were my own. Even as events started to spiral out of control, I found myself trying to think about what I would do if it were my boots in the sand. I couldn't ever question Walker's decisions because they were always based on a truth he had compiled from an incomplete understanding of the situation, which was something I shared with him.

It's a three dimensional look at war, imaged in breathtaking scenes and with commendable voice-acting. Oftentimes, war is not as we traditionally define it. Decisions are not always based on what is good or bad, heroic or cowardly. They are often driven by interpretation of orders and gut-feel. And when dreadful things happen, do we really fully appreciate the toll on those that felt they had to pull the trigger, squinting though the fog of war?

This is a visceral and engaging experience which I highly recommend to gamers looking for something a bit different.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line, set in the desert city of Dubai, is an Unreal Engine-based military 3rd person shooter that surely doesn't revolutionize its genre, but certainly stands out because of its mature, intense and moral-conflicting story and its great voice acting and writing.

The game doesn't focus on the usual glorifying AMERICA, F* YEAH crap where you blow up stuff and ride into the sunset. It shows you the dark side of war and confronts you with moral choices that will get people killed, no matter how you decide - and you will see the results of your choices, laying dead in front of you.

The playtime for the campaign is around 7 hours. The game also features a multiplayer which, unfortunately, is pretty much dead. Additionally, there is a co-op mode that lets you team up with a buddy and fight your way through 4 unique missions.

Spec Ops: The Line isn't a game with a happy ending and it certainly won't make you feel comfortable, but that's what makes this game so special and rare.

reviewText:
Specs Ops the Line is so much more than just a tactical shooter: it's a wonderful experience.

You will find yourself in emotional situations, taking imposible decisions, regreting them every step of the way. This game is so complex it feels like a Nolan's movie at times, it even messes with you in the loading screens.

The graphics are very committed to the desert feel but still manages to take your breath away at times.

The music is just amazing, ranging from Hard Rock to Motown and you may feel not all this songs are fitting to a shooting game, but they are to the emotional feeling of it, which is the game's strongest point.

One of the only downsides is how the difficulty scalates, I was so mindblown by this game I decided to replay it in the FUBAR difficulty, which is the hardest possible, it gets you thinking outside the box most of the time, looking for different ways to achive your objective, picking your shots carefully, but sadly at times it's just ridiculously hard with unskippable instadeath scenes that you will replay DOZENS of times to get through by sheer luck, and it feels like the game is trying to be longer in a really cheap way.

Other than that this game is a jewel that deserves to be appreciated.
I am yet to try the coop mode, will update this review when I do.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In the end I really enjoyed this game.  The story is amazing, but it took about two hours of play before it actually got interesting.  It has a really slow generic start and I almost gave up on it, but I'm glad I didn't.  The slow start actually helps build the characters and helps with the pay off at the end.  The gameplay is a pretty straight forward cover shooter.  Really nothing new or interesting here.  It is well done, but again, nothing new.

Pros:
-Awesome story
-Really good character progression, seeing the main character fall from grace is an amazing journey.
-Nice set pieces and overall the visuals are decent.
-Perfect length.  At about 6hrs it was just right.
-I absolutley love that the characters all get more and more beat up and battered visually, more games should do this.
-I also love that they had different voice clips as the game progressed where the characters sound more worn out and tired.  Amazing!  More games again need to do this!
-Excellent voice acting.  Nolan North takes the lead and is awesome as usual, but all the other voice actors are amazing!

Cons:
-Slow start could potentially keep people from playing through the whole game.
-Nothing new or interesting about the gameplay, a standard cover shooter.
-I wish they had used the sand storms more often.  I think it only happens two or three times.

Overall a good game with an amazing story.  I wish more games had stories that were as good as this one.  I ended up putting it on Easy mode half way through so I could just play through the story and enjoy the game.  In fact, I actually would recommend playing it on easy as medium (or whatever they call it) was kind of all over the place.  Sometimes it would be perfect, other times it would be really hard.

reviewText: A masterpiece, Spec Ops: The Line is no ordinary third person shooter; it is about the human condition and of morality that questions what it really means to be a soldier. This game is up there with and comparable to The Last of Us as both titles really do explore the true journey into the darkness of ourselves. Gameplay-wise is also great with easy controls, fun cover base combat that allows teammate commands, a good variety of weapons and enemies to takedown. I highly recommend that you watch Francis Ford Coppola's 1979 classic Apocalypse Now (preferably the Redux edition) before you play Spec Ops which has very similar themes to the film for the ultimate Heart of Darkness experience.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a seemingly average game at first glance -- linear third person shooter with a selection of current-gen guns that features a near-invincible protagonist killing everything that moves.

What's driving the difference between the metacritic score and the rave reviews is that this game has a really entertaining storyline -- it's an homage to Heart of Darkness / Apocalypse Now. The antagonist is even named Conrad. It tries to shine perspective on the choices that you make as a soldier to survive, but if you just want to gun everyone down like I do, the game is still rewarding for that.

The graphics are alright, although the sepia tone gets tiring after a while. The sound and music are good.

reviewText:
At first glance Spec Ops: The Line seems like an average modern military third-person shooter with a cover system. And that assessment is largely correct. It feels and plays a lot like Call of Duty and Battlefield singleplayer campaigns, mainly due to its action-movie style setpieces. This despite it being a third-person cover shooter.

Even so Spec Ops: The Line is one of the better singleplayer shooters you can pick up today. It's not a standout in visuals, bombastic action scenes, shooting mechanics, or multiplayer options. Rather it sets itself apart due to the atmosphere set in the singleplayer story, the gruesome choices you're forced to make, the cruel twists as the story moves along, and some horrific scenes of brutality.

You get to make only a few choices during the campaign and Spec Ops' environments are linear throughout. But those choices you do get to make have an impact - not so much on the game's story as on you as a person due to their immediate effects. Additionally the game comes with several different endings. There's no need to replay the game for them, because the decision that determines which ending you get is made in the final mission, which is both sad yet convenient.

At 6-7 hours the game never overstays its welcome. Likewise it's never overly challenging, and that's on Hard (Suicide Mission) difficulty. That short, mostly-linear campaign holds up surprisingly well in a second playthrough. Finding all the nuances that point to the game's final twists further enhances the experience.

Conclusion / TLDR
Spec Ops is not a fun game. But it's one hell of an experience for those who can handle a bit of grimdarkness in their third-person shooting. Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line, set in the desert city of Dubai, is an Unreal Engine-based military 3rd person shooter that surely doesn't revolutionize its genre, but certainly stands out because of its mature, intense and moral-conflicting story and its great voice acting and writing.

The game doesn't focus on the usual glorifying AMERICA, F* YEAH crap where you blow up stuff and ride into the sunset. It shows you the dark side of war and confronts you with moral choices that will get people killed, no matter how you decide - and you will see the results of your choices, laying dead in front of you.

The playtime for the campaign is around 7 hours. The game also features a multiplayer which, unfortunately, is pretty much dead. Additionally, there is a co-op mode that lets you team up with a buddy and fight your way through 4 unique missions.

Spec Ops: The Line isn't a game with a happy ending and it certainly won't make you feel comfortable, but that's what makes this game so special and rare.

reviewText: This is one of those great games that you just have to sit back and absorb what's happened when you've completed it (which you will do very quickly). While it's safe to say that this doesn't have the longest campaign ever, just over 6 hours, it is an extremely intense experience. Spec Ops The Line will make you think about the complexities of war and how different sides can percieve each other. This all while having players make the choices themselves so that there is an actual feeling of guilt or accountability gives it a strong character and creates an unforgetable experience. 10/10

reviewText:
Specs Ops the Line is so much more than just a tactical shooter: it's a wonderful experience.

You will find yourself in emotional situations, taking imposible decisions, regreting them every step of the way. This game is so complex it feels like a Nolan's movie at times, it even messes with you in the loading screens.

The graphics are very committed to the desert feel but still manages to take your breath away at times.

The music is just amazing, ranging from Hard Rock to Motown and you may feel not all this songs are fitting to a shooting game, but they are to the emotional feeling of it, which is the game's strongest point.

One of the only downsides is how the difficulty scalates, I was so mindblown by this game I decided to replay it in the FUBAR difficulty, which is the hardest possible, it gets you thinking outside the box most of the time, looking for different ways to achive your objective, picking your shots carefully, but sadly at times it's just ridiculously hard with unskippable instadeath scenes that you will replay DOZENS of times to get through by sheer luck, and it feels like the game is trying to be longer in a really cheap way.

Other than that this game is a jewel that deserves to be appreciated.
I am yet to try the coop mode, will update this review when I do.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In the end I really enjoyed this game.  The story is amazing, but it took about two hours of play before it actually got interesting.  It has a really slow generic start and I almost gave up on it, but I'm glad I didn't.  The slow start actually helps build the characters and helps with the pay off at the end.  The gameplay is a pretty straight forward cover shooter.  Really nothing new or interesting here.  It is well done, but again, nothing new.

Pros:
-Awesome story
-Really good character progression, seeing the main character fall from grace is an amazing journey.
-Nice set pieces and overall the visuals are decent.
-Perfect length.  At about 6hrs it was just right.
-I absolutley love that the characters all get more and more beat up and battered visually, more games should do this.
-I also love that they had different voice clips as the game progressed where the characters sound more worn out and tired.  Amazing!  More games again need to do this!
-Excellent voice acting.  Nolan North takes the lead and is awesome as usual, but all the other voice actors are amazing!

Cons:
-Slow start could potentially keep people from playing through the whole game.
-Nothing new or interesting about the gameplay, a standard cover shooter.
-I wish they had used the sand storms more often.  I think it only happens two or three times.

Overall a good game with an amazing story.  I wish more games had stories that were as good as this one.  I ended up putting it on Easy mode half way through so I could just play through the story and enjoy the game.  In fact, I actually would recommend playing it on easy as medium (or whatever they call it) was kind of all over the place.  Sometimes it would be perfect, other times it would be really hard.

reviewText:
SpecOps is a kind of strange. You will feel emotions about what you did. There is a great story behind. You will sympathize with your triplets, you will feel confused. And thats about.. Story.. PROS?:
- Level design: futuristic bloody apocalypse
- I really did care about my team
- Weapons: there is a difference, you can feel and you will think, what weapon to grab from a dead soldier, believe me..
- Weapons variety: around 10-15 kinds of weapons/grenades..
- Graphics.. I made many epic screenshots!
- That feeling.. you are fully into it.. you wont skip any animation..
- Gears of Wars taking cover system.. you can use any obstacles to keep you alive. Liked the slides very much :)

CONS:
- sorry, really dunno for $4 :)

if you like action FPS games, GET IT!  and... maybe you will hate the sand to the rest of your LIFE :)

reviewText:
Interessante e cativante, este third person shooter.

O jogo decorre no Dubai, após uma tempestade de areia lançar o caos e semear a destruição. É ordenada a evacuação e cabe-nos a nós com a pequena squad de 3 elementos auxiliar cidadãos a evacuar. Mas há algo macabro na forma como determinadas facções de soldados se comportam e passa a ser a nossa missão investigar o que se passa, auxiliando os civis.

Parece simples e linear, mas não é. E é isso que torna o jogo bastante interessante. O que poderia ser apenas mais um jogo de acção destaca-se pela sua narrativa, pelas escolhas que somos forçados a realizar e pelas suas consequências. Está em jogo a moral e a ética, além da pontaria e das decisões. Não é, definitivamente, um jogo para crianças, pelo conteúdo extremamente violento, tanto graficamente como em termos de história.

Na acção propriamente dita, há laivos de Gears of War misturados com Company of Heroes, cabendo-nos o papel de organizar, de forma simplista, o ataque dos nossos companheiros, enquanto buscamos a melhor posição para defender ou flanquear.

Surpreendeu-me pela positiva, uma vez que tinha ouvido falar pouco do jogo.

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing.

Not for the gameplay, which is fine, but nothing revolutionary.
For the story. It's horrifying, powerful, well told, and necessary.

It's the kind of game that makes you think, about choices. About consequences. About war. About survival. About humanity. About how flawed we are a species.  How fragile.

I wont spoil any of the story here (like some OTHER reviewers... who ought to know better), but this is a game that NEEDS to be experienced.

reviewText: Though the gameplay doesn't innovate and is just a generic third person shooter, the story takes you into the life of Captain Walker as you've been sent to evacuate a post apocalyptic Dubai. It focuses on what war does to people and highlights the monstrosities of wartime, instead of glorifying each kill your comrads reprimand you and question your decisions. It's really gripping and well worth the price.

reviewText:
I started this game up with little expectations as it like just just a cheap TPS with decent graphics and a surprisingly acclaimed story by a well known gaming writer. Figured the story would be o.k enough to justify the price, so I bought it during a sale.

To put it bluntly, yes, gameplay wise it is as GENERIC of a TPS or any shooter for that matter. Guns have little to no punch, enemy AI is basic but otherwise predictable and unchallenging, and weapon variety is decent but limiting with the 2 weapon loadout system... but, BUT... the story...

Let me just say the STORY for this game is the REAL SELLING POINT, far above the gameplay. You play Captain Walker accompanied by his boyband of I swear must be Ice Cube and Matt Damon impersinators. They at first seem uninteresting with that classic HOO RAAAWWW" mentality games like Call of Duty suffer from. As the story progresses they get broken down

reviewText: An amazing game to complete the trifecta of artforms, Heart of Darkness, Apocalypse Now and now this, Spec Ops: The Line. While the only things holding this game back is the functionality of the controls which can be somewhat frustrating at times and of course the length, being about 4-7 hrs depending on how fast you play. What it lacks there it makes it up in some unique mechanics like sand avalanche kills and some really cool enviroments to play in such as a canyon of sand dunes jumping from skyscraper to skyscraper. The gem that is this game however relies solely on one thing however, it's story. Consider the elements of Heart of Darkness and apply them to what war really is, an experience that will leave a man scarred and battered, not only physically but mentally.\n\nGentlemen, welcome to Dubai. 9/10

reviewText:
The Dubai Game! Really, just for its setting it's worth being played. Spec Ops puts you in the shoes of a Delta Force squad leader who - along with two members of the same squad - must uncover the truth behind the disappearance of a famous colonel. Search is immediately started after receiving a radio signal and your squad eventually finds itself in the middle of a war.

The game is a relatively difficult tactical 3rd person shooter - you control the leader but can give orders to the squad members.  You clear one room after the next - while the game is linear it offers a great story that tries to portray the dark side of a war, a war where it's almost impossible to make good choices. The game has stunning visuals and superb voice acting - all delivered from the best in the gaming industry. Replayability exists due to the different difficulties and also the different endings offered based on the choices to be made by the players.

I never tried its multiplayer mode but did not plan to do so. Just for the single player experience this is a highly recommended game not just for those in favour of the genre but for those who like a good story.

reviewText:
To start off I'll say that this is probably the most unexpected success of the year 2012 and probably one of the ridiculous ones'. Now to the actual game.
I'll start with  pros :
1.  Graphics: Now here there isn't much to explain. Astonishing views from the tall sky scrapers of Dubai and the sandy color were on the high level. It makes you believe you are in Dubai on the war zone, and not in your half broken apartment with neighbours drilling walls. Also worth noting that the demands for such beauty aren't high.
2.  Difficulty level: This one is very balanced. Like in some games of this types, you are playing a role of one man army, and fighting against huge huge huge amounts of enemies. Unlike in most of the games, and this is very important, you have very frequent checkpoints. So even if you die, you will not be thrown back to the beginning of      10-20 min fight as often it might happen, but rather 1-5.
3.  Music: During the tense fights you might not even notice it, but the music that's playing is very good, at least to my taste. Some hardcore rock really does it during the fight. Bands like Deep Purple, Alice in Chains, Bjork and others are featured in the game.
4. Plot: And here comes the beast - the reason this game is worth all of the fuss. Mainly, the aim of the plot was to show the tough job of the soldier, and the decision making, but also criticise the fact of the war itself, and the way we make war in general. Some touchy issues were shown like use of chemical weapons such as white phosphorus, and the unpleasant consequences that it can bring. You can accidentally vaporize a whole camp of civilians... And then you will have to deal with it.
One of the other touchy issues, although only if dug deep enough, is the USA invasion" in the middle east countries and their interference in the local conflicts often in order to protect their own interests which brings more victims. But this discussion will not occur here.
In conclusion the plot really makes this game a big deal with very unexpected twist in the end of the game. If you play the game the second time
date: you will feel as if you would watch say Fight Club for the second time. You know the big twist and you can see how the game slowly leads you into it.\n\nRegarding cons
recommended: this game doesn't have too many of them. The big one is movement

reviewText: I would describe the core gameplay as a competent shooter. Nothing too unique. I have become tired by repetitious shooters over the last few years when I just have so many other options in regard to games I can play. What makes this game recommendable is everything else about it. Most obviously the story - its great, and it actually feels pretty important. Its similar to Apocalypse Now but in modern Dubai rather than 70's Vietnam. The story, once it gets rolling, asks you to question how you as a player of a shooter video game can convince yourself that it can ever be right to take the life of another human being - and the lengths we go to make rationalizations for killing. The game is an exercise in cognitive dissonance; you're forced to question the act of killing and come to terms with the consequences of taking another person's life, but at the same time you're supposed to kill hundreds of people. People who thrash about near-death on the ground, coughing up blood, frantically asking for help with what little breath they have left. The story is thoughtful, the voice acting is great, the sound design and implementation of soundtrack are both great, and the game looks great. The core gameplay itself, though, is still pretty average for third-person cover shooters.

reviewText:
Renewed my fading faith In gaming

This game, like many others has sat in my library for..... probably about a year or maybe more. I purchased via a humble bundle and never gave it much thought. It seemed like a simple older consol game that'd be a meh at best.

*insert never have I been so wrong" meme here*

It was one of the more gratifying gaming experiences I have had before. It was one of those story lines that really pulled me along. I played for about 6.5 hours straight and that is fairly rare for me. It is powerful and well constructed. Everything feels deliberate and not without a review board.

This game is what I had been looking for
date: as I have grown extremely bored with these lackluster attempts at game construction lately. Triple A be damned.\n\nI don't do these reviews often. But this game truly deserves your attention. A review
recommended: especially this one will not do it justice. Just give it an hour and you'll see."

reviewText:
SpecOps is a kind of strange. You will feel emotions about what you did. There is a great story behind. You will sympathize with your triplets, you will feel confused. And thats about.. Story.. Many times i forgot about the gameplay and wanted to know, how the story develops further. Just GO GO GO.. Its not Call of Duty,  Thanks God.. It has a face of its own..
PROS?:
- Level design: futuristic bloody apocalypse
- I really did care about my team
- Weapons: there is a difference, you can feel and you will think, what weapon to grab from a dead soldier, believe me..
- Weapons variety: around 10-15 kinds of weapons/grenades..
- Graphics.. I made many epic screenshots!
- That feeling.. you are fully into it.. you wont skip any animation..
- Gears of Wars taking cover system.. you can use any obstacles to keep you alive. Liked the slides very much :)

CONS:
- sorry, really dunno for $4 :)

if you like action FPS games, GET IT!  and... maybe you will hate the sand to the rest of your LIFE :)

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line is a great game, probably one of the best 3rd person shooters I've played. On the surface it appears to be a generic shooter but if you take the time it is a lot more. The story pays homage to the novel Heart Of Darkness, and draws inspiration from Apocalypse Now, which are both exceptional pieces. Unfortunately it does a lot to turn away the casual player, it has lacklustre game play and a very unfortunate title, that was likely a thought by some producer. However once you look past that it really is a hidden gem amongst terrible tripple A titles. Stay for the immersive stories about the glories of war and ignore the short comings of the gameplay. I would reccomend playing this game on a medium difficulty as I played on the Suicide" setting and it was frustrating in all the wrong ways.\nAlso the game was very short
date: I finished on Suicide at 3 hours and 55 minutes. In saying that I got about 50x the enjoyment out of it then any shooter I've played in a long time.\n\nHighly Recommend."

reviewText: Playing this game is rather like watching the proverbial train wreck: you'll be horrified, but you can't look away. This is in no way a bad thing. Spec Ops wants to tell a story about soldiers in war. But unlike games such as Call of Duty, it doesn't want you to feel like an awesome, unstoppable killing machine that's fighting terrorism FOR 'MERICA!!!' or whatever; it wants you to see that war is not glamorous, awesome, fun, or desirable. It wants you to see the terrible toll that combat can exact on those who experience it. And above all, it wants you to see that in real conflict, there are no good guys" and "bad guys
date:
and the world is full of gray areas. War is hell, and anyone who goes in will either join the fortunate dead...or have to live with what they've done to survive.

While I enjoyed the storyline, I felt sad, very sad at parts. The graphics are amazing, worth getting. Because this game tells a story. A sad story about war.


10/10. With sad moments.

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line is a solid 3rd person shooter that focuses on the horrors of war. It's kind of like Apocalypse Now!" with Dubai as the setting but that comparison is giving it a little too much credit.  It's more like an ultraviolent summer blockbuster war movie. The story and dialogue come off hamfisted and silly at times. The voice acting is decent for the most part and the sound design is good.\n\nI would've liked the guns to be louder and bullet snaps would be great for immersion. The shooting mechanics are satisfying and the intensity of the combat is what kept me coming back to 100% this game. It's no "Red Orchestra" immersion wise
date: but I think it illustrates the horrors of war well in some ways. Enemies collapse and some suffer while clutching wounds or crawl away. They cough and whimper as blood pools around them. One thing they never do is surrender
recommended: which is an annoying trope of modern shooters. At least there are unarmed civilians on some levels
hoursPlayed: which goes against convention. The game also forces you into some bad situations with civilians which is a great way to show the ugliness of war.\n\nThe game looks fantastic
voteText: even years later and it's surreal to see Dubai turned into a wartorn blood soaked ruin. Every firefight is fun and challenging if played on the harder difficulty levels. It would've been nice to have stealth be more viable. It's also a little funny that a 3 man squad kills off thousands of enemies. I know it's supposed to be somewhat of a satire on the modern military shooter but I would've rather had "Rainbow Six" style squad selection/commands and losses than 2 invulnerable baby sitters. I hope more games try to execute a "military shooter gone horror" vibe. I really like that the game is a train wreck of bad events and it tries to make you feel responsible and bad for it
helpfulPercent: kind of like the Kane & Lynch series. It was just a little too hamfisted
votesHelpful: on rails and "gamey" for that feeling to hit me
votesTotal: but I enjoyed the horrific descent into madness nonetheless. If you are looking for a solid 3rd person shooter with an intense atmosphere
votesFunny: definitely grab this game.\n\n7/10"

reviewText: A game you will love or hate, absolutely. As a military shooter, it's a generic but functional game with a useless tacked-on multiplayer mode that the developers have openly disowned. As a story-based singleplayer experience, it's notable for taking what starts as the most generic story imaginable and turning it into a meta-narrative that questions the the nature of video games while the protagonist questions his own heroism. While not perfect in its storytelling, it tries something that flies in the face of current trends and is essentially a giant middle-finger to Call of Duty and its imitators. Either you'll be on board with the idea and enjoy its ambiguous storyline, or you'll find it a pretentious attempt at an art game built on the back of a mediocre shooter. If you're curious, it's worth the time and money simply because it exists.

reviewText:
A vailiant effort, but flawed and shows the limits of video games and how they can never be considered art.

Specs Ops: The Line has received much praise in weaving a horrific tale of an op gone wrong and the horrors of war. The game expertly puts you in the shoes of the main character as he teeters on the edge of sanity as his PTSD nightmare slowly consumes him. But in the end, the game's greatest strength is also its greatest weakness.

The game not only encourages, but actively pushes you towards making crazy gamer" decisions that leads to the story spiraling out of control. Executing a downed enemy is a common video game mechanic that players have come to expect. Executing a downed enemy also gives you ammo for both weapons. However
date: should you choose to simply double-tap them with your gun
recommended: you will not spiral into madness at the same rate as a normal playthrough. Although there are many hidden third options to most of your choices
hoursPlayed: the game doesn't let you make any key decisions that sidestep everything.\n\nSpec Ops: The Line does a great job of telling one story but fails to give you the other option of not succumbing to monstrosity. The gameplay is very tiresome and rather boring. Some would say that this is in part of the game trying to parody the meaninglessness of your generic modern First-Person-Shooters
voteText: but was this honestly the best way of going about this? Couldn't we have some fun going down this hellish slide?\n\nI only wish that there were more choices that we could make that would better simulate PTSD/anxiety/paranoia. Why was there no choice to interact with the civillian NPCs in a way that would test our distrust of the local populace? Why was there no option to deal with groups that were obviously armed and cutious
helpfulPercent: yet not overtly hostile?\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: Spec Ops: The Line is a good game to experience but not necessarily to play. I would definitely recommend this game if you enjoy storytelling experiences."

date: far better than even games such as the Telltale's “The Walking Dead”\n\nImmersion/atmosphere: 10/10 The atmosphere was incredible

this game is one of the rare games that you can truly lose yourself in.

hoursPlayed:
this game is rather realistic

Voice acting: 10/10 All the voices suit the characters very well and there is not a single voice actor that taints the immersion of the game.

Player involvement (choices): 10/10 The choices were incredible

however I would have preferred it if there were a few more.

Overall:

I don't really base the score from the minor aspects so the score (from critic point of view) is:
9.75/10

reviewText:
At first glance Spec Ops: The Line looks and feels like a generic 3rd person shooter. Partially that's true; you find cover behind objects, shoot enemies and throw grenades, there's nothing really special about that.

What IS special about Spec Ops: The Line is the story and choices you'll have to make and actually shows you the real face of war, there are no heroes in this game.

The scenery of a destroyed Dubai is really nice aswell are the graphics.

Anyone who enjoys a good, emotional story should play this game.

reviewText: An amazing game to complete the trifecta of artforms, Heart of Darkness, Apocalypse Now and now this, Spec Ops: The Line. While the only things holding this game back is the functionality of the controls which can be somewhat frustrating at times and of course the length, being about 4-7 hrs depending on how fast you play. What it lacks there it makes it up in some unique mechanics like sand avalanche kills and some really cool enviroments to play in such as a canyon of sand dunes jumping from skyscraper to skyscraper. The gem that is this game however relies solely on one thing however, it's story. Consider the elements of Heart of Darkness and apply them to what war really is, an experience that will leave a man scarred and battered, not only physically but mentally.\n\nGentlemen, welcome to Dubai. 9/10

reviewText:
How many times have you played a videogame where at the end you had to question your actions? Question the game? Cry in the bathtub?  With a breathtaking narrative, fantastic visuals and top notch OST you will feel like ♥♥♥♥. But you'll be happy you played this gem.

The only downside of Spec Ops The Line is the gameplay. Not that it's bad, it's actually very solid. But it's unoriginal and feels like a chore when there is so much more going on. The rest of the game breaks new ground, the gameplay is just bland. In the end, I think the problem was really what the Publisher wanted to sell as opposed to what the developer wanted to create. If we look at all the promotional material and even the forced multiplayer, the generic (yet popular in other games) that's the conclusion I get to.

In any case, the story is fantastic and you should give this a shot.

reviewText:
You've probably heard most of the praise to be given to this game by now, so I'll skip the part where I suck this games ♥♥♥♥ for as long as it ♥♥♥♥ing wants and stick to facts:

Gameplay (because this SHOULD be your first concern):
- Shooting is solid and the guns (for the most part) actually feel like they can do some damage which seems to lack for most games. Hit detection never betrays you and you rarely feel cheated.
- Difficult...I mean...enemies can actually pose some form of challenge. They WILL flank you and they WILL toss grenades World at War style but you are usually given a decent enough warning that if you die, it was probably your own fault.
- Close encounters/executions are brutal and the game teaches you this rather quickly in a way that doesn't break the immersion.
- It's actually fun to play. *OPINION WARNING* I genuinely enjoyed playing through it more than once and will be doing it again in the future.
- Both keyboard+mouse and controllers feel good and neither is necessarily preferable to the other.

Story:
- It's a ♥♥♥♥ing bloodbath of a war/rebellion-torn Dubai ravaged by mass sandstorms...survive.
- Okay, there is an initial objective but I don't like spoilers, let's just say there are genuinely concerning questions posed by the twists of a generally taboo topic...think about it...what if the Americans weren't ALWAYS the good guys? Mind-♥♥♥♥ing-explosion, right?!

Visuals (last because it's a ♥♥♥♥ing video game, shut up and play the damn thing):
- On a high-end machine, it's absolutely stunning the amount of detail placed into the game.
- Even on a lower-end pc, the game looks solid and if you don't want your pc game looking slightly worse than on xbox, ♥♥♥♥ing buy it on xbox. Problem solved.
- Small stutter upon checkpoints but you'll survive.

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line is a great game, probably one of the best 3rd person shooters I've played. On the surface it appears to be a generic shooter but if you take the time it is a lot more. The story pays homage to the novel Heart Of Darkness, and draws inspiration from Apocalypse Now, which are both exceptional pieces. Unfortunately it does a lot to turn away the casual player, it has lacklustre game play and a very unfortunate title, that was likely a thought by some producer. However once you look past that it really is a hidden gem amongst terrible tripple A titles. Stay for the immersive stories about the glories of war and ignore the short comings of the gameplay. I would reccomend playing this game on a medium difficulty as I played on the Suicide" setting and it was frustrating in all the wrong ways.\nAlso the game was very short
date: I finished on Suicide at 3 hours and 55 minutes. In saying that I got about 50x the enjoyment out of it then any shooter I've played in a long time.\n\nHighly Recommend."

reviewText:
First off, BUY AND PLAY THIS GAME!, It's absolutley fantastic!

Secondly, here's why:

The story is simply too original to describe, People may overlook this game as a basic mil-spec shooter, but it is NOT! The main focus here is the EFFECTS of war on the soldiers not the shooting, although the mechanics work great and the gameplay feels solid too. The story follows 3 soldiers stranded in a dying Dubai, a Dubai they thought they were there to save. Surrounded by a raging sandstorm that is too strong to break through they fight their way through hostile sand covered streets and buildings to reach their goal of saving the civilians trapped there. Although nothing is what it seems.

The twists and turns the story takes almost put the writing of games like Bioshock and GTA to shame.

GamesRadar.com reviewed the game in their The best videogame stories ever" article and I feel a direct quote would be sufficient:

"Military shooters don't often rank high on the narrative front
date: usually favoring gung-ho G.I. Joe antics and flag waving over character development. And
hoursPlayed: Spec Ops: The Line falls right in line with that stereotype--you take control of Walker
voteText: a soldier sent into a sandstorm-ruined Dubai to find a missing general. But as time goes on it becomes more and more obvious that there's something more devious afoot
helpfulPercent: and the shooter's story transforms from run-of-the-mill to one-of-a-kind.\n\nWhat unfolds is a damning criticism of shooters themselves
votesHelpful: questioning everything that gamers have grown accustom to. Walker's journey sends him marching into the nucleus of the genre
votesTotal: playing with the storytelling in ways no other game has. By the end you might feel anger or sadness
votesFunny: but the important thing is that you'll feel something
commentsCount: and that's pretty rare in military shooters."\n\nI truly feel anyone who can play a shooter
column16: even poorly
column17: NEEDS to experience this game!\n\nSide note
column18: I know it reads out I only have 2.5 hours
column19: but most of the time spent playing through the SP was offline while my internet was disconnected lol."

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a gem in an era where TPS and FPS are becoming dumber and dumber by the release. Companies rush to the chance of making a quick buck by copying a formula that was already successful. On the outside, Spec Ops may look like one of those games. It's gameplay isn't anything to go crazy about. But once you get 2 hours in, you'll realise this game is much deeper than that.

It constantly throws bones to the player about it's meaning, which you ultimately will discover in the end of the game. With that said, the game is perfect in length. It took me about 5 hours to finish, then I did the co-op and played a few games of multiplayer (lackluster MP, Co-op was fun but short) and I was done.

Conclusion: Pick it up on sale. The gameplay is 'meh' but the story and the message/plot twist you will find at the end is well worth the time investment.
Also it has classic rock playing all over the place. Jimmi Hendrix' Star Spangled Banner" is the menu-song.

7.5/10 - It's a great game"

reviewText:
Excelent story telling and gameplay. Everything is spot on, save for a couple large issues.

1.) Cover is everywhere and reliable almost all the time. I say almost, sometimes you'll take cover against the wrong side of a wall and you'll end up dead because of it. Sometimes the cover doesn't work at all. Some things that look like they should be cover aren't, which can get you killed very easily. But as I said, it's very uncommon for this to occur.

2.) The Checkpoint placement is absolutely H O R R E N D O U S, forcing you to redo large battles over and over, considering the game is relatively difficulty. This is a major problem, especially near the end of the game when you lose a squad mate (not permanantly) and are forced to take on droves of enemies on your own. Many battles seem to occur in waves, it would have been nice to overcome one wave of enemies, then get a save, then continue. It has caused me on multiple occasions to quit the game because I just don't have the mental capacity to deal with this kind of rage. This is coming from someone with hundreds of hours clocked in Dark Souls. I know that there's nothing worse than getting far in a tough situation, only to die and have to redo the entire fight. At least in Dark Souls it  makes sense though.

Other than that I only have praise for the game The story is powerful, I like the clashing characters (I don't /like/ their clashing, I just find it realistic and a great way to cause tension), the gunplay is top notch. The enemy chatter when not engaged is realistic and immersive, reminds me of the guys in Battlefield Bad Company 2 who talk about the movie Predator" before you have to kill them. It makes you think that these are real humans
date: it makes you think about your actions and everything you do. Which is
hoursPlayed: the entire point of the game."

reviewText:
A third person shooter that defines not only for its superior military shooter experience, but also for its gripping story. The whole game is intense, unique and will certainly stand out from other third person shooters of the like.

Graphics: 10/10
You’ll be greeted with a sand-filled Dubai metropolis and a vast desert environment full of dangerous hazards. The lighting, shadows and the small details is what makes this game stand out in the graphics department. It really wants you to see the small details that would usually go unnoticed, nice touch.

Storyline: 10/10
It places the player in a situation where a choice must be made whether the player likes it or not. You have come to Dubai for one purpose and one purpose only and that is to locate survivors and radio for Evac. But instead you find this city in the middle of war and the sole purpose of the mission is lost.

Sound: 10/10
Gunshots, the sandstorms and voices sound very clear. There are almost no distortions in the sound that could be heard. Each and every weapon in the game sound different from one another. The character voices sound deep and clear, which is a positive aspect of this game.

Gameplay: 7/10
The third person shooter style gameplay is just like any other generic third person shooter, it’s nothing special I’ve seen before. But that’s not to say this is a bad game, of course it’s not. It plays out smooth with no significant frame drops from location to location. The controls, the movement speed and the weapon recoil are all very well implemented.

Price: 6/10
Coming in at a premium price of £19.99, it is on the expensive side when it comes to the ‘pound per hour’ basis. It’ll only take you around 5-8 hours to finish the game, so it only gets a measly 6 for me. You are better off waiting until this game goes on sale for it to be worth buying.

reviewText:
There is so much to say about this game, but I'll make it simple.

This is one of the most though-provoking modern military shooter in quite awhile. It may seem (and it is presented) like a run of the mill generic shooter, but you will quickly be surprised by the depth in the plot. At some point, it left me with shivers, and made me question my actions. This is a rare thing that you can find in games and this is a proof that gaming is a culture.

All in all, this game is a must play.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line begins like any other shooter game. It ends like no other.

WARNING: There is a mandatory part of the game that should have a gigantic epilepsy warning in it (In middle of chapter 11). Just a word of caution!

The TL;DR short summary (scroll down further for long review):
Pros:
+Incredible single player story. It is thought-provoking and very refreshing. This is what you're playing this game for. Did I mention the story is amazing?
+The decisions you make, aside from being very morally ambigious and there is no good choice"
date: are actually pretty creative in that the game does not tell you WHAT you can choose. It plays both on the minds of the characters as well as YOU
recommended: as a player.\n+Decent gameplay. Standard 3rd person shooter with cover system.\n+Using sand as a gimmick mechanic adds a little originality to the title. There is also a little bit of tactical squad use (ordering your squadmates to do things) that is limited
hoursPlayed: but works very effectively and keeps the game from being too boring.\n+Great music

helpfulPercent: such as Hendrix

votesTotal:
but...

column16: although I found it to be the perfect length. Any longer and it would have been too dragged out.\n\nAlthough I played this fairly late (a couple years late
column17: since this came out in 2012)
column18: it still remains a testament to story telling in video games
column19: let alone one that is so focused on the things most people seemed to be entertained by - Ridiculous amounts of violence involving weapons and warfare. One only needs to look at the recent sales of the biggest hits to notice the impact shooters have in the games industry.\n\nSpec Ops: The Line is a terribly dull title and has a "seen that before" cover art. But don't judge a game by its cover
column20: as it contains some truly entertaining and thought-provoking storytelling that is sadly rare in the shooting genre these days.\n\nTaking place in Dubai
column21: the worst sandstorms in history hit the region
column22: stranding many civilians. The "Damned 33rd" infantry battalion of the United States Army is sent in on relief duty
column23: led by a famous Colonel named John Konrad. However
column24: it appears he and his unit deserted; they disobeyed orders to abandon the city
column25: and the sandstorms effectively create a 'wall' that prevents surveillance and communications
column26: essentially making Dubai a 'no man's land' where no one knows what's going on. You play as Captain Martin Walker
column27: who is sent alongside two fellow soldiers as Delta Force operators for reconaissance. The mission is simple: Confirm the statues of Konrad and any other survivors
column28: then radio for extraction.\n\nAs officially stated by the game's advertisement/captions
column29: the story is very rich and takes plenty of influence from the novel "Heart of Darkness"
column30: as well as the movie "Apocalypse Now". Without spoiling this game any further

column32: but not in the same in way a bad game would. As you delve deeper

column36: tough decisions and more....\n\nIt starts off innocently enough
column37: almost like every other shooter out there. America coming in to save the day
column39: nothing you haven't seen before. Next thing you know
column40: the line gets very blurry and there are no "good" or "bad" guys
column41: no "good" or "bad" decisions. By the time you enter the credits
column42: you're left looking at war in a different way
column43: and thinking about the actions and consequences of people.\n\nIn addition
column44: the little touches are pretty awesome. Be sure to take breaks frequently and see how the main menu has changed throughout your progression of the campaign. Take in the environmental storytelling (additional "stories" you observe by looking at things not necessarily important to the main plot). Pick up glowing objects ("Intel") to reveal additional story threads. And DEFINITELY pay attention to the loading screens - they are plenty of them and they...well

reviewText:
At first sight when you never play this game to the very end; small levels with quite linear gameplay so a normal rail shooter by today’s standards, worth a look if you like the shooter genre (as you can tell I am not a fan of the genre)
When you finish the game: The story just changed everything and makes you think the game is epic because of very unexpected changes.

I really enjoyed this game because I hate your typical mainstream hero shooter game with 0 relation to the real horror of warfare. This game emerged me so much I played it from start to end in 1 day a rare thing for me.
Your 2 AI companions are surprisingly smart, rarely had to save them from a stupid action + I can order them to focus on my target and I experienced 0 bugs. I only talk about single player but there seem to be a few co-op missions and multiplayer for which I (and most players) did not care.

Graphically it was great, the choices and rare use of environment are appreciated but don't mean or change much. The story is the big plus for this game and was well executed. There are no good guys in this game only realistic humans. Wish there were more shooters like this but with more meaningful choices and bigger levels.

At the discount I bought it, definitely recommend it. I never recommend shooters at full price they don’t last long enough and offer little replay ability in this case maybe once for a special difficulty, some collectables and the different endings.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Expecting a standard military TPS with some hamfisted morality message, I was instead treated to one of the greatest psychedelic war stories in recent memory.  The most I can say without spoiling anything is that Spec Ops: The Line calls to mind the 2nd half of Full Metal Jacket, Apocalypse Now, or the burning oil refinery scene in Jarhead.  It is a very well thought-out and self-aware commentary on the insanity of combat, culminating in an immensely satisfying and mindscrewing gauntlet.

Mechanically the game is solid, although snapping in and out of cover is occasionally more awkward than it should be.  Ammunition is scarce even on the default difficulty, and nearly every encounter is designed in such a way that the tools for victory are always available if you have the right strategy.  I never felt like I was dying for any reason other than my own lack of skill.  Checkpoints are infrequent, so the sense of tension and reward when you clear a particularly difficult segment is tangible.  Compared to most other recent shooters this was a huge breath of fresh air.  Spec Ops respects your intelligence enough to assume you can figure out a way to shoot everybody in the room if you just put some thought into it.

I bought and played this game on a whim (and because of a particular scene which you may have seen on Youtube involving incendiary weaponry).  If you've seen the same scene and felt the game was ruined/spoiled as a result, I assure you it's not.  That particular incident garnered a lot of publicity but only occurs about halfway into the game, with much more potent and interesting twists ahead of it.

I still don't feel like a hero yet.

reviewText: I just finished Spec Ops: The Line and I felt compelled to write a review.  I thought it was a descent shooter.  It was challenging  with an engaging environment.  It is set in a ravaged Dubai and you can see the opulence it once held combined with the savagery of the sand desert.   A good verity of weapons.  An interesting story if yet sometimes hard to follow.  There is nothing new here that you will not find in other games but it is all done well.  The graphics are descent.  The challenge is adjustable.  There is a coop mode and a multiplayer, but you better bring a friend because these areas are lacking in participants.  Overall a good game.  I give it 8 out of 10.

reviewText: Certainly the best modern military shooter I have ever played ! Fluid gameplay, tactical and makes you stop and think for the best way to engage your problems or your enemies, instead of just running around and shooting, squad based strategy so you don't have to worry about godlike npc's who never die because you fail your mission if your squad breaks and the storyline makes the game a whole lot to play for. Makes you think why do wars exist, who kills and who gets blamed, what war does to a mind of a soldier who faces death everyday and lives to tell the story, what are the costs of following your orders and how far can you go to achieve your goal, or a madman's goal, how insane can you become and what's real and what's your imagination, how far can you go and who can you protect. Spec ops: The line, title says it all, sometimes there is a line that must be crossed for the greater good, question is, is it really the greater good? Or is it just a vision of a madman?

reviewText:
This game surprised me in so many ways. My initial impression after completing the demo was a boring and generic third person cover based shooter with little that interested me. Now that I’ve sunk some hours into it, I can safely say my first impression was so wrong!

Spec Ops: The Line is actually one of the most moving games I’ve ever played. The setting, the characters, the overall story and decisions, it all comes together to form such an unforgettable experience. Instead of mindless violence, the player sees the effect each enemy encounter has on the main characters. There’s a progression in the attitude of the characters towards both the enemies and each other. Few games manage to successfully pull this off without making it look outright cheesy.
The sandy Dubai setting and unique back story make Spec Ops: The Line even more interesting. No more generic military desert country with “insurgents” and mud huts. Dubai really does feel like Dubai and the problems that exist there feel genuine and make you want to find out more. It’s safe to say that there are plenty of decent twists throughout the story line.
The only problem I’ve noticed with Spec Ops is the gameplay which (although fun and addictive) could be improved upon. Enemies moving around and suddenly popping up from cover looks unnatural and the ballistic and particle effects look rubbish (when you shoot walls, fire your weapon). It’s still fun to use all the different weapons and basic squad tactics though. Seeing the look on the main character’s face as he gets shot at is priceless :D
Spec Ops: The Line is one of the most surprising games I’ve ever played and I feel truly humbled to have found such a gem amongst a year of generic shooters that seriously lack story. The developers at Yager studios put their heart and soul into making The Line what it is and it shows (the same can’t be said for the absolutely terrible multiplayer, but that was made by another studio so who gives a ♥♥♥♥).

reviewText:
Do not mistake this as an anti-war piece. This is a game about games. It holds up a mirror to the player and questions their motivations. Why do you play military shooters? Why do you want to kill people? Why are you looking for excuses to kill people in these games? Do you think you're a hero? To go into more detail would be to spoil an experience that should not be spoiled. I may have given away too much already.

On the more mechanical front the game is a solid third person cover based shooter with some light tactical squad order mechanics. It plays well but within that genre but never steps into the realm of truly great gameplay. If you like cover based shooters you'll probably enjoy the gameplay.

The design and detail of the game is exceptional though. It looks lovely and makes great use of its setting in the environment design. Everything is highly detailed, even the voice lines. When giving orders Walker will say exactly where enemies are. Under the bridge"

reviewText:
8,5/10
Spec Ops The Line is an underrated game. If it was advertised like AAA titles it'd be one of best games of 2012.
The story is good, giving choices and hcallanging (if played on highest difficulty). Some of moments that occur in the game are morally questionable. In real life they are considered war crime's. The game shows brutality of the war in small manner and complete lack of emotions from the oppressors.
I recommend this game to everyone looking to have a great time in the game that is not casual! It can be completed within 7 hours.

+ Interesting story with multiple choices at every occasion.
+ Not boring with decent combat. Cover system reminds of Gears of War series.
+Shows stuff that those pseudo-war games aka CoD and BF will never show.
+ Not casual, it is easy to die.
+ Low system requirements.
+ Replayability value  (different choices throughout the game)
+ Co-op
+ Nice graphic quality...

- ... textures could use higher resolution
- too sensitive mouse controls, you need to set it to 1 ongame options at 2000DPi mouse to be playable
- Linear story with choices. Yes, those choices are insignificant sometimes they are wrong.

Neutral:

Game lasts 6-7 hours.

Out of all these advantages and disadvantages I recommend this game. Normally it costs 20€, it's good price but if you're saving money get it while on sale for 5€ ;) Regardless of which option you choose, it will be money well spent.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is one of the only games I would ever recommend putting on the lowest difficulty on the first playthrough.
This is not a game you play for the amazing gameplay, although it's nothing worse than generic. I liked it. Different strokes for different folks.

Were it to be judged purely on its design and mechanics, Spec Ops: The Line would be pretty forgettable, but it has an ace in the hole. And it's a bigg'un: a story so out of the blue in its direction and message that it's a miracle, a major publisher put this game out at all. What you think you're getting- particularly if you only play the demo- is another gung-ho gun-wielding slice of Americans saving the day by killing all the brown people. What you actually get is a slow, spiralling descent into madness of one man, that wears its Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now inspirations proudly and uses them to forge a modern-day commentary on the type of video game you thought you were going to play.

Captain Walker is no tiantic Call of Duty avatar who can murder a thousand people and walk away- he falls apart mentally, visually and audibly as the game continues, his professionalism is stripped away and raw ego left exposed. Tango down" becomes a more chilling
date: "Kill is ♥♥♥♥ing confirmed" as the game confronts you with issues of culpability and responsibility. It's incredibly unsettling and so out of the ordinary for the modern gamer that to most people
recommended:
this might be thrown aside in disgust.

This is no Gears Of War/Army Of Two clone. This is the story of one man who loses himself to the brutality of war.

To the open minded and for someone who wants a great story mixed with an unsettling message
hoursPlayed: this is a MUST OWN.\n\n"

reviewText:
2-sentence review : I came to that game from the hype about the difficult moral choices, but there was none (the marketing guys probably never played any RPG in their life). However, I got a solid TPS with a lot of action and an incredible scenery, packaged in an intriguing but ultimately disappointing story-telling.

Pros :- Amazing & original scenery : Dubai lost in a desert storm
- Even better, the scenery is well exploited and brings a lot in the gameplay
- Solid TPS gameplay ; nothing out of the ordinary, but all the basis are there and well implemented
- Good story-telling, but...

Cons :- ... But the story doesn't make much sense (yup, I've read all the explanations and they still don't explain correctly a lot of things ; I guess it's just hard to fit what the authors wanted to do with the mechanisms of a shooter game)
- Worst, the story setting isn't explained clearly, which made me know less than the protagonists and let me wondering what's the heck was going on during almost all the game
- The story setting is actually some kind of Science-Fiction stuff ; it's not bad in itself, but it would have required some clear explanation (in very short : Dubai has been taken in a several months long desert storm and people are going to die soon)
- We have to find some intelligence during the game that explains a bit more what happened in Dubai ; some of this stuff is hidden, which means I missed some and it made the story even more muddy... :-/
- It is in no way tactical (not a con for me, but it's advertised otherwise, so better be clear on that)

Bonus Note :Major Spoiler : I'm going to explain why the moral concept completely failed for me.
There's no choice that matters, and worst, no choice I felt implicated into.
Story-wise, the point of no return is when our character kills by mistake civilians. However, I had spotted these civilians and consciously did my best to avoid killing them by firing the mortar on the opposite side of where they were standing. The game still killed them all by making that particular mortar explosion much much bigger than the previous ones. Bummer... :-/
I also almost never shot 1st, died several times for that, and thus it completely voids the idea we're the bad guys...

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line.

To start of with I throught this game was just one of those games were everyone would ignore it, and it would just quietly past by in the corner. But no this game is a hidden gem, here is why.

Spec Ops The Line is a 3rd person shooter, with a cover system. But Unlike the rest, this one is more story driven, this makes a massive difference to the way this game plays.

Graphics, this game looked stunning when it first came out, and it still does now. The Devs really put alot of attension to detial and passion into this game..
The charators look good and they animate very well, voice sync is pretty much perfect to lip movement etc. The guns you can tell what they are, but remember this is a 3rd person shooter.
Finally the envirment, just wow, however word of warning which comes with a spoiler alert...This game turns...Dark and sinister quite quickly, now I did warn you that this one is different.

Sounds, the weapons sound belivable, but when playing I m spending most of my time not getting shot than I am admiring the sound of the weapons. Explosions have a bassy smooth boom to them, the envirment itself when not in a fire fight is quite quiet all you can hear is the wind howling around the buildings and things moving about in the wind.
Music is quite unnoticable during quiet stages of the game, just your standard low intensity tranquil music, till later in the game were the music turns, darker... the firefights the music does pick up but its over showed by the firefight itself.
Last, voice acting. These are fantasic I mean they would be, this is a story driven 3 rd person shooter. You can even hear the mood in the voices they are that well done.

Story, without giving away too much, this game is based in a storm ridden dubia, you are leader of 3 Spec ops trying to find survers and the dammed 31St"..But what you acturly find is..a place full of chaos
date: and civial war. This is all I m wanting to give away.\n\nGameplay

Spec Ops the line is a great 3 rd person

reviewText:
First thing I want to say before writing this review is that if you dislike strong political statements or anything that breaks the 4th wall you should not play this game. Spec Ops: The Line is set in Dubai after the Country was destroyed by sandstorms. You are a 3 man Delta force unit sent in to find out what happened to a US army 33rd Battalion. Sooner rather than later you find dead American soldiers scattered around and are attacked by an unknown enemy foce that will be revealed later into the game.

After the first encounter with the enemy insurgents you are met with a radio broadcast that signals you to US soldiers who have been captured by the enemy. You don't get there in time however and two of the soldiers are executed. One soldier remains who is slowly bleeding out and tells you about the 33rd battalion. Your unit moves into the city and it's all gone to hell.

The story of this game is absolutely magnificent and the way that the developers played it out made it even better. The length of the story was perfect and if they played it out anymore than they did it probably would have been boring and would have seemed to be dragged out. It's short, with about 6 hours play time but it has some replayability with the achievements and the unlockable difficulty.

There are multiple things to destroy in this game that makes sand smash everything which can be quite hilarious. There are also choices that the player needs to make which can effect what happens with the story and the direction the game is going in. There are also multiple endings which I will leave you to find out. When facing these decisions the player will go through and question themselves when choosing which one to do. There are also a lot of dead bodies in this game, a lot. There are also a lot of burning bodies and burned bodies.

Graphics on this game are great, the scenery is very nice and even though most of it is sand and destroyed buildings it still looks great. Even though I played on medium settings it still looked good so if you have it on High with AA turned to the highest it would look amazing.

Overall this game is a 9/10 and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes third person shooters which are different and want a bit of variety.

reviewText: Spec Ops The Line is by no means a perfect game, the gameplay is basic, it's a third person cover shooter set in the desert. The mulitplayer while a nice bonus is an odd inclusion considering the tone and content of the story. Even though the gameplay is standard and basic the story is where this game truly shines. This game achieves through its single player campaign what games like Call of Duty, Medal of Honor, Battlefield and countless other war games have tried to do. It puts you in the middle of a harsh war scenario where you have to think on your feet and make moral decisions. If you're going to play one game about war I highly suggest this one.

reviewText:
