reviewText:
A nearly flawless third person shooter.

Let's get the story out of the way. You play as Captain Walker who, along with the other two guys, is sent to the destroyed city of Dubai in order to investigate a distress signal by the missing Colonel Konrad. Pretty soon you discover that the city is not empty and is filled with some civilians as well as the AWOL U.S. 33rd Army battalion which was supposed to evacuate the city after being deployed in Kabul. You then quickly proceed to battling and killing your country-men. Neat. I'm surprised this German developer didn't get any heat from critics yet for giving you the ability to kill U.S. army men. Along the way, you unravel the mystery as to what exactly is happening.

The scenery is quite breathtaking. The Unreal 3.0 engine makes character models and distant vistas look crisp. The desert is so well made that it reminded me of the Uncharted 3 desert. You also get to leave foot prints in the sand. There are no texture pop ins and every texture is pre-rendered. However, the amount of video options is limited. The engine provides no DX10,11 or anti-aliasing for that matter.

The game itself plays like a solid A/B action flick. There are some grand action set pieces, there is plenty of dialogue, there are opportunities to sneak up on enemy and there are some grave choices to be made and alter game in the process.

One of the most essential components of the game is the A.I. and boy is it good, both friendly and A.I. The enemy soldiers will communicate with each other, they will give out orders, they will attempt to flank you and sometimes attack you from both sides at the same time, they WILL run away and jump away from your grenades, they will retreat, raise alarms, call for back ups, they will also throw grenades pretty accurately and they will do suppressing fire as well. However, some handpicked A.I. will just stand there without taking cover, just waiting to be shot. The reason is that if they are standing on the glass or next to a mountain of sand behind glass, they can be killed with the force of the surrounding environment.

This game forces you to think when dealing with the enemy. They aren't supermen and they aren't pushovers either.

As for the friendly A.I., well just about the only way that you can order your teammates around is by telling them to attack this guy or that guy or flash bang them. However, once you do give the order, your team mates will do their best to take out the indicated guy either with regular rifles, sniper fire or grenades. At times, I saw my team mates stand their own ground pretty effectively. This feature is unparalleled with many shooters, wherein even IF you are a part of the team, you are the one getting shot at most and you are the one having to kill every foe. (COD ahem)

You also get to collect intel and figure out what happened to the populace and Dubai in general after the biggest sand storms decimated the city.

Something about the gameplay feels right, I can't quite put my finger on it. You can only carry two weapons and a handful of grenades. The ammo is always scarce so the game forces you to not waste ammo. I also like how any assault rifle magazine will be out of ammo after just a few bursts - it's all pretty realistic. There is no evasion button and there is no prone button. The constant sand storm atmosphere creates a hostile and extreme environment and the sound of sand storms is quite deafening. Also, what's awesome is that once your frag grenade explodes, it also creates a collateral sand fog which stuns the surviving enemies which can be plucked one by one.

As far as the weapons are concerned, well, every other weapon has a secondary feature. The M-16 or whatever has a silencer, so does the pistol, the AK-47 has a three bullet burst feature, the sniper rifle has a 8x, 16x zoom feature, etc.

The thing that quite often DOES mess up the gameplay is the sprinting, that's right. When you go forward press space" for sprinting (default) and then let go of "space"
date: Walker will just keep sprinting for an indefinite amount of time. And if you want to stop immediately
hoursPlayed: to back up. So I decided to switch to the good old "shift" for sprinting instead. It sorta helped but the running still feels consolish
voteText: especially when you try to make sharp turns and attempt to take cover while being shot at. What sucks again though is that the crappy consolized controls made "shift" stand for both sprinting AND melee. It's like
helpfulPercent: seriously devs? You could not allocate a separate action key for melee for us
votesHelpful: PC gamers? we do have a keyboard
votesTotal: you know.\n\nOh about that

I've also noticed that the devs put a lot of effort into level design which look as if they were taken from real locations. The flamboyant hotel rooms

reviewText: One of, if not, the best game of the last generation. What is may lose credit for in it's text book third based shooter gameplay it easily makes up for ten fold in it's beautiful setting, deep character development, amazing soundtrack combined with an unforgettable story line that is based off of a mix of Heart of Darkness and Apocalypse Now. Without spoiling this for you the game can be seen as a breakdown and reflection on the last gen's boom in massively violent modern day shooters, you can even go as far as to say it's insulting our love for violence in any mass medium to the point you can wonder if they did the generic gameplay on purpose to see how dedicated it's player was to see his or her conflict to it's end.\n\nTLDR; Buy this game, you owe it to yourself.

reviewText: This game is incredible. From story to gameplay I loved every minute. I played it on Suicide difficulty my first time through and hadmy ♥♥♥ handed to me on several occasions. I finished it and probably would have regreted playing on a different difficulty so for that I am pleased. The combat is nothing special, but it is in the story that the true genius of this game is found.\n\nThe story is something that I would not have imagined from a game of this genre so that is a huge positive in my books. Unlike Call of Duty of Battlefield where some might argue that violence is celebrated, this game shows the true horror of war.. This horror is reflected upon the psyche of the characters in the game, in their clothes and the way they speak. The gradual decline and spiral towards madness is a slippery slope that is well portade in this game. This is a must play game.

reviewText:
If spec-ops is guilty of one thing, its being a damn good story wrapped up in a rather run-of-the-mill Third Person Shooter.

If you've played any Third person shooter ever, you've played Spec-ops twice.

Everything else is great.

The setting is unique and well used. The story is really well told and doesn't pull any of its punches and I enjoyed the heck out of the characters.

On release day it was about 70$. I got it for 40$. Its worth about 40$. With a run time of four hours, it would have made a better movie, but as far as Vidya game stories go, this is one of the best.

If only it could escape the constraints of a genre that hasn't changed since the first gears of war.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you want a great single player experience, this really is a great game for that.
Spec Ops The Line may look like your standard 3rd person shooter. In many ways, it is. However, this is somewhat deliberate due to the context of the game being a gritty, dark game in a unique setting that makes you question everything about shooters such as these.
This is a game that reminds you the reality of war compared to war in video games. In many games, you gun through loads of enemies because thee game told you to without thinking why. This game makes you think why.  In many games, you're a hero that saves the  day. This game makes you think what makes you that hero. The game beats you up for doing tthings that it common practice in shooters, and really makes you think differently about modern day shooters we see all so much of. This is helped by some great voice acting and script work along with both subtle and shocking story devices that make this game feel unique. The story has some shocking moments that you'll want to experience for yourself.
Those looking for a rich gameplay experience or a multiplayer masterpiece or even a game that makes you feel good for being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that kills more people than he saves may want to go elsewhere. Those looking for a unique story and setting with developed characters and good enough gameplay that questions everything in the shooter genre to date, this game is for you.

reviewText: Definitely a buy when cheap. Although masked by a 'generic FPS blow ♥♥♥♥ up AMERICA' theme, once you pull that away it leaves behind a surprisingly compelling story. Decent character interaction and development with multiple choices really gets you into the atmosphere. Yet the whole point of this game is its story - you'll genuinely feel like a monster afterwards. A decent generic waist - high cover shooter with decent graphics and decent characters with a very in - depth storyline intrinsic with deep philosophical and moral themes. Pay no more than £5, this is a single playthrough game for the weekend that really gets you thinking.

reviewText:
Spec Ops: The Line is a hidden gem in the shooter genre. In the wake of other AAA titles like the Call of Duty, Battlefield, Gears of War, Just Cause, Resident Evil and countless other shooter based franchises, Spec Ops: The Line truly captures the essence of great gaming that is usually missed by other tripple A titles. A heart felt story with likable characters who go from clean-cut delta operators to rugged murderers with heavy conciouses. The story is truly beautiful with severeal different endings all of which prove to give the feeling of sorrow as you see how far Capitan Walker has fallen into darkness. Stellar voice acting that progresses as you move through the campaign and reacts to situations. Spec Ops: The Line take away the romanticised views of war that most war games have and open the player's eyes that in war you're going to make choices between outcomes that are wrong and wronger, there is no right in war. With beautiful writing and an action pack campaign Spec Ops delivers 110%.

Some people complain that many of the choices you make don't have too much effect on the story but personally i belive the devs made it this way to show that in times of crisis a lot of the decisions you make are insignificant because in the end everyone dies in a blaze of glory and only the lucky can make it out alive and even then, they leave part of themselves behind.

The only things I can find wrong with the game are the ♥♥♥♥ multiplayer (so close to having the perfect game but sorry), and slightly wonky controls, however you get used to judging distance before hitting certian buttons (example: accidentally meleeing a car instead of going into cover because you were too far away when you hit the cover/melee key)

Don't get me wrong, the game doesn't bring anything new to the shooter genre, some could even say it starts off as a generic shooter game but, it quickly shows that it did so deliberatly in order to show the true horrors of war. What it does is use everything the shooter genre does right and fix the one thing it does wrong: leave out the results of your actions and the true horrors of war.

I would highly recommend this game to all fans of the shooter genre and those who are casual players of shooter games because this game is truly an experience that everyone need to experience once in their life.

Singleplayer story: 11/10 absolutely perfect

Controls: 9.5/10 difficult at first with slightly unconventional key bindings but the game eases you in and you can quickly master the controls

Multiplayer: 6/10 rushed, nothing special, kinda ♥♥♥♥, nobody plays the multiplayer anymore though so don't even worry about it. It has co-op though! But that is its only saving grace.

Overall i'd give it a 10/10, its flaws are so insignificant that they are overshadowed by everything the game does right, get this game ASAP, you won't regret it.

Do you feel like a hero yet Walker?
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game starts out as your typical first person shooter and quickly evolves into a memorable immersive experience.
You will begin questioning if your doing the right thing or not. You will slowly learn what it means to be a true solder and experience the difficult decisions in front of you. And the many dead bodies you leave behind.

This game is very story driven. It shows how war can change a person and make them question reality. By the end of the game I was stunned by the ending and even after playing it through a second time my feelings didn't change.

If you want a regular FPS get something like CoD or Battlefield. If you want something that you wont forget and will tug your mind in different directions get this!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is absolutely amazing and has one of the best storyline I have ever came across in any video games. Make sure you pay attention to the dialogues as the game progresses, as not fully understanding the backstory or one event in a chain may drastically hamper the feelings of what the story is trying to push onto you. In my opinion, it's far more important than the gameplay at times in order to get the most of this game because of so. The plot development is very well thought out and unpredictable, and the chain of events plus the sudden twist near the end will really make you think deeply once the game concludes. A lot of the cutscenes in the game are not like typical ones you'd find in modern shooters, as they were made to emphesize the emotions felt by the characters as well as passing it to you. A movie should be made based on the plot of this game, as there hasn't been much military movies made with plot that will make you feel emotional about what the mental torments the soldiers have to go through.

reviewText:
Like others have said, this is an incredible story that only gets better as you move through it. The characters grow and you're right there with them. The city itself is also ridiculously beautiful. You even get caught in dust storms at times, which is pretty cool.

The one thing I found occasionally frustrating is the sticky Sprint (which apparently is a feature, not a bug - kinda dumb). But the game/story is so good that, all in all, I'm really glad I put up with the mild annoyance.

It's really unfortunate that the game didn't do so well financially and the developers said they wouldn't make another like it for a while. The Line is a real gem. I hadn't heard about it until recently - hopefully if enough new people realize it's worth buying, the devs will have a change of heart. Then again, this game is so unique that I'm not sure it would work a second time.

Bottom line: Get it. If it's on sale, you really have no excuse. And stay away from spoilers!

reviewText:
Outstanding Story with a breathtaking plot with alternative endings.
Spec Ops is about you, the effects of your actions, and events that are out of your control.
This game defies the standard army shooter in a way that you have never seen before, it actually makes you question your actions, where you find yourself asking if killing is right or wrong.

Multiplayer's a wash, but the campaign is worth replaying - seeing the same events while knowing what's really going on is uncomfortable in new ways, but the intelligent encounters and level design make each fight exciting, and the voice acting creates genuine and believable characters.

Absolutely, and without a doubt, one of the best stories you'll find in any game.

reviewText:
This game is ♥♥♥♥ed up.  This game is really, really ♥♥♥♥ed up - but not remotely in a bad way.  This is hard for me to review; it's just something that you have to experience.

A+ to Yager.  Looking back and seeing that I completed the campaign in less than six hours, I had no idea that it was that short" - the pacing is well-done and the story gripping.  I very much would love to see them be able to create more titles as mindblowing and mature as this one.

Spec Ops: The Line - buy it."

reviewText: Wonky controls due to bad implementation of the context-sensitive spacebar and shift, utterly unremarkable combat and weapons, and the least satisfying AA12 in any videogame ever. That said, Spec Ops: The Line is a game with great presentation, wonderful visuals, and a very fascinating deconstruction of the modern shooter which, though somewhat heavy handed and sometimes pretentious, remains engaging enough to make up for a few of it's flaws.

reviewText:
This is basically PTSD: The Game.

As a game, it's pretty standard.  You get into cover.  You shoot guys with guns.  Run to the waypoint to continue getting into cover and shooting guys with guns.  It feels fairly clunky to actually get into cover.  I felt like I had to hit the space bar a specific way to actually get into cover.  There are a handful of weapons in different categories like rifles, shotguns, small arms, snipers and heavy weapons.  Everything feels fairly generic with a few exceptions like shooting a part of the environment to dump sand on your foes and that's about it.  You can give orders to your team, but some orders only pop up at specific times and I could never seem to be able to use the attack order.  I was able to beat the campaign on the hardest availible starting difficulty in under 7 hours.  Again, as a game, it's pretty generic.

As an experience, it's a completely different beast.  Never in my life have I played a military shooter that was this shocking.  If you thought the nuke scene and no russian" from Call of Duty were hardcore
date: then you haven't seen anything yet.  It's really something you have to see for yourself and I wouldn't dare spoil it.  If I had to compare the story to anything
recommended: it feels a lot like the movie "Apocalypse Now" and if you've seen that movie then you should be aware of the levels of shock you are getting into...but even the story here goes above and beyond that.   Again
hoursPlayed: as an experience
voteText: it's quite unique.\n\nIf you can get it cheap
helpfulPercent: do not pass it up even if you don't like cover shooters.  This is one game you need to see to the end..."

reviewText: Spec Ops: The line starts off seeming like a pretty ordinary, run-of-the-mill shooter (set in a semi-surreal Dubai) and then develops into one of the best story-driven shooters ever made (contradicted by the undeserved meta-score).\n\nDon't enter The Line with high expectations in the way of gunplay and all, but be prepared for a harrowing story-driven experience. I don't recommend reading too too much about the game before playing because the story is easily-spoiled once you're made aware of its inspirations (a certain piece of literature, and a certain film).

- no sandbox here

reviewText:
Good storyline, excellent image composition, awesome music, a couple of weaknesses.

The story of Spec Ops: The Line is somewhat different from your average shooter game. While you get to kill everyone you see, you don't get to be a hero for it. At times though, it feels a bit artificial and i could not quite immerse in the story. This maybe because it is sometimes quite brutal in showing the consequences of... well, killing everyone. I really enjoyed the imagery used in the game and the composition of colors. It was just nice to look at (at least while it didn't show you burned corpses and the like). The level design itself was rather linear though. The music is really awesome and reminded me instantly of the game's inspiration, Apocalypse Now.

What i really didn't like about the game were it's technical shortcomings (which mostly deduce from it being released on console aswell). The thing that annoyed me the most were the controls. I don't know how many times i was killed because the same button is used for cover and sprint. Actually even console controllers should have enough buttons, so why not just use different buttons ffs? Anti-aliasing would have been nice, but apparently consoles don't have it, so neither has the pc version. Last but not least, while the main character was high detail, everything else wasn't. The textures used on the environment were rather muddy, even for a 2012 title.

reviewText:
Ah.. what do I say... or infact.. what do I start with...

The way the game takes in inspiration from Heart of Darkness, a book frirst published in 1899 and written by Joseph Conrad, which centers around Marlow, an introspective sailor, and his journey up the Congo River to meet Kurtz, reputed to be an idealistic man of great abilities.. or the fact that it makes references to the great 1979 movie Apocalypse Now, directed by Francis Ford Coppola, taking place during the Vietnam War.... many things reference both.. such as the Phosphorus scences.... depicting the shear awsomeness of the weapon itself... yet also having such emphisas on its horrid use and concequences...

This game is too great to be left alone... its a must play... you will have some great times... and some wishing you'd haven't chose that path...

And to finish this review off... the wellsaid line of what I think... one of the greatest movies to ever come out of the U.S. of A...

Lance: What?

Kilgore: I love the smell of napalm in the morning. You know, one time we had a hill bombed, for 12 hours. When it was all over, I walked up. We didn't find one of 'em, not one stinkin' dink body. The smell, you know that gasoline smell, the whole hill. Smelled like

reviewText: Spec Ops: The Line. Praised for the wrong reasons, bashed for the wrong reasons. As someone who took the time to complete all achievements in this game, I think I can safely say it has a special place in my heart. So maybe I'm biased. Oh well. Look, there's more to this game than the infamous scenes you probably know about by now. The game's so much more interesting in its subtle elements and references to previous works of literature or film. Look, just play The Line. Or don't. Some people played it and thought it was a pretentius piece of crap. Well, they're kind of right. It tries too hard sometimes. But for some reason, I can't keep forgetting about this little game. Something about it just feels... right to me. Maybe it's the 33rd's interesting personalities. Maybe it's the great music. Maybe it's the feeling of what just happened?" you'll often experience. Just remember one thing: you can leave Dubai
